About the editors

Toshio Ito is a professor at the Department of Machinery and Control Systems, College of Systems Engineering and Science, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Japan. From 1982- 2013 he worked at Daihatsu Motor Co., in R&D for advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS) and commercialized pre- crash safety systems. Since 2013 he has been a professor at the Shibaura Institute of Technology, where he specializes in the study of the driver behaviour for ADAS and driving simulators.

Toshiya Hirose is an associate professor at the Department of Engineering Science and Mechanics, College of Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Japan. Previously, he worked at National Traffic Safety and Environment Laboratory (NTSEL) in Japan. He joined the Shibaura Institute of Technology in 2013. He specializes in research using driving simulators for the construction of driving models, and evaluation of driver assist systems and automated driving systems.
Introduction

There is a need for the development of a technology that deeply intervenes in driving operations conventionally performed by humans, such as driving assistance and further automated driving. Furthermore, as represented by the word "smart city", etc., development that integrates urban development and automobile and mobility is also in progress. Technology development that takes human factors into consideration, such as how people will be affected and how people react to infrastructure in response to driving interventions from automobiles, will be essential. So far, these issues have been examined through traffic experiments using actual vehicles in the field of operation, but they require a lot of energy and time, and the impact on the daily life of neighborhood residents cannot be ignored. Therefore, it is required to conduct social experiments efficiently and to promote technology development in consideration of human factors.

It is expected that the market for driving simulators (hereinafter referred to as DS) will be expanded at home and abroad as technology such as driving support becomes more common. In addition to being able to accurately reproduce the dynamics of a car, it also has functions that can simulate traffic society experiments such as not only driving but also evaluation of driving support, examination of information presentation methods to driving cars, reproduction of traffic modes other than cars DS has the possibility of developing into an industry as a service for evaluating safety design etc. in driving support, automated driving, and smart city development as a general evaluation method as well as mere hardware.

Therefore, in this document, we will explain the DS function for realizing a DS that also has a function to simulate such traffic society experiments, an HMI device used for the DS, and an example. Chapter 1

gives an overview of DS, Section 1.1 explains objectives of DS and in Section 1.2, we summarized the experiments using driving simulators and introduce the driving simulators that have been developed so far. The driving simulators introduced are (1) Belt Conveyor System, (2) 6- Axis Motion System, and (3) 6- Axis Motion System and Translator System. In addition, we introduced two Large- Scale Driving Simulators that have been developed in recent years. Chapter 2 introduces typical DSs. Chapter 3 describes the DS architecture, and Chapter 4 explains how to generate DS video. Chapter 5 describes various HMI devices and evaluation methods of driving performance etc. Chapter 6 introduces usage examples of DS.
It is hoped that this book will be useful for researchers and developers who are considering DS installation and DS development as an HMI evaluation for driving support systems and automated driving.
Chapter 1 Overview Toshio Ito
and Toshiya Hirose
Department of Machinery and Control Systems, Omiya Campus, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Japan
Department of Engineering Science and Mechanics, Toyosu Campus, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Japan
1.1 Introduction

In this chapter, Section 1.2 explains objectives of driving simulators (DSs), and in Section 1.3, we summarize the experiments using DSs and introduce the DS that have been developed so far. The DSs introduced are (1) belt conveyor system, (2) six- axis motion system, and (3) six- axis motion system and translator system. In addition, we have introduced two large- scale DSs that have been developed in recent years.
1.2 Objectives of DS

We have various kinds of DSs from games to rehabilitation for driving training. What is explained here is, of course, for academic research. And the research is human- machine interface (HMI) evaluation in advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS) and automated driving.
DS is often used for HMI evaluation in ADAS and automated driving. In the vehicle development, the actual developing vehicle is used

for the HMI evaluation, and DS is not used. It is because the usability of the cockpit of the vehicle is evaluated. However, various functions of ADAS and automated driving are not functions in which drivers directly operate vehicles, but functions to support drivers. Therefore, it is not affected by the cockpit design of the vehicle to some extent, and it can be evaluated in the general purpose cockpit. ADAS and the functions of automated driving and HMI are under development, and it is necessary to change and evaluate only functions and HMI itself. Therefore, DS is suitable for evaluating the consistency with the driver by changing various functions and HMI while the cockpit is fixed.

DS is a kind of device that can simulate driving scenes and road traffic environments by a computer. DS has several levels such as computer games, simulator for driving school, simulator for research and development, etc., and the present replacement can be called practical virtual reality.

Even a computer game can be considered a simple DS if the driving scene can be reproduced by steering or pedaling. On the other hand, in a real DS using a large screen and a driver's seat of an actual vehicle as installed in our laboratory, reproduction of sensible acceleration and simulation of road traffic environment are emphasized.

Reproduction of road structures and buildings is very realistic due to the progress in computer graphics (CG), Graphics Processing Unit (GPU), and Personal Computer (PC). On the other hand, the simulation of the traffic environment requires the reality for the behavior of other vehicles and pedestrians who are other traffic participants. In order to reproduce the movement of other vehicles and pedestrians on the DS image, a model of human movement on a computer is required. Therefore, it can be said that the CG technology which reproduces the driving scene, the driver model for generating the body sensory acceleration by the driving operation, and the model of the human action for moving other vehicles are important for DS.

What are the benefits of DS? Let us compare them with an actual vehicle test. To make a concrete comparison, let us consider the warning timing evaluation of the inter- vehicle distance warning system. As a scenario, it is a question of the inter- vehicle distance warning timing and the situation is that the preceding vehicle depresses by the sudden brake while the host vehicle and the preceding vehicle are running at constant speed.

At first, let us look at the outline of the procedure for making this evaluation in a real car. First, (1) the system which can change the timing of the distance warning must be developed. (2) It should be installed in the actual car, and the operation is confirmed. Next, the schedule to be evaluated is determined, and (3) the test course, host vehicle, subjects and collaborators in the experiment, preceding vehicle, driver of preceding vehicle, and equipment at that time (transceivers, pylon, measuring instruments, etc.) are reserved and secured. On the day of the test, (4) we need to prepare the evaluation tools, and (5) if the weather is not suitable for running after the start of the test, the test must be stopped, and re- planning is required. In addition, during the evaluation, (6) it is carried out repeatedly until (7) the brake timing of the preceding vehicle matches the plan, while taking care of safety. Then, after the experiment, data such as the vehicle speed of the own vehicle and that of the preceding vehicle are collected from the data logger, (8) the data sheets for analysis are needed to be produced, and the analysis of the test results is finally started.
This mentions the setup of the test using the actual vehicle. This list alone shows the benefits of DS. Then what happens when we test with DS? Let us look at each item of the actual vehicle test.

Development of an inter- vehicle distance warning system in DS requires only (1) programming or setting the timing of the warning. As a matter of course, (2) the man- hour of actual vehicle equipment does not occur. (3) Only experimental subjects need to reserve for the test date. However, when the DS is used for other projects, reservation of DS itself is required. And, it is necessary to make the course on DS newly, when the test course except for the prepared one is necessary. (4) Even if it is necessary to prepare for the evaluation, it is overwhelmingly shorter than the actual vehicle test, and (5) it is not affected by the weather. In DS, (6) there is no accident, and the attention for the safety is focused on whether the experiment subjects cause DS sickness or not. Since (7) DS can accurately reproduce desired timing, waste in the test is eliminated. (8) The DS system itself can automatically generate data sheets for analysis.

In this comparison, the advantages of DS stand out. Especially, DS is overwhelmingly advantageous on safety, reproducibility, and weather problems. If DS is used, it becomes possible to shift the warning timing to the rear- end collision limit which is difficult in the actual vehicle test,
and special and delicate timing can be reproduced many times, and the test can be carried out in the schedule as planned.

If DS is not used, it is difficult to conduct the rear- end collision accident and examine how the driver operates the brake pedal. In addition, in the system in which pedestrians and bicycles become detection objects, DS must be used, because it is related to the human life of pedestrians and bicycle riders who participate in the test as detection objects. Although it seems to be all good things like this, DS has some drawbacks. The largest drawback is whether it really simulates reality.

There are two points where DS simulates reality. They are, how to realistically reproduce the driving scene by CG and the reproducibility of body sensory acceleration of the front, back, right, and left generated by motion. Therefore, the performance of DS depends on how excellent the graphics performance and the sensible acceleration generation performance are.

Another disadvantage is simulator sickness. Since there is an individual difference, this can be avoided by carrying out the proper inspection of used DS, and having the experiment cooperator without the simulator sickness participate in the experiment. However, simulator sickness may be solved by improving the DS performance essentially because the sense of graphics and motion provided by DS is different from that of humans.

Another fear using DS is that the response of the experiment subjects may be dulled, because DS is not the actual operation. However, there is no problem in our experience and the reason below. When a subject drives the DS, he/she operates it while looking at the graphics scenery on the screen. It is not possible to drive accurately unless steering and pedaling are properly operated at the specified speed.

That is to say, it can be said that the operation in DS is not different from the actual operation. In order to see the response of the driver in that state, it is considered that there is no difference from the response in actual operation, and there is no clear difference from the response in actual operation from the data of the experiment until now. Therefore, there is no problem that the response time of the experiment subject in the DS simulates the response time in the actual operation.

However, it is assumed that DS generates body sensory acceleration which can simulate actual driving. In DS with no motion and only graphics, there is no problem in the initial operation of the pedal in the

front and rear directions. However, there is no guarantee that it simulates the reality, because there is no body sensory acceleration on continuous pedal operation and lateral steering operation even in the longitudinal direction.

Here, we consider DS from the Intelligent Transport Systems (ITS) point of view. Since the installation of the infrastructure equipment of ITS will start from now, it is not possible to experience it immediately on the actual road. It is not easy to change the infrastructure once it has been installed. Therefore, it is necessary to evaluate the effect of the facilities in a sure manner.

In such a system, the utility value of DS increases greatly because it cannot be evaluated in an actual test course. On the DS, the hazard level can be set freely in the general traffic environments, and it is possible to evaluate all conditions including the change of the specification from the presence or absence of the ITS infrastructure. Until the concept of ITS appeared, the use of DS was limited to automotive- related research institutes and enterprises. However, since the installation of ITS infrastructure started to be examined, the use of DS has spread to the electronics manufacturers related to the infrastructure.

DS is also effective from the viewpoint of whether the infrastructure will affect the landscape of the city. Since the viewpoint of the landscape drawn by CG can be freely changed, the evaluation from the viewpoint of not only drivers but also pedestrians becomes possible.
1.3 History, evolution, and challenges of DS
1.3.1 Driving experiment using DS

A DS is a device that can reproduce the state of driving a car without actually getting on a car. This is a device that has the function of presenting similar feelings of the driver's visual perception, auditory, and force senses to those during driving, and causing an illusion as if the driver is driving an actual car. The advantage of tests using the DS is that it can reproduce dangerous traffic situations in the DS and perform the tests safely.

The tests related to the performance evaluation of such vehicles are divided into the following categories: numerical simulation, DS, tests on test courses, and tests in actual traffic environments. Experiments for

those tests can be conducted in situations where the safety is ensured. DS include tests performed by professional drivers for vehicle performance evaluation, as well as many tests by general young or elderly drivers.

In the tests targeting general drivers, the data of their driving behavior, such as how a driver operates the accelerator, brake, and steering wheel, have been measured so far. In recent years, attempts have been made to fundamentally clarify the driving characteristics of drivers from the measurement of biological information, such as drivers' brain waves and skin potential, and of gaze direction, in addition to the basic data measurement of driving behavior.

When conducting the tests targeting humans, the experimental plan must be reviewed by the bioethics committee at the testing organization in advance, taking into account the human rights of the experimental participants in the test. Tests have been conducted. Therefore, the test is performed in an environment where sufficient security is ensured. Experimental participants can decide whether to participate in the test. The driving data of DS cannot be measured against the intentions of the experimental participants.
1.3.2 Belt conveyor system

DS can provide safe test environments. For example, it is possible to reproduce a future autonomous driving system on the DS and to test in advance what will happen. DSs are useful as data measurement devices that contribute to clarifying the driving characteristics of drivers and developing automobiles. Many DSs have been developed so far.

To evaluate the performance of vehicles, tests had been performed, using a vehicle that moved on a belt conveyor by the driver's driving operations of accelerator, brake, and steering wheel, before the development of a DS, in which a driver gets on a DS and performs tests.

A camera was set up on the road reproduced on the belt conveyor, and the vehicle moved on the belt conveyor by a driver's operation. The driving scenery captured by the camera was displayed on the screen, information of which was used for a driver to perform the driving operation. The belt conveyor system reproduced the experience information by the vehicle moving on the belt conveyor, and presented the driver with the running sound, vibration, and reaction force of the steering wheel.

The cockpit was almost the same as the one in an actual vehicle because of an actual vehicle being used. However, there were some problems, such as the limitation of straight- ahead traveling or the poor display of acceleration and deceleration.
1.3.3 Six-axis motion system

A DS that was developed in 1968 reproduced lateral acceleration and longitudinal acceleration by using a hydraulic cylinder to tilt the cab in the roll direction during steering operation and in the pitch direction while applying the accelerator or braking. In recent years, two types of simulators have made an impact on the research of DS, followed by the development of the subsequent system. One is the simulator that started operations at the Swedish Road Transport Research Institute (vÃ¤g- och transportforskningsinstitut (VTI)) in 1983, and the other was the simulator of Benz (Figure 1.1) [1] that started operations in 1984.
Figure 1.1 Driving simulator (DS) block diagram (Benz)

These two types of simulators established two standards for the mechanism that gave the perceived acceleration in the front, back, left, and right directions. The VIT simulator was the type that moved on two

orthogonal linear rails, and the Benz simulator was a six- degrees- of- freedom motion type that used six actuators. Generally, an aircraft simulator has a six- axis motion system (six degrees of freedom in the front, rear, left, right, up, and down: pitch, roll, and yaw) with six actuators. The Benz simulator applied the six- axis motion system directly to a DS.

A dome equipped with a cockpit and screens was supported by the six- axis actuator. An actual vehicle was placed inside the dome. Driving images were presented by six projectors on the six screens inside the dome. Benz not only aimed at researching human- machine systems but also announced the use of this simulator in the experimental phase of vehicle development, which showed new possibilities for using the simulator. After the Benz simulator was announced, various car companies and related laboratories began to introduce simulators.
1.3.4 Six-axis motion system and translator system

The VIT simulator (Figure 1.2) [2] proposed a system that exceeded the limitations of the six- axis motion- based method because the limits were revealed from the viewpoint of vehicle motion simulation in the six- axis motion- based method. For example, the six- axis motion base reproduced the feeling of acceleration in the front- rear and left- right directions by tilting, which caused discomfort to a driver. In addition, the speed of the tilting of the motion device was not fast enough in the six- axis motion- based method.
Figure 1.2 Driving simulators (DS) (VTI)

The VTI simulator had additional motion devices with translation functions under the dome equipped with the cockpit and under the six- axis motion base. The additional motion devices enabled reproducing the feeling of driving by moving the dome and the six- axis motion base on two- axis linear rails in the front- back and left- right directions. This VTI simulator became the mainstream of the motion system (a six- axis motion base with linear rails), which is still used to reproduce the motion of vehicles.

In the 1980s, a DS that allowed drivers to board like the current DS, was developed. In the DS, drivers could perform driving operations by visually recognizing the traffic environment reproduced by the visual system. The visual system of a car DS was required to reproduce various
traffic environments, such as highways and urban areas, using CG as a mandatory condition.

Simulators that could present a vehicle's running scenes using CG were developed after the 1970s. A motion system that reproduced the movement of an automobile was required to have a function that could reproduce the transient response of an automobile, such as sudden acceleration and sudden braking. In the 1990s, as computer development progressed, large DS that actively utilized computers began to be developed.

In the large DS, a driver rode in the driver's cab simulating a vehicle, and drove while watching the CG traffic environment projected on the screen by a projector. The simulator's motion device moved according to the driver's operation. The motion device had a mechanism in which the translation device moved the entire simulator to the left and right. Also, the motion device was developed to present pitch and roll angles.

Currently, this method are used by the National Advanced Driving Simulator (NADS) in the University of Iowa and the University of Leeds Driving Simulator (HoLDS). In the simulators, a six- axis motion base is mounted under the dome. Both the dome and six- axis motion base are moved by a two- axis linear rail (XY table), resulting in eight degrees of freedom. In the University of Iowa NADS, a two- axis linear rail can move the simulator back and forth, right and left, about
20~\mathrm{m}
, where a building like a gymnasium is required to install such a large simulator.
1.3.5 Recent large-scale DS
1.3.5.1 DS of Toyota [3]
1.3.5.1.1 Overview

In 2008, Toyota developed a large DS (Figure 1.3) with reference to the University of Iowa's NADS. The DS enables the analyses of driving behavior to find the causes of traffic accidents, and the evaluation of the effect of preventive safety systems that prevent traffic accidents. First, traffic accidents to be addressed are identified from the accident statistics analyses and the accident situation analyses, and then a simulator is used to find out what kind of driver's driving behavior causes the accidents.
Figure 1.3 Driving simulator (DS) (Provided by TOYOTA MOTOR CORPORATION)

In other words, by using the simulator, it is possible to safely analyze the driver's driving characteristics in the driver's situations of driving at low consciousness such as drowsiness and not paying attention, carelessness for danger such as looking aside while driving and unconfirming safety, and driving unsuitability such as drinking, fatigue, and sickness. In addition, the effectiveness of the preventive safety system can be evaluated using a simulator.
1.3.5.1.2 Motion equipment
The structure consists of a six- axis motion device and a translation device below the dome. The feature is that the operating range of the translation device is
35\mathrm{m}
, and it can reproduce
0.3\mathrm{G}
front- back acceleration and left- right acceleration. The turntable with an operating range of
\pm 330^{\circ}

is installed inside the dome to reproduce the yaw motion simulating the rotational motion of the vehicle. Also, in order to compensate for the lack of a feeling of speed at low speeds, the stroke of the four vehicle- body shakers supporting the turntable is set to
\pm 50\mathrm{mm}

The development of the simulator focuses on the response characteristics of the front- rear and left- right acceleration that is generated in the simulator's vehicle. The simulator is controlled by the method in which the vehicle acceleration calculated by simulation is fed back by the vehicle motion simulator. In this case, when the system is operated by the actual device, a delay occurs in the feedback, so the system requires higher frequency response characteristics than the frequency response region of the simulated vehicle.

Frequency response characteristics of lateral acceleration due to steering in normal driving and longitudinal acceleration due to brake pedal stroke were measured, the results of which showed that response characteristics required
2\mathrm{Hz}
for lateral acceleration and
4\mathrm{Hz}
or more for longitudinal acceleration. Therefore, the response characteristics of the motion in the simulator were all constructed to realize the response characteristics of
4\mathrm{Hz}
or more.

In addition, in order to prevent a driver from feeling as if the front- rear and left- right accelerations of the vehicle were generated by the device, the acceleration by a tilting device is designed to be generated at low tilt speed in a low frequency range, while the remaining acceleration of the target acceleration is designed to be generated by the translation device. In these controls, almost the same size as the intersection is required in order to reproduce the vehicle movement at one intersection. In addition, since the translation device needs to be prepared for the next movement, the dome is set to gradually move to the center. This is called washback, which is implemented so that a driver does not feel it.
1.3.5.1.3 Video equipment

The video device that displays the vehicle's running scene in the dome consists of a dome screen, projectors, a video simulation computer, an experimental scenario computer, an image database, and so on. The dome screen has a height of
4.5\mathrm{m}
, an inner diameter of
7.0\mathrm{m}
, and a spherical screen inside. The dome screen can be viewed from
23^{\circ}
above,
20^{\circ}
below, and
around the entire circumference. The vehicle's driving scene is displayed by eight projectors fixed to the ceiling.
The center of the spherical screen is set at the driver's eye point in the driver's seat, and is
1.27\mathrm{m}
above the floor. The resolution of the projector is Ultra Extended Graphics Array (UXGA)
. The image is displayed at
60\mathrm{Hz}
by eight liquid crystal projectors so that
the driver can distinguish the vehicle
100\mathrm{m}

1.3.5.2 DS of Nissan [4]

The simulator is used because it is dangerous to evaluate how a driver is affected by driving assistance and whether a driver can respond in dangerous situations, and so on, by using the actual vehicle. In order for drivers to keep getting into the simulator for a long time, they must be free of simulator sickness. In particular, it is said that people with long driving experience and rich driving sensations are more likely to experience simulator sickness.

Therefore, the simulator was designed for reducing the discomfort caused by the difference in the driving sensation between an actual vehicle and the simulator, and achieving something that is realistic and less sick. At present, the cause of simulator sickness has not been completely clarified, but there is a theory of "sensory inconsistency" that can best explain the sickness. The theory says that the simulator sickness is caused by a driver's discomfort that occurs from the difference in between the driver's driving feelings expected in an actual vehicle and
that reproduced in a DS. The difference in feeling can be roughly classified as follows:

1. Somatic sensation: Difference or delay between acceleration felt in an actual vehicle and the one reproduced in a simulator2. Visual perception: Difference and delay between the scenery actually viewed and the image by the simulator.

The following countermeasures were taken to eliminate the difference between the two types of sensations that could be the cause of simulator sickness to a driver, that is, the somatic sensation and visual discomfort.

The discomfort of the somatic sensation means that the front- rear and the left- right accelerations in driving an actual vehicle cannot be felt the same by the simulator. So, the performance of the simulator motion device was improved. In order to obtain an acceleration equivalent to that of an actual vehicle, it was necessary to use a simulator with XY rails. In addition, the rail length stroke was increased, and a direct drive using a linear motor with high thrust was applied to the drive unit of the rail shaft.

Thus, the goal was to develop a translation device with the world's highest performance that could move in a wide range of motion with high response speed. A turntable was installed inside the dome to give the rotation sense in the yaw- direction like an actual vehicle in order to reduce the discomfort caused by the lack of the rotation sense in the yaw- direction when turning left or right at an intersection.

Regarding the discomfort of visual perception, first, an actual vehicle was placed in the cockpit in order to reproduce the image actually seen by the driver. It made it possible that a driver had the front view from the driver's seat similar to that while driving an actual vehicle. Next, a CG image was projected on all sides of the large spherical screen in the dome. Then, a drawing system was constructed by a computer processing at faster speed and a projector drawing at faster speed in order to draw CG images drawn at high density with little delay to the driver operation.

When the evaluation is performed by general drivers, there is a concern that the results may be affected by the difference of the positions of the steering wheel in between the DS and actual vehicles that they normally drive. Therefore, assuming the evaluation with the right or the left steering wheels, the operation system, such as the steering wheel,
accelerator and brake, was installed on both the left and right sides so that it could be implemented efficiently without changing the cockpit.

1.4 Conclusion

Here, we introduced objectives and the history of DS and the large- scale DS developed in recent years. A DS equipped with functions that involve longitudinal movement and lateral movement can simulate ordinary driving scenarios to emergency driving scenarios, and can also present large acceleration/deceleration to experimental participants. This shows that it is possible to use a DS to evaluate the ADAS that supports emergencies and the evaluation of future automated driving systems. In addition, with the progress of virtual reality technology, it has become possible to present visual information to experimental participants using a high- resolution device, and in the future, small- scale driving will be utilized by utilizing head- mounted display technology.

2.1 Introduction

A driving simulator (DS) is a device that can reproduce driving scenes and road traffic environments on a computer and simulate driving. There are several levels of simulators such as computer games, simulators for driving schools, and simulators for research and development. In the case of computer games, it can be said to be a simple DS that simulates driving operations if it is possible to drive with steering and pedal operations. However, in the full- fledged DS that uses a large screen and real car seats, reproduction of sensible acceleration and simulation of road traffic environments are emphasized.

At present, the type of DS which can reproduce the sensible acceleration for carrying out the research for advanced driver assistance systems and automated driving can be divided roughly into three types: simple, advanced, and full- scale. DS used at Shibaura Institute of Technology are of two types: simple and advanced. And, there is University of Leeds Driving Simulator (UoLDS) of Leeds University as a full- scale DS, which we used during our stay in the United Kingdom.
In this chapter, these three DSs are introduced as examples of simple, advanced, and full- scale simulators.

Section 2.2 presents SIoTDS- O (Shibaura Institute of Technology Driving Simulatorâ€”Omiya campus) as an example of a simple DS. Generally, the hurdle to the introduction of the DS is high, because it is expensive and a large installation area is also necessary. Then, a DS which can comparatively easily be introduced, though the evaluation item is limited, is considered. The SIoTDS- O simplifies the three main components of the DS: the video presentation system, the cockpit system, and the swing system.

In Section 2.3 "The driving simulator SIoTDS- T," the functions of the DS SIoTDS- T installed on the Toyosu campus of Shibaura Institute of Technology, are introduced. The contents are (1) Motion Device, (2) Image Generator (IG), (3) System Configuration, and (4) Cockpit.

The introduction of UoLDS is given in Section 2.4 "Driving simulator UoLDS (full- scale type at Leeds University)." UoLDS is a DS installed at The Institute for Transport Studies, University of Leeds in United Kingdom; it simulates the movement of a car with a motion device that combines a six- axis motion device and a parallel device for longitudinal movement and lateral movement. Details included are (1) Motion Device, (2) IG, (3) System Configuration, and (4) Cockpit of UoLDS.
2.2 DS SIoTDS-O (simple type at Omiya campus in SIT)

At present, the types of DS for research on driving support systems and automated driving can be roughly divided into three types: simple, advanced, and full- scale. Let's look at some typical examples of these types.
The two DSs in our laboratories are simple and advanced ones. There is UoLDS of the Leeds University as a full- scale DS, and it is possible to introduce here from simple DS in order.

In general, a DS is expensive and requires installation space, so it is not a device that can be easily introduced. Then, though the evaluation items as objects are limited, the effect of the introduction of advanced and full- scale DS is often attempted by introducing the simple DS. The
composition of DS is roughly divided into three systems: video presentation system, cockpit system, and moving system. The simple DS makes each of these components simple.

The video presentation system over the advanced DS projects on the screen by multiple projectors is to present the driving scene widely and largely in the visual field of the driver. Therefore, some installation space is required. In the simple DS, the installation space of the DS is drastically reduced by using the monitors which display the driving scene. And, the DS equipment itself becomes large, because the cockpit over the advanced DS utilizes the cockpit of the actual vehicle. Contrary to this, the simple DS has a minimum configuration of only a steering wheel, necessary switches, seat, and pedals, and the meters are drawn while presenting a driving scene, and simple meters are installed on the upper part of the steering wheel. By doing so, it almost becomes the usual installation space of a desk and chair for one person, and the installation space can be drastically reduced. Then, the installation space including the direction of the height is decided by the configuration of the moving system, and the introduction cost increases. This moving system is often a hurdle for introduction of DS. Therefore, in the simple DS, a simple moving system is used.

The simple DS in our laboratory is based on the aforementioned trend of simplification of DS. That is to say, three PC displays of 21 inches in horizontal length are respectively used for front, oblique right and oblique left, the cockpit is made to be only necessary minimum controls and seats, and a two shaft rotation system for the arcade game is adopted as a moving device. 2.3 DS SIoTDS-T (advanced type at Toyosu campus in SIT)
2.3.1 Introduction of SIoTDS-T

This section introduces the outline of the SIoTDS- T with a six- axis motion device and a turntable device in the Human Machine System Laboratory at Shibaura Institute of Technology. The SIoTDS- T consists of an actual vehicle, a motion device, and a cylindrical screen. The SIoTDS- T reproduces the information of the view of the vehicle driver and presents the motion of the vehicle by the motion device.

In the 1980s, a simulator was developed in the Oguchi Laboratory (Professor Emeritus Yasuhei Oguchi) at Shibaura Institute of Technology, as shown in Figure 2.5. This simulator was a drum- type bench test machine, where an experimental vehicle made of pipe frames was set on a drum installed in parallel in the front and back, and the movement of the vehicle was simulated by rotating the drum. This simulator was used to measure the vehicle maneuverability and stability data.
Figure 2.5 Driving simulator in the Oguchi Laboratory

In the 1990s, the simulator shown in Figure 2.6 was developed at the Sawada Laboratory (Professor Emeritus Toichi Sawada) at Shibaura Institute of Technology. This simulator reproduced the roll and pitch motion of the vehicle by expanding and contracting two ball screws installed behind the cockpit, and reproduced the yaw motion by rotating the entire simulator. The image of the road was presented with the help of computer graphics (CG) images by three projectors, and the reaction force of the steering wheel, accelerator, and brake was presented to the driver.
Figure 2.6 Driving simulator in the Sawada Laboratory

The DS is constructed for the purpose of evaluating the performance of the driving support system and the automatic driving system. The feature is that the DS consists of the actual body and the motion device. The driving support system is evaluated for the effect on the prevention of traffic accidents and on the driving operation by the experiments where participants use the function of the driving support system installed in the DS.

For example, adaptive cruise control (ACC) has functions of detecting a motor vehicle ahead automatically and of adjusting the distance between the vehicles by sensors mounted on the vehicle. The lane keeping assist system (LKAS) detects lanes on a road by a camera, presents an alarm sound, and automatically operates the steering wheel when the motor vehicle seems likely to depart from the lane. The advanced emergency braking system (AEBS) presents an alarm sound, and then automatically activates sudden braking when the driver does not perform any driving operation to avoid collisions, such as braking.

These technologies have been installed in motor vehicles as existing technologies. As for AEBS, the international standards for improving the safety of AEBS have been discussed in the United Nations, and the mandatory installation of AEBS is being considered in each country. In order to verify the effect of such technologies on improving safety, many experiments using DS have been performed so far.

In Japan, the Advanced Safety Vehicle (ASV) project promoted by the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has been implemented since 1990. The ASV project has been active as ASV Phase 6 and considered how these systems should be in the future from the
perspective not only of driving support systems but also of automatic driving systems. The ASV project also targets a driving support system using communication technology.

The system using Cooperative Intelligent Transport Systems (C- ITS) is a technology that can detect the presence of a motor vehicle in a blind spot by connecting the vehicles via communication and mutually communicating information, such as the position and speed of each vehicle. Currently, some motor vehicles are equipped with C- ITS technology, but it will be some time for many of the motor vehicles equipped with the technology to become popular.

For systems in safety devices that are expected to become popular in the future, the effect evaluation using a DS is one of the means to examine the effect of the systems. It is possible to build a future driving support system on the DS by a computer program, and to predict the effect of these systems in advance by experiments.

For example, the DS makes it possible to evaluate the effectiveness of a system equipped with a human- machine interface (HMI) that presents the presence of other vehicles to the driver by communication with other vehicles in a blind spot on a DS, using communication technology. The DS also enables to consider in advance the safety benefits of future technologies, such as construction of driver control models and application to vehicle control, by utilizing AI technology that has been actively researched and developed in recent years.

2.3.4 System configuration of the SIoTDS-T

Figure 2.10 shows the system configuration of the SIoTDS- T with the six- axis motion turntable. In the SIoTDS- T, the signals of a driver's operations of the accelerator, brake, and steering wheel are input to the computer, where the motion and IG are controlled according to the operation amount. First, based on the direction from all information aggregated in the host computer, the control is executed in each device.
Figure 2.10 System configuration in SIoTDS-T

Most computers, including the host computers, are connected to the network. The necessary information is exchanged between networks using UDP (User Datagram Protocol) communication. UDP is a protocol used on the Internet, and computers can send and receive data using a network. It is because UDP communication used in the network enables
the communication with minimum exchange and low delay time. In addition, all of these computers are designed to calculate the sampling time at
120\mathrm{Hz}
. When the calculation load increases, such as in the cases controlling many other vehicles, the calculation is processed by reducing the sampling time to
60\mathrm{Hz}

The computers calculate how the vehicle is moving from the motion of the vehicle based on the driving operations of a driver, where a vehicle motion model is required. As the motion model of a vehicle, there are various methods proposed, such as an equivalent two- wheel model that simplifies the calculation by regarding a four- wheel vehicle as a two- wheel vehicle. Among them, CarSim provided by Virtual Mechanics is used.

The CarSim has to immediately output the results of the vehicle motion when a driving operation is input. When it takes a long time to calculate, it causes an operation delay of the motion device and provides the driver with a feeling of strangeness. Therefore, a real- time calculator provided by dSPACE Japan Co. Ltd. is used. It has a function to reliably calculate the vehicle motion within a defined time and output the results.

From the calculated vehicle motion, the motion device presents the vehicle motion and the mage is generated. First, the motion device composed of a six- axis motion device and a turntable reproduces the movement of the vehicle by controlling each electric motor. The results from the vehicle motion are input to the control computer of the motion device, where the control amounts of the six- axis motion device and the turntable are determined.

The control computer also has the function of a safety device. When a driver operates an emergency stop switch installed in the vehicle, all of the motion devices stop. Figure 2.11 shows the relationship of the input and output between the motion device and the control computer.
Figure 2.11 Input and output between the motion device and the control computer
The IG presents images at every
120\mathrm{Hz}

of sampling time based on the calculated vehicle motion. The simulator presents the images on the cylindrical screen using six projectors. Therefore, when there is a difference in the timing of presenting the image, flickers occur at the joint of the images. So, the flickers of the image are eliminated by synchronizing the time of the image generation on the computer that generates the six images, using a synchronous signal generator.

The driver can feel the reaction force from the accelerator, brake, and steering wheel according to driving. It is because the simulator simulates these reaction forces as well. First, the reaction force of the steering wheel is presented by a motor, which uses a system of Moog, that is, for the purpose of simulating the steering reaction force. The reaction force is simulated by communicating between the host computer and the real time computer that calculates the steering reaction force.

The reaction force of the accelerator indicates the reaction force using a spring used in the actual vehicle. For the reaction force of the brake, a motor- based system like the steering reaction force, can be used. However, in this simulator, the pedal reaction force is simulated by utilizing the brake system mounted on the actual vehicle. The author has employed a motor- based pedal reaction force system, which requires the

quick response of the pedal reaction force, regardless of different pedal reaction forces. For example, the pedal reaction force can become larger by a driver with a large body, while it can become smaller by a driver with a small body.

Since it took time to adjust different pedal reaction forces to every case, the actual braking system was used. In a passenger car, a brake activates when the brake pad contacts the brake caliper using hydraulic pressure converted by the brake pedal input. A booster is installed to ensure that the brake works even with the small force of a driver. Therefore, for simulating the pedal reaction force of the brake, it is necessary to reproduce the pedal, booster, hydraulic piping, brake pad, and brake caliper.

In passenger cars, the booster normally generates negative pressures in the engine, which are used for the power of the booster. However, since the SIoTDS- T has no engine, it has to use a motor for generating negative pressures to input. The reaction force of the brake pedal is simulated using the pedal, booster, hydraulic piping, brake pads, and brake calipers, so that a driver can operate the brake in a natural feeling.

2.4 DS UoLDS (full-scale type at Leeds University) [3]
2.4.1 Introduction of UoLDS

The Institute for Transport Studies, University of Leeds in the United Kingdom, developed a DS (Figure 2.12) in 1994 in order to clarify the driving characteristics of drivers and conduct research on traffic safety. This simulator could accurately reproduce various environments, vehicle characteristics, and traffic conditions, and conduct experiments in controlled environments.
