3.1 Architecture principles
3.1.1 Introduction

The architecture of a driving simulator (DS) is mainly composed of two types of components: hardware and software. However, if we consider the DS as a whole system, we must also include the human part. That is at least one person technically capable of making a diagnosis of the problems and dealing with them when they occur, someone knowing what is possible to be achieved with the simulator and correctly advise the users in their research. In general, that person or the group of persons in charge of a DS must have not only the knowledge about the simulator itself but a good understanding of the goals of the research and how the simulator performs best in different scenarios. In most cases that knowledge comes from trial and error and becomes an accumulation of techniques applied to overcome difficulties such as simulator sickness, and lack of fidelity in the physical, visual, and other feedback given to the driver. It also includes building practical dynamic scenarios and dealing with many other operational issues that may exist. Each simulator has strengths and weaknesses; specific knowledge is always necessary to use or deal correctly with them. However, knowledge of another simulator's design and usage is highly recommended, and the persons in charge of a simulator should have the opportunities to study other simulators. This knowledge not only helps to make better use of the simulator, but it also gives useful indications on how to improve or upgrade an existing simulator architecture. To conclude on this point, when building or purchasing a new simulator, the human component of the system is
an essential point to consider; it is as critical as other components of the simulator.

Let us go back to the non- human components of the architecture. First, it is evident that there is not only one architecture for DS but many differences in terms of scale, budget, performance, and effectiveness and that each newly designed simulator can be very different from others. For that reason, we try to clarify the relationship between the components and what they achieve, and why they are important depending on the goal of the simulator.
3.1.2 Hardware/software general architecture

We insisted on the fact that simulators are different in their realization and implementation. At a more abstract level, they all follow very similar architecture concepts that we call the general architecture of a simulator.

If we look at the components surrounding the driver, they are made to reproduce the stimulus given to the driver while driving. The main effort in DS is to provide accurate feedback in the visual, audio, and motion cues, respectively, provided by displays, speakers, motion systems, and haptic feedback systems.

There are also measurement devices to get information on the physiological state of the driver, such as gaze tracking, heart rate monitoring, stress level, or cerebral activity measurement of the driver.

A simulator is not always used only to reproduce a driving environment for the driver. In many cases, the goal of a simulator is to conduct research on and develop new vehicles or related technologies, new types of human- machine interface (HMI), or new mobility technologies. Such simulators include one or several hardware components as the subject of the research that are tested and developed with the simulator, then implemented in real vehicles for actual field tests. We call this system configuration HIL (hardware in the loop) as it incorporates actual vehicle components integrated with the other simulation elements. Typical hardware parts are electronic control units (ECUs), prototypes of pedal or steering systems, seats, and cockpit components such as monitors or head- up displays (HUDs) with their interactive systems, haptic or new types of feedback systems. The increase in research for advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS) pushes the standardization in interfacing simulators with vehicle components and simulator integrators to design simulators as the part of a vehicle.

If we take some distance from the driver and the vehicle, another essential part of the architecture of a simulator is what makes it operate. In terms of facilities, a simulator includes an electric system for the power supply and signals between the different devices, air conditioning, cooling systems, monitoring and diagnosis systems. In terms of procedures, safety precautions,
accessibility to the hardware requiring maintenance, the layout of the simulator and operation room, are fundamental aspects of the system.

Also, we may want to consider the effort in preparation and tuning of a scenario. The scenario is often first built without the actual simulator hardware but only with the scenario engine. Procedures necessary to run or repeat a simulation are also important aspects when designing a simulator.

Especially in large and complex simulator installations, it becomes very critical to have a robust and failsafe architecture, that is power- efficient, easy to maintain, and easy to diagnose. On a per- day operation point of view, we want to pay attention to switching time between drivers or experiment content. Finally, if possible we would recommend making some effort to reduce the driver's preconceived ideas or stress about getting in a simulator.

The software components give life to the simulator. They must control the hardware that provides motion and haptic feedback, generate the images and sound for the driver, and simulate the dynamics of the main vehicle and traffic with other elements of the environment. In automotive R&D, the software is also in charge of simulating sensor data, then passing it to ECUs or their simulation models, including another piece of software that is a part of the vehicle. Finally, the control of the scenario, and gathering and analysis of data are also crucial roles of the software that permit optimization and tuning of the tested system.

The software contains modules that act to control or interact with each subsystem. The simulation itself can also run in several independent modules linked together. Table 3.1 lists a typical split of the functions in a DS.
Table 3.1 Main software modules in a simulator

1. Dynamic simulation of the main vehicle  
2. Models of the vehicle control unit  
3. Traffic simulation  
4. Environment simulation  
5. Scenario control  
6. Audio simulation  
7. Visual simulation  
8. Sensor simulation  
9. Driver and simulator video monitoring  
10. Driver/passenger physiological measurement: gaze, eye blink, heart rate, sweat, brain activity, etc.  
11. Data recording and replay  
12. Feedback hardware control: cabin, steering wheel, pedals, motion system

A scenario engine is often at the center of the software architecture and usually includes all the necessary features to run a driving simulation. Depending on the level of fidelity or customizability that is required, the scenario engine can also connect to specialized software solutions that will better respond to the requirements on one or several elements of the simulation. For instance, in Table 3.1, items 4 to 7 are often provided by the scenario engine, and 1, 2, and 8 can be part of specialized software. Items 9 and 10 often require the use of some piece of software that connects to the different measurement devices. Depending on the hardware of the simulator, items 12 and 13 may require some development. Still, some simulators, including standard plug- and- play equipment or those already linked with existing software programs, are also provided as integrated solutions. There is, in fact, no restriction on how to combine software elements. For instance, solutions specialized in simulating very high fidelity sound for the vehicle also exist. If the system must use individual components, a system integrator team or company is typically in charge of connecting all the parts and making sure the system works up to the functionality and performance requirements. As mentioned, fully integrated simulators or plug- and- play simulators also exist. They usually benefit from standard quality control and user support, and are comparatively less expensive than built ones, even with similar size and performances.
3.1.3 System integration
3.1.3.1 XIL and standardization

Before we go into more detail about each part of the architecture of a simulator, we must go through typical system integration methods. Here we focus on system integration with regard to automotive R&D, not intending to reduce DS to that domain but because they show clear examples of how to integrate components.

Let us start with XIL and the main phases of the development of a vehicle. XIL stands for the X in the loop where X can be M for Model, S for Software, P for Processor, and H for Hardware. In each case, using a DIL (driver in the loop) simulator is an option. It depends on the importance of the human factor in the object of the research.

Model in the loop simulation uses models of car parts or control programs and are only pure software simulation. Model- in- the- loop (MIL) is a methodology for the early stage of development, to test and validate the principles of a model. MIL does not always require a very detailed simulation of the vehicle or its environment. For instance, work on the engine control may

only need a simplified vehicle dynamics model and a straight road. In MIL, the model runs in a simulation environment such as MATLAB\textsuperscript{\textregistered}, and if a human driver is necessary, the model interacts with the simulation software of a DIL simulator. If no driver is needed, the simulation does not have to be in real time and could run faster than reality to multiply the number of tests made in a given amount of time.

Software- in- the- loop (SIL) integrates the full version of the software of the real vehicle. It is still in the early stage of development but goes in much more detail in debugging than MIL, and similarly, SIL can integrate with DIL simulators. However, because of the large number of tests that occur in this stage, scenarios are pre- programmed and use a driver model, so thousands of test cases can be executed at a reduced cost.

PIL and HIL integrate some real hardware, usually the processing unit or the whole control unit or embedded computer. HIL can also include real sensors or any type of equipment tested before going to actual prototyping. Simulators are often connected to HIL systems as the human factor becomes more critical at this stage of development. Also, because the hardware can only run in real- time speed, the simulation software must run at that speed, to make integration with a simulator possible.

Different solution providers working closely with system integrators provide XIL solutions to original equipment manufacturers (OEMs), car companies, and research organizations. Integration has a long history, and each company or country has developed its methods over the years. Considering that technology also evolves rapidly, it is difficult to master every integration method or every platform available on the market. To federate efforts and simplify integration, some entities and groups work on standardizations.
For instance, ASAM provides an XIL API (https://www.asam.net/standards/detail/xil/). Below is an extract of the ASAM website:

ASAM XIL is an API standard for the communication between test automation tools and test benches. The standard supports test benches at all stages of the development and testing process - - most prominently model- in- the- loop (MIL), software- in- the- loop (SIL) and hardware- in- the- loop (HIL). The notation 'XIL' indicates that the standard can be used for all 'in- the- loop' systems. This has the advantage that it enables users to freely choose testing products according to their requirements and integrate them with little effort. Using ASAM XIL- compliant products allows users of test systems to mix and match the best components from different suppliers without having costly integration efforts.

AUTOSAR (AUTomotive Open System ARchitecture) is another initiative that started in 2002 with BMW, Bosch, Continental, DaimlerChrysler, and Volkswagen. Now, it is a worldwide group with core partners coming from Europe, the United States, and Japan. The following is an extract from the AUTOSAR website: (https://www.autosar.org/),

The primary goal of the AUTOSAR partnership is the standardization of a common methodology, basic system functions and functional interfaces. This enables development partners to integrate, exchange, re- use and transfer functions within a vehicle network and substantially improves their efficiency of development. Having this goal in mind, AUTOSAR pushes the paradigm shift from an ECU- based to a function- based system design attempt in automotive software development and enables the management of the ever- growing software and E/E complexity with respect to technology and economics.
3.1.3.2 Data collection and simulation replay

Any system used for research, training, education, or marketing, as simulators can be, uses data for various types of analysis. Basically, as a simplified description, the simulation executes calculation in a loop where each time it takes the current state of the objects and simulates what they become after a given time interval (time step of the simulation). Each step possesses the status of all objects, which is kept for data collection. Collected data is stored for future analysis or visualization, or it can be analyzed in real time, or just after the simulation to provide immediate feedback.

Now let us go in for a more exact description. A simulator has many hardware and software components or modules that carry out tasks at different rates or time steps. They generate a large amount of output data. Also, the output of one module becomes the input of the next module until it reaches its final form of light on screens, sound wave or movement, and vibrations. Also, ultimately, the original data is the time, pressure on pedals, and torque applied on the steering wheel by the driver, and other actions of the driver and operator of the simulator. It is possible to represent the entire system as a graph where each node is a module with input and output, and is working at its frequencies (Figure 3.1). One piece of software like the vehicle dynamics calculation or traffic simulation could contain thousands of nodes if we look at the system in a very high granularity. If every information must be kept, in case the data becomes necessary in the future, the original input to the system and the output of each node should be in the record. This approach is, unfortunately, not realistic at the moment as it would require too much processing and data storage.
As a result, the level of details of the data that should remain is a choice based on the requirements.
Figure 3.1 General architecture of a driving simulator

Another challenge is data propagation. Figure 3.2 shows an example of data flow between the different modules of a simulator. Each module requires some time to process the data and generates an output. Data also is not immediately used by the next node in the chain due to transmission time and input frequencies of the node. In the end, time flows between the initial input and final output. All the data generated at one step of the simulation is not ready at the same timestamp. When data is collected, we should pay particular attention to understanding the data flow, when information is collected, or else, the causes- consequences order could be reversed, making any detailed or time- critical analysis impossible.
Figure 3.2 High-level view of data propagation between simulator modules

The replay of data in a DS is a method to execute the same simulation again without asking the driver to repeat his drive. It would also be impossible for the driver to do the same actions exactly. Technically a replay function uses data collected at strategic positions in the data flow and replaces the work of the original modules by sending the recorded data to the following modules. For example, the reproduction of the visualization of the moving objects would require to save their position and orientation in the virtual environment at each frame initially rendered by the system. The position and orientation data would then be fed to the image generation software so it can be shown again on the screen. This simple replay function can be sufficient to explain to the driver where, for instance, he did not stop at intersections or drove too close to pedestrians in a narrow street.

Replaying data has another practical use that is not to replicate the visual and audio content for someone, but to re- send information to modules so we can adjust or tune their parameters or algorithms. Replaying data ensures that the test conditions are always the same, reduces the time a driver must be in the simulator, and finally helps to make consistent improvements economically. For instance, replaying data is used a lot in the development of sensor fusion algorithms, as acquiring real sensor data each time is not possible. But it can be used for less evident purposes like tuning a motion cueing algorithm (MCA) or debugging timing issues in a scenario.
3.1.4 Hardware architecture
3.1.4.1 Introduction
The simulator hardware used to support and provide the necessary feedback to the driver includes the following components.

The cabin is the central part providing support for other components and where the driver and sometimes the passenger are seated for the driving experience. The cabin replaces the cockpit of the real car.
Display screens provide visual feedback to the driver. They are either fixed into the cabin or installed outside.

The steering wheel, pedals, and other levers and switches are used to get the driver's input. The steering wheel and pedals also provide haptic feedback, either passive or active. Passive feedback is often provided by springs and dampers and mostly used in pedal systems. Electric motors provide force feedback in steering wheels and sometimes ABS feedback in brake pedals.
The cabin can also include multiple types of cockpit displays, including the cluster of the instrument panel, interactive or information screens, or HUDs.
Finally, to provide motion feedback to the driver, there exists a multitude of motion systems, from simple vibration feedback to large- scale motion platform and rail systems.
3.1.4.2 The cabin

The cabin is the part of the simulator reproducing the cockpit of the vehicle. At one extremity, compact simulators do not try to replicate a real vehicle cockpit but only provide the support for a seat, steering wheel, and pedals. At the other extremity, full- scale simulators use real vehicle cockpit as a cabin. Between these two extremes, there exists a large variety of cabins for simulators.

The primary role of the cabin is to provide physical support for the driver seat and input devices such as the steering wheel, pedals, gear levers, and other types of HMI the simulator may include. The secondary role is to provide immersion to the driver so he can feel like in a real car, reducing the gap with reality. Depending on the goal of the simulator, some cabins must look realistic, while it is less a matter for others.

Another fundamental requirement for the cabin is if the cabin is mounted on some motion feedback system, and what accelerations the cabin must be able to handle. In that case, the resistance to accelerations and the stiffness of the cabin are critical points in its design. We also want to stress the fact that particular attention should be on the reduction of squeak or rumbling noises that are a disturbance to the driver.
Finally, the budget to a great extent impacts the decision, but the two main requirements, that is, (1) the role of the cabin and (2) the motion requirement,
must be taken into account when deciding what type of cabin to use. We describe here three possible strategies.
3.1.4.2.1 The frame structure and its variations

Essential parts such as the driving seat, steering wheel, pedals, lever, switches, and display panels are mounted on a frame structure. The distance between the driver and the steering wheel/pedals need to be changeable. This can be achieved either directly on the seat if it includes an adjustment feature or by an adjustable frame structure. In very simple simulators, a chair can even be directly placed on the floor with some locking mechanism or anti- slip materials, so it does not move when the driver pushes the pedals.

Because it is a frame structure, there are gaps between the frame beams or tubes and the other components, and the driver is not confined like in a real vehicle cockpit and can see through the frame. It is possible to cover the gaps or to lower the light of the simulator room to give a better sense of confinement to the driver. Also, the use of real car seats and steering wheels can improve the immersion.

Another advantage of the frame design is that it can be partially dismantled for transport, lowering the cost and effort when moving the simulator. Compared to other types of simulators, it also makes it usable in rooms with narrow or limited access. Figure 3.3 shows an example of a simple frame structure with three mounted projectors.
3.1.4.2.2 Immersive cockpit design

3.1.4.2.2 Immersive cockpit designImmersive cockpits compared to frame structures are designed to give a look and feel of a real vehicle by using some car components like seats, clusters, pedals, and steering wheel. The cockpit itself can be designed and built to incorporate the chosen components and sometimes ease the installation of cameras or other measurement devices. Such a cockpit can go further in improving the immersion by adding a roof, pillars, and other elements that provide a similar type of enclosure to a real cockpit. In general, immersive cockpits are designed as DS products and are produced more than once. However, some simulators for which it is important to convey the theme of the research can use some unique cabin design, as we can see in Figure 3.4.
Figure 3.4 Nagoya University simulator cockpit for research on mobility
3.1.4.2.3 Full-scale simulator using a real car

3.1.4.2.3 Full- scale simulator using a real carThe opposite strategy to build a new cabin as in the other three cases is to use a real car. Most of the time, unnecessary parts of the vehicle are taken, especially to reduce the payload if the cabin must stand on a motion system. If the constraints in space and payload are too restrictive, a cut removing parts such as the back or front of the body becomes necessary.

After adjusting the size and weight of the cabin, it must be electrically powered. The steering wheel, pedals, and other instruments must also be connected to the rest of the simulator to get the driving input information. For this purpose, most vehicles now include sensors and information that can be retrieved directly from the Controller Area Network (CAN) bus, but additional sensors might be necessary. The force feedback, especially crucial on the steering wheel, can be achieved using the steering power directly; knowledge and expertise on the vehicle are, however, necessary. Not only for the steering wheel power but also other parts, when it is not technically achievable to reuse them as it is, they are replaced in part or entirely by standard simulator components.

In the end, the driver is in a real cockpit, with a windshield, doors, and seats, which provides the most immersive environment as a cabin. The passenger seat often provides a way for an instructor or engineer to sit next to the driver, helping communication and analysis in some cases.
Building this type of cabin requires time, vast knowledge of vehicles, and mechanical skills in addition to the cost of the car itself.
3.1.4.3 The main display system

Many different systems can provide the display, from the most simple using a single monitor to the most elaborate systems using a synchronized multiprojection system with distortion correction and image blending. Visual cues are used the most while driving, and it is crucial not to underestimate what performant display systems can provide comparatively to lesser quality ones. Let us see the main aspects of display systems.
3.1.4.3.1 The display size

Larger display areas provide a better immersion, as they provide more information to the driver. Especially for scenarios including intersections, corners, or lane change, including other vehicles or moving objects, a display system including most or all of the natural field of view (FOV) of the driver becomes necessary. Independently from the FOV, the distance between the driver's eye and the physical screen affects how the eye focuses (the contraction of the muscles in the eye). In a driving situation, eye cornea muscles are mostly relaxed; the distance of the screen is best when eye fatigue is similar to real conditions.
However, as a side effect, a large field of vision accentuates the problem of motion sickness in simulators, so proper countermeasures are necessary.
3.1.4.3.2 Brightness and contract
When the driver needs to read a sign or look at details, it is better if the driver does not have to concentrate or take more time than in reality. Higher resolutions

and high brightness and contrast help to solve that problem, not only in terms of comfort for the driver but also because it can affect the reaction times or become a distraction. Even if displays cannot yet reproduce the light energy found in a real driving simulation, displays with high brightness and high contrast become essential when lighting is an integral part of the simulation.
3.1.4.3.3 Large FOV and multi-display systems

To provide an image with a large angle, unless using a Virtual Reality headset, multiple displays combined is the general solution. It is also possible to use specially designed curved mirrors combined with a projector. However, that second option is not the preferred one in simulators because once stretched on the full FOV, the image resolution is often too low.

For multi- display systems, both projectors and monitors are valid options. Usually, simulators do not combine projectors and monitors for the main display, but monitors can be used in a multi- projector system in place of mirrors, for instance.

In multi- display systems, monitors have the disadvantage of having a frame with a bezel, which prevents generating a continuous image over the whole FOV. In contrast, projector images can overlap and blend to solve that issue. The use of monitors of different sizes allows making bezels less noticeable, for instance, when their position matches the cockpit front pillars.

Monitors, however, do not require much more space than the actual display area and are preferred for compact systems. They are also relatively easy to set up with well- designed support frames, and small errors in their position do not affect the simulation much compared to projectors.

Projectors on their side also have strengths. As explained above, they project an image on a screen of any shape. For simulators with large FOV, we often find a portion of or a full cylinder, sphere, or prism, sometimes used in combination with a floor screen. The immediate advantage is that there is no separation in the display surface, which allows generating an uninterrupted image. As a counterpart, geometrical correction of the image is mandatory, so that seen from the driver viewpoint, the scene is not distorted. Second, the projected images of two adjacent projectors overlap, but without any processing, so that the overlap band is twice as bright as other areas. The brightness correction that solves this problem is commonly called edge blending. The software that generates the image can be in charge of these transformations. That is also, in general, a less expensive solution. However, if the simulator must run with two or more different software solutions, it might be necessary to consider using a projection system that is able to deal with the geometrical and brightness corrections directly. So the often time- consuming setup and configuration of each software can be avoided.

In terms of size, projectors require more room space, but at the same time, they can work with large screens, and therefore allow creating more distance between the driver's eye and screen surface. Finally, projectors are also more resistant to motion and vibration than monitors. Especially large monitors can have a reduced lifetime when mounted on motion systems. Figure 3.5 shows and example of dome screen using eight projectors for display.
Figure 3.5 Multi-projector display system in a driving simulator with a dome

We can also use CAVE systems in a simulator where CAVE stands for Cave Automatic Virtual Environment. It consists of several flat projection screens and corresponding projectors. The most common configurations involve at least three screens/projector pairs (front, left, and right).

This type of display is used mainly for data visualization, or for entertainment to explore a virtual world. Nevertheless, some CAVE systems can be found in DS, like the one from Nagoya University CAVE DS, which also includes stereoscopic vision (Figure 3.6).
Figure 3.6 Nagoya University's CAVE Driving Simulator with stereoscopic vision [2]
3.1.4.3.4 Displays in a system with motion

Let us now consider display systems and motion systems together. The role of the motion system is to provide motion cues to the driver. As the motion system creates movement and physically modifies the reference position of the driver eyepoint, the viewpoint of the generated image must follow in real time the eyepoint reference. One method is to make the display system physically combined with the motion system. However, when the display system is independent and stationary as in Figure 3.7, the software must nullify the movement of the eyepoint relative to the display system in the final image. For this, data of the current eye reference position in the cockpit relative to the screens must be acquirable in real time. We develop more on this matter in Chapter 4.
Figure 3.7 Eyepoint reference in a simulator
3.1.4.3.5 Head-mounted displays

3.1.4.3.5 Head- mounted displaysA head- mounted display (HMD) for virtual reality (also called VR headset) is another option for DS. They are compact and easily adaptable to any simulator, and they allow avoiding problems of complex multi- display systems while providing a large FOV. Usually worn on the user's head, HMDs can also be mounted on a helmet in case of aviation applications. In both cases, the HMD integrates a small LCD in front of one eye (monocular HMD) or a display in front of each eye (binocular HMD), which gives the user a sense of depth (Figure 3.8). Combined with a head- tracking device, it allows moving and rotating the camera in the virtual scene by replicating the motion of the user's head. The result is the illusion of the head moving in a virtual environment, resulting in a high degree of immersion.
Figure 3.8 Head-mounted displays (HMDs) used for gaming (a) and medical research (b)
However, they have two main issues to solve:

The driver is not able to see his/her hands and the steering wheel, switches, and levers. This issue can be partially dealt with by using hand movement detections and creating a virtual image of the cockpit, hands, and arms of the driver. This field is under development due to the democratization of HMDs, and future products may integrate as a standard feature, the image of the physical cockpit, and the body of the driver in the 3D scene.

The other issue is comfort. As for the first problem, each new generation of products improves this aspect. For the readers, we want to mention some points of consideration when selecting a device: (1) The ease of wearing it and removing it, (2) The weight of the set and its balance, (3) The presence of cables and battery and if they are a problem or not, and (4) The number of users and sanitary/cleaning issues.
Nevertheless, an HMD allows creating an environment entirely virtual and displaying objects that are not in the physical cockpit. They become beneficial
devices in research on HMI, and we can easily add them to a simulator that already has a traditional display system.
3.1.4.4 Head-up displays
We wrote about the primary display system, but depending on the research needs, a simulator can include multiple additional display systems in different forms.

The first one is the instrument panel, including the speed meter, tachometer, and other information on the vehicle as in a real car. An authentic instrument panel cluster can be used and connected to the simulation software to provide a realistic experience to the driver. However, using real clusters prevents from changing its design, and what and how the driver reads the information. When the flexibility on the design of the instrumentation is imperative, some configurations use LCDs, where the software generates a graphical representation of the instruments. It is possible in that case to adapt the look and feel of the cockpit of the vehicle and to conduct research on HMI on the in- cockpit display.
Touch screens are now also an essential part of the vehicles. They are often included in simulators to connect to multimedia and navigation systems for HMI research and studies.

We also see HUDs installed in some simulators. As HUDs are under very intense research for HMI, there is no typical HUD setup in simulators. An HUD is a display device using a transparent or semi- transparent surface on which information is projected.

The position of the HUD is adjusted with respect to the user's line of sight so they can perceive the information displayed without either having to rotate the head or change the direction of the eyes.

The term HUD comes from the fact that the user can perform a task while keeping the head up and still be able to read instrumentation data on a cockpit or dashboard, unlike traditional head- down displays (HDDs), where the user has to look downward to read the data.

With HUD in vehicles, the superimposition of information over the natural FOV of the user allows minimizing the displacements of the user's eyes. It thus improves the ability to focus on the current task.
There are mainly two categories of HUDs:

- The fixed type are mounted displays that we find mostly when the information is projected onto a windshield (or small device mounted on the dashboard) (Figure 3.9)- Head-mounted type, where the screen is mounted on the user's head, ensuring that it remains in front of the user's eyes. A notable sub-category of head-mounted display (HMD) is the helmet-mounted display (also
abbreviated HMD), for which the information is visible on the helmet's visor (Figure 3.10).
Figure 3.9 User's viewpoint, projector, windshield HUD in a car)
Figure 3.10 Head-mounted display HUD: head-mounted type (JHMCS from Collins Aerospace [5])
3.1.4.4.1 Background

The first HUD was created to allow plane pilots to operate the plane and shoot a machine gun at the same time. Currently, we use HUDs within vehicles, as driving assistance. Stemming from the aircraft industry, HUDs have been adopted by the automotive industry, initially targeting luxury cars. We can also find them as augmented reality display, usually in museums or exhibitions.

For vehicles, they are typically used to project on the windshield the vehicle's current speed and revolutions per minute (rpm). We can also find HUDs in low budget versions where the information is displayed on a small device mounted on the dashboard rather than the windshield (Figure 3.11).
Figure 3.11 Hudway HUD mounted behind the wheel [6]
3.1.4.4.2 Use of HUD in DS
When used in a DS, the HUD is of two forms: either as an actual HUD system or a simulated one (Graphical user interface superimposed on the virtual camera view).
The choice of using an actual HUD or a simulated one depends mainly on the type of goal to achieve, but cost considerations can heavily influence it.
3.1.4.4.3 Using a real HUD hardware

3.1.4.4.3 Using a real HUD hardwareThe use of an actual HUD device implies integrating a projector and a semitransparent mirror when the simulator does not equip a windshield. This type of HUD is often involved when the purpose of the simulator focuses on the development of the HUD itself, usually before integrating it in an actual vehicle. It allows conducting various types of studies, ranging from behavior and performance [7, 8] to ergonomic design [9].
3.1.4.4.4 Simulation of HUD devices in VR
When simulated, the graphical information that would be displayed by the HUD is integrated directly in the simulator's display or projected on the virtual windshield of the car [10].

The main advantage of this solution is the low cost comparing to an actual HUD. It is a valid solution when the purpose of the simulator aims at driver behavioral studies rather than the development of the HUD itself.
3.1.4.5 Steering wheel

The steering wheel is an essential part of the simulator hardware and software integration. The performance of the steering wheel can be crucial in training simulators or simulators used in driver behavior research, and it is also necessary to have a customizable system for R&D on HMI.

A steering wheel in simulators replaces the real steering wheel of the vehicle and plays the roles of retrieving the steering angle input from the driver. The simulation software uses the retrieved data, then reflects its value into the simulation. The system then gets the amount of torque that needs to be applied to the steering wheel of the simulator. The system can inject this value in the force- feedback control that generates torque on the hardware. How the system concretely calculates and uses that value to control the force of the steering wheel depends on the algorithm of the software application; the algorithm itself is sometimes the subject of study in the research. For general driving purposes, the software uses more or less complex mathematical models. The general process is to calculate the effect of the steering angle on the vehicle dynamics, then to determine the force that would occur on the steering shaft. That force comes principally from the reaction between the tire and the road surface. The power steering or power- assisted steering of the vehicle also modifies this force. In that case, the algorithm can be a fixed algorithm with some parameters that the user can change.

In other simulators, it is necessary to be able to change this algorithm, so it is possible to simulate non- standard steering wheel behavior or research on new types of steering feedback and HMI. Figure 3.12 illustrates two types of simulator; the first one provides a control algorithm ready for the user, the second one allows the user to implement their own model.
Figure 3.12 Steering wheel control in a driving simulator
Now let us have a closer look at important aspects of the design of steering wheel devices for simulators.

First, since the steering wheel is used to provide steering angle input to the simulation, some kind of sensor to read the position of the wheel is necessary. There exist several types of sensors that can be used, and some manufacturers develop their sensor. There are two typical families of sensors: sensors measuring the angle of the steering wheel directly, and sensors measuring the movement of the electric motor used to control the position of the steering wheel.
The most important points are how accurate the sensor is and at what frequency the wheel position can be sampled.

The resolution can be defined by the number of bits used to encode the data. For instance, if the angle is encoded using 8 bits, 256 values can be encoded. For a steering wheel, it would be too low a value, and it would not be possible to control the direction of the vehicle with enough precision as it would require too many unnatural adjustments from the driver. Fortunately, nowadays, most steering wheel systems provide more than 10 or 12 bits precision with, respectively, 1 024 and 4 096 possible values. Above 12 bits, it becomes difficult to notice the difference while driving for casual drivers, and some systems provide even 16- bit signals. It is still imperative to understand that the resolution in the signal may not be the same as the physical resolution of the sensor. Because the logic is to select the number of bits so that there is no loss when encoding the real value into a digital one, the number of bits may be higher than what the sensor can truly measure.

From a hardware point of view, an electric motor usually provides force feedback. The motor connects to the wheel with two main strategies: direct drive where the motor transfers the force directly to the shaft of the steering wheel, and non- direct using a gearbox to connect the motor to the wheel. The gearbox increases the torque and allows for using comparatively smaller motors than

direct- drive systems. Direct- drive systems are naturally heavier and more costly, but they get rid of every small disturbance coming from the gearbox. For instance, the micro gaps between gears can cause small drops in torque. The elasticity of the belts can generate wrong feedback too. The gearbox also is a component that, with time, wears out, and the discomfort can increase. About the motor itself, cogging is another important point for the quality of the steering wheel. Cogging is the irregularity in the torque due to static magnetic forces of the motor and other design and manufacturing quality. Finally, some natural friction exists and generates a resistive torque and damping when turning the wheel even if no electric current flows to the motor. Resistance must be as low as possible so that the feedback provided to the drivers comes primarily from the mathematical model of the software instead of forces that exist just from the mechanical parts of the device.

The role of the software is to calculate the wanted feedback that represents best the behavior of the simulated vehicle steering system. Theoretically, the torque generated on the steering wheel from the vehicle is the only input that the software should provide to the control unit of the motor. However, as it is the response of the car to the current angle of the steering wheel, it is naturally a closed- loop system where the frequency of the control loop becomes essential. The rate of the loop depends on how fast the software can calculate the feedback and communicate with the motor control unit. In many instances, some high- frequency responses cannot be correctly reproduced with only a direct torque control from the software. It becomes especially noticeable when the torque is almost null and, in worst cases, can also prevent the system from stabilizing at the wanted angle. Most steering wheel systems, to deal with these issues, provide additional control functions like generating extra friction and damping forces. The software then must mix these functions with the main torque control.
3.1.4.6 Motion, haptic feedback

The goal of motion systems in simulators is to provide a driving experience as close as possible to the driver as motion cues give vital information to the driver while driving. Simple logic says the driver feels motion in a real vehicle; this is why the simulator should at least partially reproduce it to reduce the gap between simulation and reality. The difference between the movements perceived on the screen and physically is also a cause of motion sickness in simulators. Motion sickness highly reduces the active time drivers can spend in the simulator, which impacts on productivity and the achievements of the study or training. Additionally, motion cues play an essential role in the driver's judgment on how to steer the vehicle.

Many research results teach on what hardware and control systems are most effective for different kinds of usage. Even though there is no ideal solution, we can find some commonly used configurations that we describe in this paragraph.
We explain in more detail about motion cueing and haptic feedback in the next section of this book and invite our readers to go through its content for a more in- depth understanding.
3.1.4.7 Physiological measurement

Studies on driver behavior require retrieving measurable data that can be analyzed and compared. As a black- box approach, the action of the driver can be measured by looking at data on the steering wheel and pedal inputs, and then we can compare some reaction time to scenario events. It is also possible to ask the driver to perform some additional tasks like pressing a button or a specific switch and then record the timing of these actions.

But a black- box approach is limited as it cannot extract what the driver felt, thought, or the reason for a reaction or an attitude. As a white- box approach, surveys are also often conducted, and well- designed questions provide valuable data by asking the driver directly what he felt, thought, and the reasons for what he did. However, when it is necessary to conduct a comparative study where the same driver has to go through several scenarios, surveying each run will very probably influence the driver for the next series. Switching patterns and 3D environments can help to ensure the driver reacts naturally to the situation instead of anticipating because of the questions. Still, it is time- consuming and can reduce the validity of the comparison. With few iterations, it might be possible to ask questions after all the runs, but after a time, the driver may forget what happened and won't be able to answer accurately.

These difficulties are where physiological measurements come to help, by cross- checking results and sometimes highlighting facts that could not be found only with a black- box approach and survey techniques. Typical measurements in simulators are electrocardiograms, electrodermal activity (stress level), eye movements and blinking, and neural activity. In the following paragraph, we introduce some of these techniques.
3.1.4.7.1 Neural activity measurement, EEG, MRI, fMRI, and NIRS

Neural activity measurement is about looking at how the brain works during a task. The spatial and temporal distribution of brain activities and their intensity provides information on the concentration or relaxation of the driver and his cognitive effort. Many things are yet to discover on the brain, and neural activity measurement cannot interpret thoughts or images formed in the mind of the driver. However, specific stimulations trigger specific responses, which can be captured by brain imagery techniques. Unfortunately, it does not mean that one brain activity image always corresponds to the same cognitive process. Neural activity measurement in driver behavior research is often about comparative studies where a task is repeated several times with several persons to establish some reference measurements.
Several brain imaging techniques can be used, such as electroencephalography (EEG), near- infrared spectroscopy (NIRS), and functional magnetic resonance imagery (fMRI).

EEG uses electrodes to measure the electrical activity of the brain. Electrodes are placed on the head and perform local surface measurements of brain activity. The measurement device amplifies each electrode signal so that it can draw a graph over time for each location. The number of electrodes is important as it defines the resolution of the measurement. A drawback of EEG is that it can only measure the activity near the surface of the brain; it is not able to detect if a signal comes from a deeper region of the brain. On the other hand, it is a reasonably affordable and portable system, accessible to many researchers.

NIRS is a method to measure brain activity that relies on the level of oxygenation of the blood. Where the brain activates, the oxygen contained in the blood present near the activated area is used to activate the neurons, resulting in less oxygenated blood in that region.

NIRS uses the fact that oxygenated and deoxygenated blood cells absorb light differently. The measurement device, placed directly on the head, emits light in the near- infrared range and measures the amount of reflected light. This technique determines the amount of oxygen in a specific region. However, this measurement is not accurate as an absolute value and provides information on the variation of oxygenated blood. The device is portable and has a better spatial resolution than EEG, but is even more limited to the surface activity of the brain. It is also usually more expensive than EEG but stays accessible to most research.
MRI provides a structural image of an organ by detecting its hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen is present in water, and water makes

of the human body, so reading the distribution of hydrogen atoms provides an image of the organ, the brain in the case that interests us. However, the structure is not the activity, and fMRI also measures the blood oxygenation that indicates brain activity. Oxygenated and deoxygenated hemoglobin have different magnetic responses. Similarly to NIRS, this difference is detected by fMRI, which gives an image of the relative concentration of oxygen in the blood. The image of the activity is then superimposed with the standard brain structure image to recognize activated areas easily.

MRI is a piece of very high- cost equipment that requires a dedicated facility and specific technical skills to use. Also, because it generates a strong magnetic field, it is not possible to use standard DS parts with it. Another weakness is a lower temporal resolution (one to a few seconds) compared to other solutions (milliseconds). However, fMRI provides a much more extensive range of information that can capture activity in the deep layers of the brain with a high spatial resolution. Recent years have seen a growing interest in using fMRI with a DS [11], and it is possible to find driving systems made of plastic or non- magnetic and non- electronic materials.
3.1.4.7.2 Eye-tracking
Eye- tracking commonly refers to the measurement of the eye movements to determine where the user is looking (point of gaze).

Eye- tracking is usually achieved by using an eye- tracking device (Figure 3.13), which continuously measures the position and orientation of the user's eyes. From these data, we can estimate the point of gaze. Further analysis, like contextual analysis, gives information on what the user is looking at.
Figure 3.13 Screen-based eye-tracking devices from Tobii [12], Gazepoint [13]
3.1.4.7.2.1 Types of eye trackers

The first eye- tracking techniques tried to record the eye displacements mechanically. The experimental device made by Delabarre [14] consisted of attaching a "harness" directly onto an anesthetized eye. It was made of plaster material to naturally stick to the eye by itself and trimmed to fit cornea in shape and size. It also contained a hole of the size of the pupil, and a light thread attached the harness to a recording lever, allowing to record the horizontal and vertical movements of the eye onto a smoked surface of a kymograph cylinder. The system could track fairly well the eye movement, but it was limited to slow motion.
Although with time, several techniques have been developed to record the eye movements:

- Electro-oculography (EOG): movements of the eye estimated by measuring the electric signal from two pairs of electrodes positioned around the eye.- Scleral Search Coil technique: the movements of the eye are measured using a coil embedded in a plastic ring placed on the eye [15]- Video-oculography (VOG): video-based combined pupil and corneal reflection [16].
Video- based eye- tracking (or VOG) remains the most popular, mainly due to its low intrusiveness and relatively easy setup [17].
It can be mounted either in front of the user (Figure 3.13), on the same frame as the display, or on the user's head (Figure 3.14).
Figure 3.14 Head-mounted eye-tracking device (Tobii Pro Glasses 2 [18])
In the following, we focus on video- based eye- tracking.
3.1.4.7.2.2 Video base eye- tracking: principle

An eye tracker usually consists of illuminators, cameras, and one or several processing units. The conventional tracking method estimates the position of the pupil's center and the position of the reflection of a light source on the cornea (Figure 3.15).
Figure 3.15 Tracking of the pupil center and corneal reflection, video-based eye tracker

The illuminators (light sources) project a light beam in the direction of the eyes (Figure 3.16) and serve two purposes: make sure the eye is adequately lit to facilitate the detection of the edge of the pupil, and create a reflection on the cornea. After reaching the eyes, the light is reflected and refracted on the user's pupils. A camera then captures this reflection.
Figure 3.16 Principle of a video-based eye tracker
The cameras record the movements of the eye, while the task of the processor unit is to estimate the direction of the eye within the head reference frame.
The difference in the position of the center of the pupil and one (or more) corneal reflection(s) is then used to estimate the eye's orientation in the head reference frame.
This method is known as Pupil Center Corneal Reflection eye- tracking or PCCR.

In the case of a head- mounted eye tracker, the small movements of the eye tracker within the head reference frame can influence the results. Misinterpreted reflections might also adversely affect the tracking accuracy and precision.

Although the main technology used in illuminators to create the reflection on the cornea is near- infrared light sources, some eye- tracking systems use visible light and camera. However, working in the infrared light spectrum improves the
detection of the limits of the pupil considerably and lowers the chances of creating uncontrolled reflections.
3.1.4.7.2.3 Bright pupil tracking vs. dark pupil tracking
We find two types of tracking methods: bright pupil tracking and dark pupil tracking (Figure 3.17):

- Bright pupil tracking: the illuminator is placed close to the optical axis of the camera. The result is that the pupil appears brighter than the iris, in a similar way as the red eyes effect in photos with flash.- Dark pupil tracking: the illuminators are placed away from the optical axis of the camera, causing the pupil to appear darker than the iris.
Figure 3.17 Bright pupil tracking vs. dark pupil tracking

For the most advanced devices, these methods can be used simultaneously at the calibration phase. Then the method that offers the highest accuracy is kept for tracking. Also, some eye- tracking devices automatically switch from one method to the other, for instance, when the device loses tracking.
3.1.4.7.2.4 Applications

Applications involving eye- tracking techniques are available in a wide range of domains where eye movement plays an important role. Among them are: psychology, marketing/advertising, neuroscience, industrial engineering, sports science, and computer science [19].
Research applications:
The main applications orbit around behavioral research:

1. Consumer research: focuses on identifying the preferences, attitudes, motivations, and buying behavior of customers that helps marketing campaigns target the right types of customers. 
2. Human performance evaluation for athletes. 
3. Driving: driver's behavior on the road and reduce accidents.
HMI
Eye- tracking techniques happened to be very beneficial for persons who cannot operate a mouse or keyboard, for instance, persons with cerebral palsy, or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) [20].

When integrating eye- tracking into an HMI, the activity of the eye can be used to bypass traditional manual operations. The eye itself becomes the input device: the gaze direction controls a cursor position, and the user looking at the same location for a certain amount of time can be equivalent to one action.
3.1.4.7.2.5 Limitations
Like any measuring techniques, eye- tracking shows limitations:
Eyelid ptosis (droopy eyelids):

The eyelids don't open to an average full extent, partially blocking the pupil. This condition makes it more difficult for the camera to detect the edge of the pupil, which decreases the accuracy of the tracking.
Mydriasis:

Often encountered when the user is under medication prescribed for muscle relaxation, like Baclofen for ALS. In the case of Mydriasis, the pupil dilates significantly more than usual, also decreasing the ability of the camera to detect the pupil's edge.
Although some systems take into account both ptosis and mydriasis, both conditions might adversely affect the quality of eye- tracking.
- Head motion:
Either in case of fixed tracking or mobile tracking, the motion of the head can induce difficulties in tracking eye motions.
3.1.4.8 ECUs and sensor modules

ECU was originally the abbreviation for engine control unit, but it became electronic control unit as ECUs started to control more parts of the vehicle. They are embedded computers, and a vehicle usually contains more than one ECU. Each ECU has a task like controlling the engine to maximize its power while reducing emissions, control pre- crash brake systems, manage the automatic shift of a transmission, deal with idle stop control, and other advanced systems that are in vehicles. There are also embedded computers that centralize data to distribute orders and information to other units, so there is a coherent control over the various functions of the vehicle.

Embedded computers can only work if they receive information about the status of the vehicle, driver, and the environment around the vehicle. Retrieving physical measurement and formatting them into data that ECUs can process is the role of the sensors. Many sensors are looking at mechanical parts of the vehicle that give data on the status of the vehicles. There are also sensors like Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR), radar, cameras, and GPS. They provide information about the road, surrounding vehicles, pedestrians, and other important features of the environment like signs and road lane marking.

For simulators having a focus on vehicle R&D, mechanical parts are modeled and simulated by the software. ECUs can be incorporated in the simulator as long as they can receive data as they would in real conditions. When we connect ECUs to a simulator, we talk about HIL systems. They are very common, and several suppliers, such as dSPACE and National Instruments, provide real- time solutions to connect the simulation with hardware components.

It is also possible to connect real sensors to the simulator. For instance, a camera captures the image generated on a screen placed in front. A radar catches the electromagnetic waves generated by radio frequency (RF) transmitter that simulates target objects.
Figure 3.18 illustrates an example of the architecture of an HIL simulator.
Figure 3.18 Typical setup for HIL simulators

In terms of the usefulness of such architecture, HIL simulators are used in the last stage of simulation for the development of a vehicle, where hardware is subject to a final test sequence to find potential issues that could not be found in pure simulation. The combination of ECUs with a simulator enables to test most of the software logic; adding real sensors to the system helps improve the robustness of the final design. Because these tests are conducted in a simulator, the engineers can use many scenes and situations to assess the vehicle systems in a much more efficient way than using prototypes, which are onerous and time- consuming to build and use for tests.
3.1.5 Software architecture
3.1.5.1 Vehicle modeling and simulation
3.1.5.1.1 Role and integration of the vehicle simulation

The simulation of the dynamic behavior of the vehicle is one of the core software components. It connects with most of the other software and hardware components. It is an essential component in the simulator, therefore it should be performant, stable, and versatile. We can list its essential roles as follows.
3.1.5.1.1.1 Simulate the dynamic movement of the vehicle accurately to test its performance

The physical behavior is the response to the various forces and constraints applied to the car, such as the normal reaction of the road, gravity, air friction, tire friction, engine power, and braking force.

3.1.5.1.1.2 Respond to user driving input, ADAS, and other ECU commandsVehicles are complex not only because of their mechanical parts but because most of these parts are monitored and controlled by the driver and by computers. It goes without explanation that the software must be able to take the driver's driving into account. Also, the mathematical representation of the vehicle dynamics should be as modular as possible with clear input and output specifications for each module. The modular approach enables the replacement of modules by new ones developed by engineers while using other modules as generic vehicle simulation. For research on ADAS, modularity is also necessary to connect necessary logical components or units throughout the mechanical process of the vehicle.
3.1.5.1.1.3 Reproduce the movement and other information of the vehicle represented in the virtual environment

In a DS, the vehicle simulation should provide all the information that is usually visible and audible from a driver's point of view. It includes the movement of the body, wheels, suspension, and information displayed in the instrument panel. The audio simulation mostly uses the RPM, the load of the engine, rolling, and slip conditions of the tires.
3.1.5.1.1.4 Provide data to control motion and haptic feedback

Vehicle movement provides the information to control motion systems. Simple vehicle dynamics descriptions often stop at what is necessary to calculate the vehicle movements; still, DS also need to give haptic feedback that includes the force felt from the steering wheel, pedals, and seat vibrations. From the simulation of the tires included in any physical models, we can directly derive the steering feedback force. It is less trivial to find models for pedal and vibration feedback in simulators, and they are often developed as additional features getting information from the primary vehicle simulation, without sending back their results into it. Nonetheless, they can be quite critical in some scenarios to give proper immersion and feedback to the driver.
3.1.5.1.1.5 Integrate with the simulation of the environment, surrounding vehicles, and pedestrians

In the previous items, we had a vehicle and driver- centric view of the simulation. Here we want to consider the car in its environment and other dynamic elements. The surrounding is mostly composed of road traffic and pedestrians, weather, and lighting conditions. As we describe in the next section,

the traffic simulation can start from very simplistic models with only a few cars surrounding the main vehicle to very advanced models, including multimodal transport systems. In a simulator, it is imperative to integrate the vehicle model with the other elements of the environment. The interactions between the driver vehicle and other vehicles or other agents of the traffic are the primary goal. It provides a proper and realistic simulation of the surrounding, enabling not only research on driver's behavior but also ideal object sensing data of the traffic that is part of the ADAS input. In the scope of intelligent transportation systems or autonomous driving research, the integration of the main car into one whole traffic simulation also permits studies on communication between the vehicle and other elements of the environment such as other vehicles, pedestrians or elements of the infrastructure, often summarized in the term V2X communications, where V stands for Vehicle and X anything.
Given the different roles given above, we can draw the following diagram (Figure 3.19) that shows the relation between the vehicle simulation and other components of the simulator.
Figure 3.19 Vehicle simulation in the software architecture
3.1.5.1.2 Vehicle dynamics simulation

Vehicle dynamics is an essential part of the simulation when it comes to research and development of vehicles. In that case, the simulation runs with specialized software solutions such as CarSim or CarMaker. Engineers can also develop their model or customize existing ones with solutions like SimulinkÂ®, for

instance. When the focus is more on the driver, it is not always necessary to use a specialized solution; vehicle dynamics provided as one component of integrated solutions generally provide accurate simulation for most scenarios.

Whether the dynamics simulation comes from a dedicated solution or an integrated solution, the modeling of the vehicle always relies on mathematical models of the different components implemented by software algorithms. These models have a set of parameters that the user modifies to simulate the desired behavior. In cars, many elements act on the dynamics, and it takes advanced engineering skills to obtain a stable and performant result as a whole vehicle. It is the same for vehicle software simulation; the more advanced and precise is a model, the more difficult and time- consuming it is to tune. It is a necessary step for simulation focused on vehicle engineering; it is not or should not be a slow process when the focus is on the driver. We would recommend selecting the appropriate software solution or switch between solutions depending on the goal of the simulation.
Below is a concise introduction of the dynamic model of a vehicle we hope helps non- expert readers to organize their work when facing the difficult task of creating a new model for their experiment.
3.1.5.1.2.1 Vehicle body model

This model defines the dimensions and mass of the vehicle and layout of the other components. It is in charge of integrating the simulation of the sub- models and provides the dynamics of the whole body of the car.
3.1.5.1.2.2 Tire and wheel model
This model simulates the interactions between the tire and the road surface and calculates the physical behavior of the wheel.
3.1.5.1.2.3 Suspension model
This model simulates the behavior of the suspension and integrates the interactions between the sprung mass and the wheels.
3.1.5.1.2.4 Powertrain dynamic model

This model includes the engine and the transmission, and depending on the software solution, it can have different levels of granularity or simplification. In advanced and specialized solutions, every mechanical part of the powertrain is simulated, and configurable with parameters.
3.1.5.1.2.5 Brake system model
This model defines the type of brake system and the parameters of its properties.
3.1.5.1.2.6 Steering dynamics
This model simulates the mechanical parts and power assistance to the steering. It is an essential part of the model to provide correct haptic feedback to the driver.
3.1.5.1.3 ADAS simulation

Car manufacturers and providers strive to make more performant, efficient, safer, and comfortable cars at each generation. A large part of the research work is now on ADAS. ADAS includes not only automatic support from the vehicle but feedback given to the driver through the HMI. Research in that field can go from developing an entirely new ADAS to improving the performance of an existing one. The development also touches the algorithm, hardware, and HMI components. The software architecture for ADAS development must be very flexible and customizable to allow engineers and researchers to simulate every aspect at all the stages of the R&D.

We must also consider that many vehicles now include various ADAS, so research on driver behavior also requires a generic simulation of existing systems. We write generic here because a lot of then are still under intense development and have improved each year; there is also a difference between manufacturers. A simulator cannot take into account all the variations of existing ADAS but should at least provide generic ones with the possibility of parameter customization.
All these considerations lead to the following conclusions.

1. The simulation software must include generic and configurable ADAS features.  
2. The simulation software must provide a way to replace ADAS logic modules or incorporate new ones.  
3. The simulation software must provide the information to feed connected ADAS algorithms or devices.  
4. The software must provide a way to represent HMI in the virtual environment, and must provide tools to customize it.

Some of the listed requirements are important until real HMI devices or ECUs are connected to the simulator and play their role in the simulator directly. But as a simulation, they are essential features through the first stages of the development. Below is a list of typical ADAS features amongst the multitude of algorithms a software could provide.

1. Adaptive cruise control (ACC) system  
2. Lane departure warning and lane keeping assist system  
3. Forward collision warning  
4. Advanced emergency braking system  
5. Blind spot monitoring
6. Traffic sign recognition 7. Adaptive front lighting system.
3.1.5.1.4 Sensors

Nowadays, cars integrate sensors for ADAS as commonly as ABS, at different levels with different options, but they are, with no doubt, an integrating part of the vehicles. If we go back a few years, driver's senses, as a part of the system, were the only sensors used for the driving maneuvers. Therefore, simulators were designed and built for the driver. Now vehicles have their own eyes and ears, and the simulation must provide the corresponding "cues" to the system.

Primary sensors in cars are cameras, stereo cameras, long- and short- range radars, and LiDAR sensors. All of them first give a physical measurement of the environment around the vehicle. This physical measurement can be used almost directly in some cases; for instance, rear and side cameras provide an all- around view to the driver in the navigation monitor.

Including camera imagery, the raw data stream coming from a sensor is treated and merged with some other sensor data to extract meaningful information that is used by the ADAS algorithms. For instance, the result of this data fusion is often a list of relative positions and velocities of objects surrounding the vehicle, detection of road signs, or the color of a traffic signal.

Sensor manufacturers, in addition to the raw data, deliver some postprocessed information directly to relieve vehicle computers from processing raw data. Given this context, let us establish what the simulation software should provide in a simulator architecture.
3.1.5.1.4.1 Ideal sensor and physical models

By ideal sensor, we refer to the result of data fusion. Data fusion takes data from the sensors and makes sense of it in the form of object- oriented information. As typical ideal data, we have the positions of the surrounding vehicles or pedestrians, their speed and movement prediction, the positions of the lanes and road markings, signs information, or traffic lights with color information. Ideal data still takes into account the main characteristics of the sensor, such as the maximum sensing distance, the angular range of detection, light conditions, or obstruction by other objects. That way, the model can return what is supposed to be detected by real sensors. However, it is not possible to take into account noise, resolution, or errors that occur with real sensor data.

A physically based simulation uses mathematical models of the phenomenon that generates the physical value that is measured by the sensor. Physically based models can use very advanced theory or a simplified one when it is necessary to simulate in real time. For instance, models that simulate light could model it only as a ray of photons to simplify it, or calculate the propagation of the electromagnetic waves, and take into account interferences of other waves.

This type of simulation provides a series of physical values as an intermediate result. Then in the context of vehicle sensor simulation, the physical values must be converted in the same or a similar format to the output of the imitated sensor.

A physical sensor simulation does not rely only on a mathematical model and program algorithms; the physical definition of the environment is also necessary, or else there would be no target against which to simulate. The physical definition or modeling of the environment may not be trivial. However, thanks to the advance in computer graphics, and that ADAS sensors use light as information, the way to define object materials for light reflection with a physical approach is mostly standardized. We invite our readers to refer to Section 4.3.2 of Chapter 4. Even if this approach uses a simplified model, it is relevant for real- time applications, which is the case for most simulators.

Sensor errors or failures are other aspects of sensor simulation; simulating them is critical to design robust algorithms. Algorithms for ADAS impact performance and safety, and testing them with a full extent of hardware precision error, noise, and failure is a crucial point for engineering them. Regarding sensors, first, there are precision errors by design that can be reasonably straightforward to model and simulate. If we take the example of a pre- crash system using object distance information retrieved from image processing of a stereo camera, the sensor is limited in the precision in which it can capture the distance of objects. By design, the pixel resolution, FOV, and spacing between both cameras are the essential factors that set the precision of the sensor. From this information, a simple equation gives the error range depending on the distance of the object. A simple way to simulate that error would be to add a random value generated within the calculated error range. But, other precision loss or failure to measure a distance can occur because of the limitations of the program that analyzes the stereo image. For instance, a simple stereo image processing is sensitive to reflections, lack of contrast, or lack of color change in the image. Errors and failure patterns must be analyzed and modeled to be simulated meaningfully, and sometimes it is simpler to take the physically based approach. In that case, the physical approach would be to simulate the raw data stream of the stereo camera and use that data with the actual image processing algorithm. In that case, the challenge shifts from simulating the final results of the sensor to creating photo- realist computer graphics.

It would not be possible to provide an answer to whether physically based sensor simulation or ideal sensor simulation should be used. Both methods have strengths and weaknesses depending on the subject of the study, and the phase of the research. Researchers and engineers must decide which way to go for a DS environment and sometimes switch from one approach to the other.
In the following, we introduce the concept of the three most typical sensors used in ADAS, that software applications can provide.
3.1.5.1.4.2 Camera sensors

Cameras for ADAS are, in essence, standard camera sensors placed around the car to catch the information of the surrounding. Cameras can also work with infrared light to help identify heat sources like pedestrians when they are not detectable with visible light.

The data coming from the camera is captured by a data- processing unit or presented to the driver with minor modification like the one to provide an allaround view. Deep neural networks are now famous for making extensive use of camera imagery to detect objects and extract other meaningful information.
Cameras for ADAS include monocular and stereo cameras. Stereo cameras provide depth information using stereo computer vision techniques and make it possible to detect the distance with obstacles.

Radars are not a new invention, and they have applications in many domains. For ADAS, radar systems have been improved and specialized for the automotive industry. A transmitter sends a frequency modulated continuous wave (FMCW), as the name says, continuously. The receiver also functions continuously. The time to receive the emitted wave, its frequency modified by Doppler effect, and the direction from which the wave returns are used to determine objects' distance, velocity, and position relative to the sensor, respectively. The intensity of the wave can also provide information on the material on which the wave is reflected. Still, radars have the most difficulty in classifying objects as waves mainly bounce on metallic materials.
