4.2.3 Modeling the road surface
The final representation of the road is often a 3D surface defined as a triangulated irregular network (TIN), or as a procedural model or a combination of both.
Figure 4.6 shows both representations of the same road. On the picture, the TIN is a quad network, but it is easy enough to imagine each quad divided into two triangles.
Figure 4.6 Representation of the road surface as a procedural model (right) and TIN model (left) (VR-Design Studio)

The procedural representation of a road generally uses a horizontal alignment (Figure 4.7) and vertical alignment or curve (Figure 4.8). A 3D spline or actual road curvature alignments such as circles and Clothoid spirals are all mathematically defined and give the main information on the shape of the road.
Figure 4.7 Curves used in horizontal road alignments (VR-Design Studio)

This road curvature is then combined, usually with a cross- section shape (Figure 4.9) that defines the change in road height in the lateral direction of the road. The cross- section can be either defined with a series of points or another curve mathematically defined.
Figure 4.9 Samples of road cross-sections (VR-Design Studio)

The road surface information at any point of the road is calculable from the two coordinates defined as the station (distance along the horizontal road alignment), and the offset (distance to the horizontal alignment).

An advantage of a procedural representation is to be less time- consuming than defining a full TIN mesh manually while allowing to automatically generate a 3D mesh for the visual representation of the road surface. However, it is not possible or very complicated to define details such as road bumps or holes in the road surface. Irregularities in the road surface can be very difficult to describe mathematically, and their shapes do not always depend on the station and offset coordinates. We can add bumps and other asperities to the procedural model as patches that applies a modification to the road surface. These patches are small TIN meshes or height maps stored in a grid format and reused at different positions on the road. For instance, bridges joints, maintenance holes, and potholes can be represented that way with a reasonable
modeling time. The open format OpenCRG is an example of such representation as shown in Figure 4.10.
Figure 4.10 OpenCRG detailed road surface definition as a curved map (OpenCRG user manual) https://www.vires.com/opencrg/docs/OpenCRGUserManual.pdf

A final method uses LiDAR scan data to define the road surface of existing roads. The point cloud generated from a scan can be triangulated and give a physical representation of the road surface. These scans can be challenging to obtain every part of the road. Instead of defining the whole road surface, it is possible to incorporate them as patches at strategic positions on the carriageway.

In terms of simulation of the vehicle, we often see drivers going too fast and not able to maintain the car in the limits of the road until they get used to driving in the simulator. That issue necessitates deciding whether to allow driving on other surfaces and dealing with the boundary of the carriageway. When allowing driving outside the limit of the definition of the road, the software must pass some default ground surface information to the vehicle simulation algorithm. A method is to generate a 3D mesh wide enough around the definition of the road. It is also possible to extrapolate the defined road surface outside its boundary. However, this method can be arduous to apply in curves in a nonhorizontal road as it requires complex methods to ensure providing a smooth and continuous surface.

The other option is to force the vehicle within the limits of the carriageway by applying an external force to the car and push it back within limits. This method provides a natural look and feeling to the driver, but it can be a problem when combined with motion feedback. An alternative technique is to change the position of the vehicle instantaneously back into the road boundaries while taking care of not generating small shocks due to sudden change in road surface conditions.
4.2.4 Transparent and semi-transparent surfaces
4.2.4.1 Concepts of transparency in computer graphics
Polygons with transparent parts or semi- transparent polygons are useful for drawing various real- world objects, such as trees, glass, and markings, as described below.
Usually, we define transparent or semi- transparent parts of a polygon with a texture that serves as a mask. For a

transparent part, the mask is used in the shader to decide if the fragment is drawn or discarded; it necessitates no special algorithm. Figure 4.11 shows the result of the image process for both cases, where the mask defines
transparent parts, and the opacity defines the amount of light that is blocked by the polygon.
Figure 4.11 Use of masks and transparency textures

However, attention is required in the drawing of semi- transparent polygons. The color of the polygon is not determined only by the lighting calculation of the polygon but also depends on the color behind the polygon, so it cannot be drawn like a regular polygon. When dealing with semi- transparent polygons, it is necessary to determine the color that is behind and blend it correctly with the color of the polygon, so the final results represent a semi- transparent surface.

The simplest way to do this is to treat polygons separately from nontranslucent ones. After drawing opaque surfaces, all semi- transparent triangles must be sorted from the farthest to the closest to the viewpoint and rendered in that order, so semi- transparent polygons blend correctly together.

There is another method called depth pilling, where fragments are sorted instead of polygons. Each rendered fragment belongs to a layer where layers are split of the space in the depth direction. The number of splits defines the precision of the sorting, and several techniques can be used to implement depth pilling [1]. This method has the advantage of using the GPU instead of the CPU for sorting elements of the scene.
4.2.4.2 Trees and vegetation

If we wanted to represent trees and plants geometrically fully, it would require too many polygons for real- time rendering. To solve that problem, vegetation, especially leaves, are represented with few polygons where each polygon has a texture showing many leaves and possibly branches. Parts that are not leaves are masked out using another texture or the alpha channel as a mask. Figure 4.12 shows a tree where the mask is applied on the branches and leaves on the left side, and not applied on the right side.
Figure 4.12 An example of tree model using a texture mask

However, when using mipmap to adapt the resolution of the object texture to the resolution of the framebuffer, textures, and masks are resized to a lower resolution, changing the original value of the mask and color. In the original texture, if masked pixels are black, in the lower resolution versions of the mipmap, neighboring pixels are mixed with the masked black pixels. If mixed pixels include more nonmasked polygons than masked ones, the pixel is visible, thus showing a darker pixel than intended. We can avoid this problem by customizing the mipmap resizing process and not take into account pixels initially masked. Another solution is to use a similar color for masked pixels than non- masked ones that are in proximity.
4.2.4.3 Windows and glass
The transmission of light through glass or translucent materials is simulated with semi- transparent polygons as shown in Figure 4.13.
Figure 4.13 Glass representation

Transparent materials such as glass are also very reflective, depending on the incident angle of the light. In addition to blending the color of the semi- transparent surface with what is behind, simulating the reflection of the surface itself is crucial to give the correct effect. Once the reflection on the material is calculated, this result is set as the color of the polygon. That color is then blended with the color of the fragment that is behind to give a transparent effect. Even fully transparent surfaces should be rendered that way to provide the correct effect.

For more photorealistic rendering, we sometimes render refraction computer graphics. For windows, because they are manufactured to keep the distortion due to refraction very small, it is not necessary to try rendering it, at least for a driving simulation context. However, the refraction of the water on the road or the windshield can be an appreciated addition. Simple simulation is often enough as the goal is not to really simulate refraction but only the effect of refraction. We can simplify the process by blending the surface color with a fragment that already exists in the scene. For each fragment, a refraction vector is calculated using its position and normal. The fragment to blend from the pre- rendered scene is selected using that vector. In reality, the light may
be refracted from something that is not visible in the rendered scene, but as mentioned, we only want to give an effect of refraction.

At first, it may look superfluous to render transparent surfaces in a driving simulator. It may have been the case before, or maybe because computers were not powerful enough, no real attention was put to it. But now it is possible, and real- time rendering of transparent surfaces can push forward the development of HMIs or cockpits that rely on this type of material. Another critical aspect is the information a driver gets through the windows of other vehicles or buildings. How many did we anticipate braking times by looking, through the windows of the vehicle immediately in front, at the brake lamps of vehicles further ahead? With Figure 4.14 that shows how the driving scene looks like with transparent car windows, we clearly see that it is possible to look at the brake lamp of the car in front.
Figure 4.14 Checking brake lamps through the window of the forward vehicle
4.2.5 Optimization for real- time application
4.2.5.1 Geometry simplification and texturing

4.2.5.1 Geometry simplification and texturingRendering a scene requires processing each vertex of the 3D objects to calculate the position and color of each pixel of the image. Therefore, the rendering time is highly dependent on the number of vertices used in the scene and the number of pixels of the screen. The surface of the road, for instance, in reality, is made of many asperities visible from the driver's point of view. We see it in the form of shadows and change in color that give the grain of the surface. It would demand too much from the GPU to store all the vertices and render the geometry of the asperities and other irregularities of the road only using a geometrical definition. With regards to geometrical details, depending on the desired level of detail, significant parts of objects shape are represented with polygons and some surfaces that can be considered flat and defined with only one polygon. Surfaces defined flat, but that, in reality, include visible geometrical details and color patterns use texturing to represent them.Also, already explained about the modeling of trees and vegetation, masking is another method to simplify shape definitions while representing complex ones. Figure 4.15 shows an example where the truss beams of the bridge and mesh of the fence are only using a flat polygon but making it look like a much more complex geometry.

Also, already explained about the modeling of trees and vegetation, masking is another method to simplify shape definitions while representing complex ones. Figure 4.15 shows an example where the truss beams of the bridge and mesh of the fence are only using a flat polygon but making it look like a much more complex geometry.
Figure 4.15 Geometry simplification using masks
4.2.5.2 Normal mapping

4.2.5.2 Normal mappingNormal mapping is also commonly used to optimize the rendering process. Normal mapping is used to describe bumps and dents in the surface, which is used to alter the light reflections and refractions, resulting in a way more appealing output while drastically reducing the number of vertices, which reduces memory use. For example, describing the nerves of leather in a car seat would require millions of vertices, making the model too big to fit in memory and very slow to render. With normal mapping represented in Figures 4.16 and 4.17, the vertices only describe the general shape of the car seat, and a single repeating texture describes the nerves of the leather. The memory use is significantly reduced, and such a model can be rendered in real time.
Figure 4.16 Normal mapping. Left: the base model. Right: the model optimized with normal mapping, requiring only the same number of vertices as the base model.
Figure 4.17 Road surface representation without (top) and with a normal map (bottom)
4.2.5.3 Texture baking

As another technique, texture baking saves into one or several textures the result of rendering a scene with advanced calculation techniques too complicated for real- time application. The saved texture is then applied as- is on the object to improve the lighting calculation effect such as shadows or indirect lights and improve the sense of depth. During the baking phase, the surface of the rendered object is rendered with the
appropriate viewpoint and resolution, and then the resulting image is saved as new texture for the object. Rendering effects are "baked" and ready to be consumed by the real- time application.

For driving simulators, changing sunlight conditions in real time might be necessary, so it is not recommended to bake sunlight and resulting shadows. However, parts that usually receive less light than others, whatever the position of the sun, should appear darker. In real- time applications, ambient occlusion (SSAO and SSDO) is the most common technique to simulate that effect. Still, it is somewhat time- consuming on the GPU and lacks precision in some cases so that baking textures (Figure 4.18) can be a preferred method. Baking also allows for creating textures of complex objects while using only a simplified geometry for the real- time application.
Figure 4.18 An example of a model using a baked texture
4.2.5.4 Multiple levels of detail

When an object is close to the viewpoint, it is possible to see its details, so more precision in the geometry and texture is necessary. When it is far from the viewpoint, such details are not necessary. Here, close and far can be defined as the angle of the field of view that is covered by the object on the screen (view angle). Objects close to the viewpoint have a larger view angle than far ones. If an object is modeled in multiple levels of details (LOD) as shown in Figure 4.19, it is possible to switch from one level to another when the distance of the object changes. Using a lower level of detail permits drawing more objects in the scene while keeping the load of GPU in an acceptable range. It is essential to notice that as the distance from the viewpoint increases, potentially more objects become visible in the scene. So not using different levels of details efficiently may force the user to reduce the maximum viewing distance during the simulation.HighFigure 4.19 LOD conceptual diagram
Figure 4.19 LOD conceptual diagram

Multiple LODs are very useful. However, their challenging aspects are (1) modeling all the level of details may be time- consuming depending on the tools and (2) during simulation, the driver should not be able to notice the switch from one level to another; otherwise, it could become a distraction.

Figure 4.20 shows the relationship between LOD differences and the distance with the model. When close to the model, it is possible to see the differences between the level of details; switching levels at that distance would be wrong. On the right, levels of details are not distinguishable, so the lower level of details can be used without impacting the visual simulation.
Figure 4.20 Relation between multiple levels of details and distance from the viewpoint
4.2.6 Particle systems: rain, snow, and smokes

We often draw elements such as flames, smoke, rain, and snow using particle systems in computer graphics. In a particle system, each particle follows its movement and is rendered as one element. All particles of one system follow some rules and are rendered similarly. Particles often have an initial state partially randomized, then evolve during a given lifetime. A particle can have multiple attributes that store its current status and modified each time the particle is updated. These attributes are also used when rendering the particle. Even if all particles follow the same basic rules, because the generation parameters and the environment in which they evolve differs, it is possible to simulate and visualize complex phenomena.

In terms of rendering, particles can be simple points, use a sprite or some simple geometry. Rain and snow are a typical use of particle systems in simulators. For special scenarios involving accidents or extreme weather conditions, fire, fumes, or concentration of fog reducing visibility, it is relatively straightforward to simulate them with particles (Figure 4.21). In that case, particles are often rendered as sprites with some transparency. We previously explained that semi- transparent polygons should be rendered with some sorting algorithm. For smoke, it is possible to simplify the algorithm to use a large amount of particle without lowering the rendering time. As long as a unique color is used for the sprites, it is not a problem to draw them in a random order as the final blended color stays the same. However, the problem persists if they must be mixed with other transparent objects such as windows.
Figure 4.21 Flare and fumes (Image from VR-Design Studio)

Because systems use many particles (few hundred to several hundred of thousands as shown in Figure 4.22), the movements of the particles should be reduced to model with minimum calculations. Usually, particles do not interact with each other, or if they do, it is often possible to use the previous state of the particle, so calculations are not order dependent. That means the process is highly parallelizable and that calculation can occur on the GPU instead of the CPU to benefit from the parallel architecture of the GPU.
Figure 4.22 Simulation accident in a tunnel, used for road safety and simulation for tunnel incident management (Image from VR-Design Studio)
4.2.7 Water on road surface and windshield

There are several ways of generating reflection of the scene in reflecting objects. Ray- tracing allows for creating a reflection of any object in any shape. The latest generation of GPUs provides real- time ray- tracing pipelines, but the rendering time is still slower and perfect reflections may not be necessary for driving simulation. Without ray- tracing, it is possible to represent an accurate reflection on flat surfaces by rendering the reflected image in a temporary buffer, then use that buffer as a texture mapped on the reflecting surface. With some adaptation, this technique is also applicable for almost flat surfaces such as a road surface, water, or slightly curved mirrors.

For complex shapes, such as the vehicle body, the reflection of the surroundings is usually made with an environment map. However, the environment map must be generated from a point relatively close to the reflecting object if we want to represent reflections of objects that are close to it. It means that a map must be generated for each vehicle of the scene. It is not realistic for real- time applications; therefore, we use

environment maps only for the reflection of far objects. Screen space reflection is another method for reflection on any object. This technique looks for each reflecting surface in which parts of the already rendered scene reflects. If the reflected object is found, it can be shown on the reflecting surface. If not, a default color or the reflection of a static environment map is used instead.

Here, we explain in more detail the principle of a perfect mirror reflection applied on the road surface to reproduce the road conditions in rainy weather. To simplify the reflection calculation, we consider the road surface as a constant gradient plane, as shown in Figure 4.23.
Figure 4.23 Mirror image of a reflection

In this case, the reflected image appears at a symmetrical position relative to the road surface. A mirror view of the scene is calculated by rendering from the mirrored viewpoint by applying global space transformation to the scene. Once the reflected image is saved to a frame buffer, we use it to calculate the color of the reflecting surface (Figure 4.24). In the case of water, the surface is not perfectly flat but presents waves. Instead of using a simple linear mapping of the mirrored image, we calculate a reflection vector for each pixel of the water surface, from which the corresponding reflected fragment of the frame buffer can be determined. We calculate the reflection vector by looking at the normal of the surface at the reflection point. In the case of water, we can generate the normal value from standard wave generation equations.

From the vector, the reflected fragment of the frame buffer is calculated. We could observe that because we are now dealing with reflections in arbitrary directions, we fall in the same problem as screen space reflections where it is possible not to find the correct reflected fragment. However, we assumed the surface to be almost flat, and we can control the maximum deflection of the reflected vector compared to a perfectly flat surface. In the worst- case scenario, we can still clamp the reflection angle, so we are sure to find a reflected color.
Figure 4.24 Reflection of the environment on the road surface

A similar method can be used to simulate water on the windshield of the vehicle (Figure 4.25). But in that case, instead of rendering a mirrored scene into a separated frame buffer, we can simply use the main frame buffer data. The idea is to re- render each pixel of the screen once. This time a refraction vector is calculated instead of a reflection vector. The light coming from outside the vehicle is indeed passing through a layer of water that has nonparallel air- water and water- glass interfaces. Due to refraction, we see a distorted image from inside the vehicle. We can assume that from the windshield, most of the arriving light, even with refraction, mainly comes from the scene already rendered before distortion.
Figure 4.25 Water refraction noise on the windshield

From the refraction vector, generated at each pixel of the screen, we then choose what fragment to display from the pre- rendered frame buffer. Depending on how realistically the refraction vector is calculated, this technique can provide very good results when the experiment, for instance, requires to simulate reduced visibility in rainy scenarios. Compared to a reflection, the processing is quite fast since it only requires recalculating the color of each pixel of the screen. We can also simulate the reflection of light sources on the water layer, providing an even more realistic rainy scene at night where many street lights and vehicle headlights hit the windshield of the vehicle.

Finally, the simulation of wipers is necessary for driving simulators. An implementation of the wipers' movement allows updating the refraction map locally, so the light arrives directly where the glass has been just wiped (Figure 4.26).
Figure 4.26 Wiper effect
4.3 Shading

According to Wikipedia, "Shading refers to the depiction of depth perception in 3D models (within the field of 3D computer graphics) or illustrations (in visual art) by varying the level of darkness. Shading tries to approximate local behavior of light on the object's surface and is not to be confused with techniques of adding shadows, such as shadow mapping or shadow volumes, which fall under global behavior of light." This explanation makes perfect sense because what shading makes in computer graphics is what a painter does by darkening the edges of an object on a painting to create some depth effect while being only painted on a 2D canvas.

In computer graphics, the amount of light - or absence of darkness - - is often evaluated through the use of two components: the diffuse and the specular components. These two components form the base of the Phong
illumination model (Bui Tuong Phong, University of Utah, 1975) represented in Figure 4.27.
Figure 4.27 The Phong illumination model. Nowadays, ambient is barely used and can be ignored.

The diffuse component uses the light direction and the surface normal to calculate how much a surface is illuminated. When the surface faces the light, those two vectors are collinear, resulting in the brightest representation.

The specular component evaluates the amount of reflection from the light to the camera. If a ray of light bounces on a surface and is redirected directly to the camera, this part of the surface becomes very bright. As would the corners of a car under the sun, for example.

A third component, known as ambient, describes the color an object would have in complete darkness, which is, by essence, a representation error as in complete darkness, any non- self- emitting material should be black. This component has been used in the past because it does not require computation. With modern hardware and using physically based rendering techniques, the use of this component has been abandoned.
4.3.1 Rendering of light sources

Several light sources lit any 3D scene representing a real environment. Unless under complete darkness, the most important source of light for any realistic scene is by far the sun and sky. In broad daylight, it is the only source of light. It is why ensuring a good representation of the sky, as explained in Section 2.2.1 is very important for a modern simulator. Once the sky colors have been computed (not only the visible areas but in all directions), it is possible to use these colors to perform the light

calculation on the object of the scene. We call this method global illumination because the source of light is not only the direct light of the sun; it includes indirect illumination from the surroundings of an object.

Figure 4.28 is a good example of global illumination. In this scene, the sun is apparently the only source of illumination. The whole right of the car is more illuminated than other sides because the surface normal is oriented towards the sun (diffuse component). The right doors of the car are brightly highlighted because the surface orientation makes the light emitted by the sun being reflected directly at the camera (specular component). However, this does not explain the front of the car, which is visible while being oriented oppositely to the sun (using only direct lightning; this part would be completely black). With global illumination, any object is illuminated from the surroundings. In this particular case, the sky in front of the car (and behind the viewpoint) illuminates the front of the car. That part of the sky is probably darker than areas next to the sun, resulting in a darker illumination. We want to clarify the fact that global illumination does not modify the Phong illumination model in any way as the calculations of the diffuse and specular components do not change. Still, the light is like a sphere surrounding objects and not a single point, resulting in, as can be seen in Figure 4.28, very realistic representations of objects.
Figure 4.28 Screen capture of a car under the sunset

While global illumination is, in many cases (especially during daylight), the most significant contribution to the illumination of objects, discrete light sources are still needed to represent a wide range of 3D scenes accurately. Discrete light sources include any human- made light (streetlights, headlights, the various lights found in rooms, and any other light source). Most discrete light sources are positioned at a precise point within the scene, and light attenuation has only an effect on surrounding objects. Many types of discrete lights can be implemented depending on the light shape and direction. The following are a few common examples.

Point lights (Figure 4.29) are often used in computer graphics, as they can mimic the effect of most simple light emitters like bulbs. Point lights are positioned at a particular point in space and emit light in all directions.
Figure 4.29 A point light

Spotlights (Figure 4.30) are also often used in computer graphics and especially simulators as they can be used to effectively represent a light that is emitted from a point with a specific direction (like car headlights, for example). Besides the origin and direction, it is usually possible to define the angle of the spot.
Figure 4.30 A spotlight

Directional lights (Figure 4.31) are used for large and distant objects, like the sun or the moon, where it is visually safe to assume that the light is emitted in a constant direction. A point or spotlight could be used for such distant objects, but calculating those is slower and does not result in any improvement of the rendered scene. Directional lights are approximation made to increase rendering performance.
Figure 4.31 A directional light

An area light (Figure 4.32) represents a light that is emitted from a surface in a specific direction, like LED arrays and displays. It can also be used as an alternative to neon lighting arrays, on office ceilings, for example. These usually are way more complex to process and can result in lowered performance, but are sometimes required to represent a 3D scene accurately.
Figure 4.32 Area lights
4.3.2 Physically based rendering

As briefly explained previously, modern 3D rendering should be performed using a physically based approach, which requires knowing the physical properties of materials and how to implement shading models for each material type. The reason behind the need for separate shading models for each material type is that most of these shading models employ the use of a bidirectional reflectance distribution function (BRDF), which is a function that defines how light is reflected on a given material type. Essentially most metallic materials reflect the light in the same way, so the same BRDF is used. On the other hand, glass reflects light very differently, so the same BRDF is probably not adequate, and

therefore, a different shading model is required. Many BRDFs have been researched over the years, and some can be implemented well enough to match the requirements of real- time rendering. For example, an inexpensive BRDF model for physically based rendering was developed by Christophe Schlick at the University of Bordeaux.

One of the very famous shading models for physically based rendering is the metallic- roughness model. This model describes materials with only three parameters: the metal content of the material ranging from
to
, the roughness (the inverse of the smoothness) also ranging from
(mirror polished, so highly reflective) to

(very rough, almost no reflections), and the material base color. These parameters can be provided as textures to have nonuniform materials. For example, a new car is well polished, and roughness might be close to 0. After some years, some areas might be more worn out than others, effectively becoming rougher: it is easy using a texture to adjust the roughness of the material in certain areas only. Figure 4.33 shows a vehicle rendered using a metallic- roughness model where we can see the left side of the car (on the right in the image) with a brighter reflection than the front of the car. The resulting image in Figure 4.33 accurately reproduces the fact that the light coming from the environment from the right of the viewpoint is brighter than the light coming from behind the viewpoint.
Figure 4.33 The metallic roughness model implemented on a car model

As a final note, physically based rendering makes sense when lighting is performed accurately because shading models only calculate the amount and color of reflected light. In particular, physically based rendering is almost useless without global illumination.
4.3.3 Material layering

In the real world, the surface of an object is rarely made of a single material. For example, the surface of a car is a combination of the metal paint itself, the wax applied over it, and any dust or dirt that is sticking to it. In such a case, we can apply multimaterial rendering techniques, also called material layering. In that case, each material of the surface is rendered, then the results are combined using coefficients in the final color. These coefficients are usually provided by textures so that they can vary over the surface. In our example, the bottom parts of the car are likely to collect more dust. The dust coefficient would be higher at those locations.

This technique, while being resource- intensive, because several materials are rendered, is to this day the best way to achieve photorealistic renderings. Many optimizations can be applied to make material layering affordable. For example, for distant objects, it is possible to render the dominant material only.
4.3.4 Color range and tone mapping

To understand the color range and tone mapping, we shall start by considering how humans see. The retina is composed of two types of photoreceptors: cones and rods. The cones provide color sensitivity while the rods provide mostly light sensitivity. There are about twenty times more rods than cones, which is why the human eye is far more sensitive to light than color: in darkness, everything turns gray, and while we can look almost directly at a light source when we do so colors seem to fade too.

On the other hand, the output image of a simulator is either projected on a screen or displayed using LED or TFT displays. Without going into historical reasons, any of these devices are composed of red, green, and blue triplets that form a single pixel. Each of those dots can only be lit up to a specific level (measured in lits for displays and lumens for projectors). Therefore, the simulator software calculates the bounded amount of red, green, and blue for each pixel of the scene (usually the bounds are from 0 to 255).

Since the final output is bound, image renderers used to limit the intensity of light sources to these bounds and perform all their calculations within them. We call it the standard dynamic range or SDR, but this is not physically correct because, in reality, the light intensity is not bounded, and SDR clamps the light calculations at each step.

As for the first issue of the intensity of light, let us consider the various headlight technologies presented in Table 4.1. Traditional halogen headlights are far less powerful than modern LED headlights. Yet, in the future, some other types of LEDs (or completely new technology) could be used to produce even higher light intensity. For reference, the brightest video projectors today can reach several tens of thousands of lumens. Because simulation software should support any type of light, including lights that do not yet exist, it does not make sense to describe lights with a bounded value.

The second issue with bounding light parameters is that there are usually many successive calculations that are made to determine the resulting color of a single pixel. For example, anyone can be easily blinded by some headlight reflecting into a side or room mirror. Because the light gets concentrated at that point, it effectively raises the light intensity at this particular position. If light calculations were bounded to the output capacities of the display equipment, we could not accurately represent this effect.

The process of bounding neither light source intensities nor successive calculation results is called high dynamic range (or HDR) rendering. HDR rendering ensures that light is simulated accurately. But since inputs and intermediary calculations are unbounded, the question becomes: how to "fit" the result within the bounds that the display equipment can accept? We use tone mapping to solve that issue. Concretely we use a curve to define, for an unbounded input, a corresponding bounded value. There have been many kinds of research conducted on the subject of tone mapping, and many algorithms have been extensively used by games and movies (Reinhard, ACES, etc.). One thing to remember about tone mapping is that there is no "best" or "most accurate" tone mapping. The process of tone mapping is inherently subjective. It should be adjusted to particular display equipment and purpose. For instance, some movies tend to be very dark while games aimed at kids are brighter and have vivid colors. The following figures (Figures 4.34- 4.37) present a few examples of the same scene being
rendered using various tone mapping techniques (all images are from https://64. github.io/tonemapping/).
Figure 4.34 No tone mapping: colors are clamped to the bounds of the display equipment. Pixels exceeding the upper range are entirely white on the ceiling and windows.
Figure 4.35 Reinhard tone mapping: less highlight saturation on the glass ceiling
Figure 4.36 Reinhard-Jodie: limits highlight saturation even more while providing more vivid colors
Figure 4.37 ACES tone mapping: created by and for the movie industry, it provides more contrast and generally a more dramatic effect
4.3.5 Data and processing flow

Figure 4.38 shows the OpenGL rendering pipeline. At the beginning of the process, the vertex data (including the vertex position, normal, and other attributes) is stored into the GPU memory (generally only once for each 3D shape) then pulled each rendered frame. The vertex shader uses vertex data to calculate the final position and normal of the vertex. The camera's view matrix and projection matrix serve to transform the vertex position into viewpoint coordinates and screen space coordinates. The shader can also use vertex attributes in other calculations for which results go to the next step of the pipeline.
The blue and gray parts can be customized with shader programs.
Gray parts are not mandatory to render a scene.
Figure 4.38 OpenGL rendering pipeline

In the tessellation and geometry shaders, it is possible to split the lines and face primitives to make a finer mesh and increase the precision of the shape of the object or the accuracy of the light calculation that occurs in the next steps.

After that, the GPU performs the rasterization, so the fragment shader can perform for each fragment (that are in most case pixels seen on the screen), mainly the color and illumination calculations. Finally, the per- fragment operation makes processing, such as the depth test and color blending.

At the end of the fragment processing, a pixel color is determined and must be stored in a buffer. Only when the whole scene and all polygons have been rendered, the buffer is outputted to the screen so that the newly rendered image appears instantly and not progressively, polygon after polygon.

Data transfer from the CPU to the GPU is a bottleneck, so to improve the performance, it is crucial to reduce the frequency at which data transfers, and if possible, to reduce the amount of data sent for each frame. If the program transferred all the vertex data for each frame, the rendering time of one frame would be too long as most of the time would be spent only to pass data to the GPU. Even if the amount of data is not large, transferring small pieces of data at high frequency would make the system prone to stuttering or micro freezes, which is a problem in simulators.

It is also necessary to reduce the amount of data stored on the GPU as much as possible. For example, if you want to send color data for each vertex where the original color format uses only 8bits per color, it is better not to convert it to single- precision float numbers. In addition to the time necessary to transfer the data mentioned earlier, when the amount of data exceeds the capacity of the GPU memory, a part of the data goes to the main memory. From this point, swapping of data between the two types of memories frequently occurs, resulting in poor rendering times, not acceptable for driving simulators.
4.3.6 Multitarget rendering

To understand multitarget rendering, we need to explain how graphics hardware functions. As explained in Section 2.3.5, each pixel color is calculated in the shaders and then outputted to the screen through a buffer. The first GPU architectures had buffers linked to the display

output itself, so those could only be used as a final presentation medium. Later on, those buffers became only memory blocks on the GPU, which means that they are not necessarily meant to be displayed on the screen, and it is possible to create multiple buffers. Therefore, any type of data can be rendered to these buffers (not only the visible colors of the scene), and a single rendering pass can store various data about the scene in separate buffers.

One typical use of this scheme is to store the depth of the scene in a separate buffer. Other uses could be to store the real 3D position of each pixel, the normal of the surface, or the type of object that is being rendered. There are absolutely no limits to what can be stored in buffers besides the amount of GPU memory.

Figure 4.39 shows example of multi target rendering where in addition to the visible color, the depth, height and surface normal vector are saved to additional buffers and represented in red/green/blue values in the image for visualization purpose.
Figure 4.39 Multitarget rendering

When considering the simulation of autonomous vehicles, multitarget rendering can be truly useful. Most autonomous vehicles have several cameras recording their surroundings, then perform calculations to

classify the captured images (e.g., to detect other cars, pedestrians, road markings, traffic signals). Once the images have been classified (segmented), the decision- making algorithm can be run, and the car acceleration, steering angle, as well as other parameters can be adjusted.

While both image classification and decision making are necessary to develop autonomous driving, working on both at the same time can be error- prone and time- consuming. Using multitarget rendering in a driving simulator, we can render the scene to display it to the user, and the segmented scene (Figure 4.40) that we feed the decision- making algorithm simultaneously at almost no performance cost. It allows researchers and engineers to focus on the image classification and the decision- making algorithms separately, making the whole process straightforward, less error- prone, and more cost- effective.

Figure 4.40 A scene rendered in a single pass in VR-Design Studio v14 can output both colors to be displayed on the screen and a classified image that could be fed to an autonomous driving decision algorithm
4.4 Hardware
4.4.1 Rendering hardware architecture
4.4.1.1 Role of the GPU and CPU

The GPU is dedicated to graphics and has graphics- specific features. Mostly, it is specialized for vector and matrix calculations in parallel. Recently, the use of parallel computing capabilities other than for graphics has also advanced, such as artificial intelligence and numerical computing. Due to the characteristics of the hardware, some processes are considered unsuitable for GPUs, such as conditional branching. For nonintegrated GPUs, the GPU and CPU communicate through a high- speed Peripheral Component Interconnect Express (PCIe) connection. Although, even if fast, that data communication can be a bottleneck in some situations described later in this chapter.
Because of its nature, GPU's primary use in a simulator is to calculate the graphics of the scene. In contrast, the CPU calculates the logical behavior of the simulation.
4.4.1.2 A simple comparison between existing GPU solutions

There are two primary types of GPUs: those integrated with the CPU and independent GPUs installed separately. Intel with the Intel HD Graphics product and AMD with the Ryzen product both provide integrated GPUs. In integrated solutions, the CPU and GPU share the same memory, which can lower the performances. The GPU is also less performant than what stand- alone GPUs can deliver. We would not recommend using an integrated solution for research simulators now. However, integrated solutions saw a fast improvement in performance in the past few years, so the previous statement may not be accurate in the future. NVIDIA and AMD both make consumer and professional solutions for GPUs, and both are very high- performance products. spans.content: One of the significant differences between consumer and professional products is that professional products can perform double- precision operations and synchronize frame update timing among several connected computers. Today, consumer and professional products use the same architecture to lower the production and design costs, so consumer products can be used if you do not need double precision or frame synchronization.

Frame synchronization is necessary when several computers together display active stereo vision graphics. With active stereo vision, the images for the left and right eyes must be perfectly synchronized on all screens. Another consideration is that, in their design, some software solutions may use the synchronization feature. It is a point to check with the solution provider when using several computers.

Finally, NVIDIA and AMD both sell high- end, middle- end, and low- end products for consumer and professional GPUs. In some scenarios, low- end GPUs can be enough. Still, the system would be limited in the amount of complexity of the scene, and mostly not usable if you think about using stereoscopic vision. It is also essential to consider that GPUs with less memory have to rely more on the computer's main memory and data transfer between the CPU and GPU. As explained earlier, this would result in stuttering in the image flow. This effect can negatively impact the driver and the result of the experiment or training. Considering these points, we would recommend choosing high- end or near high- end products for serious simulators.
4.4.1.3 Double-precision versus single-precision floats with GPUs

About double- precision operations, the conclusion would be to not rely on it for driving simulators. The first reason is that if the software relies on double precision, it cannot provide acceptable performances with consumer products, which reduces the choice of hardware for the end- user. The other reason is that for driving simulation, double precision is not useful in the whole rendering pipeline and using double precision in the GPU can be avoided.
A double precision offers a tremendous resolution, even for extralarge areas where single precision starts having a problem when the virtual space goes over
10\mathrm{km}

However, we can solve the problem with single precision even for vast spaces, considering that GPUs render objects relative to the viewpoint. Most objects in the scene have a radius much smaller than the distance where single- precision values start having problems. So the 3D mesh of each independent object can be stored with enough accuracy. For instance, objects which dimensions are under
100\mathrm{m}
have an accuracy of
10\mathrm{mm}
, which is enough for cockpit design purposes.
On the other hand, the position of the object can be well above
10\mathrm{km}
away from the origin

. Now let us consider that the position of the object and the viewpoint are both stored as single- precision values. The result of using these values to calculate the relative position of the object to the eye position might not be precise enough. When both coordinates are higher than
10\mathrm{km}
, the relative value is also accurate to the centimeter. If there is movement, the result fluctuates and gives a very uncomfortable shaking effect of the objects to the driver.

In that situation, what saves us is the fact that the position of the object and viewpoint be of double precision on the CPU side. We can also calculate their relative value on the CPU. The result is that all objects near the eye have excellent accuracy. The 3D objects far from the viewpoint do not benefit of high precision, but it is not anymore a problem as objects
10\mathrm{km}
away (when displayed) do not suffer from a 1 or
10\mathrm{cm}

error in their position. The only remaining problem is for very long or large objects like the roads or the terrain. But they can easily be split in smaller objects, which they already are in most cases to improve the rendering performance.

A final comment would be that double- precision support of the professional versions of the GPUs offer higher calculation performances in double precision but still less performance than single precision.

4.4.2 Synchronization over multiple displays

Many simulators require more than one display to cover the entire area of the field of view. We saw in Chapter 3 that TV monitors or projectors are used most of the time as display hardware. Let us now see why and how to synchronize the image generation over multiple monitors or projectors.

What happens when several displays are not in synch is similar to the screen tearing artifact on one screen, when vertical synchronization is not activated. It is because in a multidisplay system, without synchronization, one device could be displaying a content one frame older than the others. If tearing is noticeable by the driver, this becomes a distraction or even a hindrance to the experiment. It also means that display channels have different latency properties, which may not be acceptable either. Finally, in an active stereo system, all left- eye images and right- eye images must be displayed simultaneously over all the
devices; otherwise, the stereo parallax would be reversed in some displays.

In the image generation flow, there are two points where synchronization is necessary. One occurs at a hardware level and the other is in the software. The first one is to ensure that all image buffers are sent from the computers, at precisely the same time, to all the display devices. As we saw in the GPU hardware descriptions, only professional solutions provide such feature. It is necessary when active stereo display is one requirement of the system. It is also necessary to reduce tearing artifacts and inconsistent delays among display devices. However, these last two problems cannot be solved only at a hardware level. The image generation software must also ensure that all images sent to the GPU correspond to the same timestamp of the simulation. Synchronization is essentially a problem when we use multiple computers to generate the images, so let us study the solution for synchronization between several computers.

Figures 4.41 and 4.42 represent the sequence of messages for a system with one central computer and two slave computers that render the image. The center computer calculates the content of the simulation and sends it every frame to the IG (image generators) computers (Message Nb. 1). The IGs then render the content of the image according to the latest simulation data and then send the image buffer to the display hardware (Message Nb. 5). For synchronization, the timing at which the image buffer is sent to the display hardware and the simulation data used to generate the images must be the same. That is why some synchronization control is necessary.
Figure 4.41 Hardware and software synchronization flow for multiple displays
Figure 4.42 Hardware only synchronization flow for multiple displays

Message 4 is coming from a signal generator and is sent at the same time to all IGs. The IGs use that signal to trigger message 5, which sends the data to all the display hardware. This process is made in the GPU, and only professional editions provide input for the synchronization signal. This synchronization process solves the first problem of sending all images buffer at the same time so that the display devices can show the image at the same timing.

However, all IGs may not have the same rendering process duration, and some may finish later than others. In that case, how to ensure that all the image buffers represent the same instant of the simulation? For this, we use a software frame synchronization or frame lock mechanism. Figure 4.41 shows that process with messages 2 and 3. Message 2 indicates to the central PC when all IGs have finished rendering their part of the scene. After sending message 2, IGs wait for message 3 before asking the GPU to send the image to the display hardware. In the proposed sequence, message 3 is sent by the central computer after receiving all the messages 2 from the IGs. This method ensures that all IGs send the same simulation content to the screens.

If we look in detail at the sequence, we notice that because messages are sent to several machines at the same time, the time of the reception of the message can be slightly different between computers. Because messages 3 and 4 come from different sources, message 3 may arrive after message 4 for some machines. These machines would then send the image buffer one frame later than the others. We could solve that issue by adding more control in the synchronization. However, more control requires more messages or higher thresholds, which reduce the available time for rendering the scene. In a driving simulator, we want to achieve a stable and high frame rate, so it is preferable to prioritize the time available to render the scene. If we put enough attention on the creation of the 3D scene at the same time, it is possible to generate images at a
high frame rate with reliable rendering time. In that situation, the frame lock mechanism is not necessary and can be turned off to provide more time to the rendering process (Figure 4.42).

Above is a theoretical description of the synchronization for multiscreen or projector systems. In practice, we must address other items. The data is sent over some kind of network (most often Ethernet) between computers, so any congestion on the network can profoundly affect the performances of the system, add delay or different response time between computers. So it is imperative to ensure the local network is stable and performant. The connection between the computers and the display hardware is another area that can impact the system. In large simulators, there is often a long distance between the computers and the display devices. The amount of data that must be sent does not allow for long HDMI or Display port cables, and some sort of signal amplification or conversion to a more stable medium such as LAN cables or optic fibers is necessary. This type of connection adds more intermediate devices on the link, which then becomes more prone to connection problems. Selecting suitable quality devices and cables, plus ensuring the installation is clean and not affected by electromagnetic fields generated by power cables, for instance, is important.
4.4.3 Synchronization of driver's eye with VR viewpoint
When the user's head moves significantly, it becomes essential to also track the movement of the head and correct the position of the virtual camera (virtual viewpoint) accordingly.
Such needs arise in systems with a large field of view, like CAVE systems or when the screen is close to the driver's viewpoint.

With the ability to track the position and orientation of the user's head, the user can examine an object in the virtual environment from different angles, which might be useful when an object that is partially or fully occluded by another one.
Also, in a driving simulator, the position of the eyes allows adjusting the view to display in the virtual rear mirror.
Besides eye tracker devices, the estimation of the eyes position can be achieved by wearing a head tracker, usually offering a 6DOF tracking (position and orientation).
The most popular technologies are electromagnetic and optical.

- For electromagnetic trackers, electromagnetic sources with a fixed position create an electromagnetic field, while sensors (attached to the head or skeleton joints) track the changes of the electromagnetic field during motion. The analysis of the data recorded with the sensor provides a full 6DOF of the sensor motion.

- For optical trackers, active markers (emitting light) or passive ones (reflecting the light from an external source) are attached to the head or joints to track. Passive markers are usually small spheres recovered with glass powder to reflect the external light source. The markers are attached to some glasses that the user wears.
The tracking is achieved by one or several cameras recording the movement of the markers.
By using at least three markers, it is possible to track the position and the orientation of the head and, thus, the position of the eyes.
Using several cameras decreases the chances of marker occlusion or false readings.

5.1 Introduction

When analyzing driver behavior using simple driving simulator (DS), advanced DS, and full- scale DS such as those at the University of Leeds, it is necessary to understand how to detect the driver's line of sight, handle the driver's response time, measure brain waves and cerebral blood flow, understand the driver's condition by heart rate (HR), estimate the driver's condition from driving performance, analyze steering operation, understand simulator sickness, reliability of DS, advanced driver assistance system (ADAS) evaluation method, automatic driving evaluation method, etc. This chapter explains these issues.

In Section 5.2, we introduce the system that detects the viewpoint of the driver used for the evaluation of human- machine interface (HMI). There are two types of eye monitoring systems, contact type and non-
contact type, and the functions of each are introduced. We also introduce an example used in a DS experiment.

Section 5.3 describes how to handle one of the most important response times in analyzing the driver behavior of DS. The response time is the time from the presentation of the stimulus to the driver until the response. It is necessary to understand the response time because the appearance of the reaction time varies depending on the way of stimulation.

Since the state of the driver driving the DS affects the physiological state of the driver, it is possible to grasp the driver state objectively and quantitatively by observing the physiological state. Frequently used for this observation are electroencephalograms, cerebral blood flow meters, and HR meters. In Section 5.4, we introduce brain wave detection and the details include (1) Electrode Configuration, (2) Electrode, and (3) Measurement Method; also, we introduce methods for measuring brain waves in experiments and (4) Data Processing is used to measure them in DS experiments.

Section 5.5 describes near- infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) as a cerebral blood flow meter. NIRS does not directly observe the activity of the brain, but it observes the situation of the change by the oxygen consumption of cerebral blood flow. This is because cerebral blood flow changes when the brain is activated and consumes oxygen due to a change in the state of the driver. In addition to the principles of NIRS, here are some examples of studies using NIRS.

As a biological system which shows the driver condition, the heartbeat is the representative one which shows the autonomic nervous system. When HR is used as an index, sleepiness, surprise/near- miss, tension/excitement, attention concentration, malaise, etc. can be recognized. Section 5.6 describes the heartbeat.

The state of the driver can be estimated from the driving performance of the driver without using the physiological measurement. Section 5.7 explains the meaning of distance between vehicles and the position of the vehicle in a lane as an evaluation of driving performance. Since steering operation clearly indicates the state of the driver, Section 5.8 introduces a steering entropy (SE) method that can quantitatively analyze steering operation.
Section 5.9 explains the topic of simulator sickness that is required for DS. And in the next section, Section 5.10, the importance of changing

the way of thinking about the trust evaluation of the DS and the design concept of the DS required to obtain exceptionally reliable experimental results are explained. Next, the knowledge about the perceptual characteristics of human beings, which is considered to be useful for realizing this design concept, is introduced, and the usage method is described individually.

Section 5.11 describes the ADAS evaluation points that can be evaluated using DS. Section 5.12 also explains the evaluation items in automated driving, explains the issues of automated driving, and introduces the expected use of DS in the future.
5.2 Gaze detection
5.2.1 Introduction of gaze detection

In DS experiments, it is necessary to clarify how a driver obtains information from the traffic environment while driving a motor vehicle, in order to reveal the characteristics of the driver's driving operation. It is an element for the evaluation of the HMI to investigate how much the information from the driving support system and the automatic driving system contributes to the safe driving of the driver. Various methods are used for the HMI evaluation, and this chapter focuses on a driver's gaze.

The information that the driver obtains from the vision while driving is surely very important, and devices for measuring the position of a human viewpoint are provided by manufacturers. These devices are roughly classified into two types: contact- type devices worn by experiment participants and non- contact- type devices detecting the viewpoint by using a camera installed. The contact types worn by experiment participants include wearing glasses or hats.

The human eye movement measurement has a long history. A paper published in the 1800s employed the method that directly observed corneal movements. In the 1970s, devices using cameras like the current ones, were developed. Initially, small- sized charge- coupled device (CCD) cameras had not been put into practical use, so the devices had been large in size and been utilized as non- contact- type ones.
When small- sized CCD cameras were developed, contact- type devices worn by experiment participants have also come to be developed. The devices enabled the measurement of various types of eye

movements, such as gaze direction, nystagmus, saccade, rotation, and convergence. The measurement of driver's eye movements was reported from the results in an experiment using the contact- type device and a DS.
5.2.2 Measurement method

There are three methods suggested to measure human- eye movements; (1) The electro- oculography method that measures changes in muscle potential along with eye movements. (2) The intense- film- reflection method that measures eye movements using the difference, which occurs in reflected lights between cornea (black eye) and sclera (white eye) using infrared light. (3) The corneal reflection method that measures eye movements using the reflection image that occurs when the light source irradiates the cornea [1].

Currently, the most frequently used method is the corneal reflection method, where the measurement is conducted based on the reflected image from the cornea, using an LED that generates the near- infrared light. In the corneal reflection method, the near- infrared light is directly radiated to the eyes of experiment participants, so the safety standard (EN 62471) has been established for ensuring the safety of products using LED light. When devices with LED light are used in experiments, it is necessary to confirm that they comply with the safety standard (EN 62471).
5.2.2.1 Contact type

The eye movement measurement device of the contact type is a type in which experiment participants wear the device to measure it, as described above. Various types of devices, such as an eyeglass or a hat, are currently developed. The basic mechanisms of the measurement are almost the same among them and are designed to irradiate near- infrared LED light to the eyeball and then capture the reflected light with a small camera.

The contact- type device (Figure 5.1) is also equipped with a small camera for capturing the scenery in front of the wearer. Researchers can easily confirm where the experiment participants are looking by using video data taking the front view overwritten by the measured data. Figure 5.2 shows the sample of gaze measurement in the head- up display using the contact- type device.

5.2.2.2 Non-contact type

The eye movement measurement device of the non- contact type (Figure 5.3) is a type of the measurement by a small camera and near- infrared LED light installed in front of the experiment participants. Compared with the contact type, it has an advantage that the eye movements of experiment participants can be measured without wearing the device. However, the small camera for measurement is installed at a fixed
position, so many cameras and LED lights are needed in order to detect the gaze of the experiment participants over a wide area.
Figure 5.3 Eye gaze measurement (non-contact)

In the non- contact type, all the cameras measuring eye movements are fixed, and the coordinate data of the detected viewpoint does not change, even if the participant moves the body, such as shaking the head. On the other hand, in the case of the contact type, the coordinate data constantly changes because the device moves along with the behavior of the experiment participant.

The fixed coordinate data enables easy analyses, because the coordinates of the area of interest for analyzing the data obtained in the experiment can be limited. However, when the coordinate data is not fixed, the viewpoint position along with the video data may need to be checked.
The non- contact type also has further advantages. In the non- contact type, the video data can be overwritten by the data measured in the same
way as the contact type so that researchers can easily confirm where the experiment participants were looking.
5.2.3 Issues

This chapter describes the contact- type and non- contact- type issues in the corneal reflex method, which is currently most frequently used. The corneal reflection method is to measure eye movements from the reflected image of the cornea, using a light source such as an LED. For example, when an experiment participant has poor eyesight and regularly wears eyeglasses, the reflected image cannot be detected sometimes, because the light illuminating the cornea changes due to the characteristics of the eyeglass lens when irradiating LED light through glasses.

In experiments, there are many participants having poor eyesight. When the DS experiments are conducted by participants without eyeglasses regardless of poor eyesight, their behavior can be much different from their normal driving. There are some cases where the information of eye movement can be obtained from experiment participants and other cases where it cannot be done. In addition, when the experiment targets only on participants who are not low- visioned, it can be biased towards experiment participants.

Currently, with the advance in the software processing the measured data, the proportion of cases that can measure the data of experiment participants wearing eyeglasses has increased, but in some cases, the data cannot be obtained from them. Some contact- type devices allow users to attach prescription lenses on spectacle- type devices. Participants who need to correct their vision can wear glasses with prescription lenses as necessary.

The non- contact type has an advantage of data analysis because the position coordinates can be fixed, as described above. But the effect of glasses of the experiment participants is adjusted by software. There may be some cases in which the data cannot be measured for some of the experiment participants.

There is no influence of sunlight in the DS experiment conducted indoors. However, in outdoor experiments, it may not be possible to measure the eye movements of drivers due to the influence of sunlight.
When the devices are used outdoors, the effect of sunlight should also be considered.
5.3 Response time evaluation

This chapter explains important matters in analyzing the behavior of the driver using simple DS and advanced DS of this laboratory, and full- scale DS as in Leeds University. At first, the response time of the driver is measured.

In the analysis of the driver behavior of DS, the most important thing is the response time. The time from the presentation of the stimulus to the response is defined as the response time, and the stimulus is called the trigger signal. As a taskthat examines the response time, there are simple response tasks that look at the single response for the single stimulation and selection response task that chooses from multiple alternatives according to the content of the stimulation. As the number of stimuli and alternatives increases, the response time increases, and according to Hick's law, the response time is proportional to the logarithm of the number of alternatives

. This is the entropy of choice. The time from the trigger signal to the response is called trial, and the time between trials is called ITI (inter trial interval)time. When ITI is fixed, the subject predicts the next stimulation, so it is important to change it at random.

The response time is different, when the preparatory signal is given before the stimulus signal presentation. The response time becomes the shortest when the fore- period in Figure 5.4 is 500 ms from the preparatory signal to the stimulation, and the response time becomes long even if it is over or under. The response time is affected by the preparatory state of the subject, and the response time is shortened when the preparatory state can be made by the subject. And, since response time is also stabilized in this state, an experimental scenario to make a preparatory state is required.
Figure 5.4 Timing chart of selection response task

The response time is also different by the type of the sense. When compared in the representative sense type of visual sense, auditory sense, tactile sense, the response time becomes faster in the order of tactile sense, auditory sense, and visual sense. In the simple response task, the representative value of the auditory stimulation becomes
200~\mathrm{ms}
, and in the visual stimulation, it becomes
200 - 250~\mathrm{ms}

. The stronger the stimulus, the shorter the response time and the longer the noise added. In the response site, the arm is faster than the leg, and in the arm, the finger is faster than the arm. When a button is pressed and released, the release response is faster. The response of a pedal operation is faster when the pedal is released than when it is depressed. The response time also depends on the suitability of the stimulus and the response. For example, the response time is shorter when the right button is pressed with the right stimulus, and longer when the left button is pressed with the right stimulus. In the case of the selective response, the response time differs according to the appearance probability of the stimulation. The higher the frequency of appearance, the shorter the response time, and the lower the frequency, the longer the response time.

The response time has an ordering effect and is affected by previous trials. For example, when there are two alternatives, the same stimulus has a shorter response time and the opposite stimulus has a longer response time. However, the effect disappears, if the time between stimulation is lengthened. When the time between stimuli is short, the

repetitive effect is generated, and the accelerating effect for the response is produced. Therefore, an experimental design to eliminate the ordering effect is required. The response time also changes with the elapsed time of the experiment. The response time is short just after the start of the experiment and becomes almost constant afterwards, and the response time becomes longer as the experiment time becomes longer. However, the response time becomes shorter at the end of the experiment. The phenomenon by which the response time becomes short at the end of the experiment is called the termination effect. When the subjects know the end of the experiment, they concentrate on the task.

Response time is measured in milliseconds. Thus, stimuli that can be presented within 1 ms are used. The PC screen is often used for visual stimulation, and the display characteristics on the PC should be understood. For example, a refresh rate of
60\mathrm{Hz}
can cause a delay of 16 ms, which may be unsuitable for experimental purposes.

In stimulation by sound, the simple sound is not especially a problem. However, in the case of speech, the definition of the start time becomes difficult because the rise is slow. Similarly, the definition of response time is difficult when speech is a response. And for the finger or foot response, the selection response task requires a contrivance that equalizes the distance between each finger or foot and the selection button.

It should be noted that the response time is basically variable. In the simple response task, the same person under the same conditions does not repeatedly become constant. Since the response time is not constant, statistical analysis is required. However, since the response time does not become 0, the distribution becomes a form in which the root spreads in the larger value. That is to say, the statistical test assuming the normal distribution cannot be applied directly in many cases. The theoretical distribution of response time is ex- Gaussian in Figure 5.5 and inverse Gaussian in Figure 5.6. The inverse Gaussian function is given by (5.1). In Figure 5.6,

The ex- Gaussian distribution is a composite of a normal distribution and an exponential distribution. Considering the response time characteristics, the shape which gradually extends from zero to the larger rise value is simulated. The inverse Gaussian distribution is a distribution in which the moment generating function is the inverse function of the moment generating function of the Gaussian distribution. This is the distribution of the time required for the random walk process, and the response time is applied because the processing process in the brain is considered to be the random walk process [2].
Since response time data have an asymmetric distribution extending to the right, the

The decision whether the response is an error or not is clearly seen as a wrong selection in the selection response task. The anticipatory response and response delay are determined from the distribution of response time. If the response time is extremely short, it may be an anticipation error, and if it is long, it may be a response delay error. However, since the error judgment involves subjectivity, statistical processing is used to provide objectivity. A commonly used method is to regard the outside data of the mean value
\pm 2 \times

\pm 2 \times

\pm 2 \times
standard deviation, the test is terminated.

The regression method has a disadvantage that it keeps data extending to the right side because the response time distribution is asymmetric [3]. As a countermeasure to this, it is better to remove the
maximum value, calculate the mean value and standard deviation, then return the maximum value and apply the regression method [4].
5.4 Electroencephalograph - brain wave detection
5.4.1 Introduction of electroencephalograph - brain wave detection

It has been devised that the brain activity of a driver during driving is quantitatively captured and utilized actively. The brain activity generates weak electrical signals along with the activity, which are measured to clarify the features of the brain activity by analyzing its characteristics. Brain waves were discovered in 1929 by German psychiatrist and neurologist Hans Berger. Since then, the research and development of an electroencephalograph (EEG) have progressed. The EEG has been developed using vacuum tubes or transistors and microcomputers, and is mainly used as a medical device [5].

In the 1990s, the EEG was also increasingly digitized with the advancement of computer technology, recording vast amounts of data on computers and analyzing data for diagnosing diseases. On the other hand, for drivers who are driving motor vehicles, the EEG is used to evaluate the driver's arousal level during driving by using driving support systems to prevent drowsy driving and to evaluate the effect of the driving support systems for support of safe driving.

In recent years, brain- machine interface technology, which connects a brain and a machine directly or indirectly to read the brain information and to treat brain diseases, has received attention. These days, the research and development of automatic driving technology have been actively progressed, and the functions of automatic driving are expressed at five levels. For example, in level 3 of the autonomous driving systems, normal driving is performed by a vehicle, that is, by an autonomous driving system, but when a situation that cannot be handled by a vehicle occurs, the driver needs to take full control of the vehicle.

Therefore, a driver has to keep awake and constantly monitor the control of the vehicle in order to cope with such a situation. Research focusing on the transfer of driving control in autonomous driving

systems of level 3 has been conducted, considering the characteristics of driving operations affected by driver arousal and reaction time. In such research, brain waves are used as one of the methods to quantitatively measure the degree of drivers' awakening. The technology using brain waves is also attracting the attention in the process of the growing availability of future automatic driving systems.
5.4.2 Measurement method
5.4.2.1 Electrode configuration

When EEG measurement is performed, electrodes are placed on the scalp, from where the electrical signals are detected. The commonly used method that indicates the location applying the electrode is the International 10- 20 System (Ten- Twenty Electrode System).
