5.4.2.2 Electrode

There are two types of electrodes to be attached to the scalp. One type is an electrode that reduces the contact impedance between the skin and the electrode by using conductive paste to fix the electrode. The other type is an electrode that conducts measurement by contacting the electrode with the scalp without a conductive paste on the electrode. Electrodes with conductive paste can perform measurements, preventing electrical noise contamination. However, dry electrodes without conductive paste may be affected by noise from external devices (Figure 5.8).
Figure 5.8 Measurement tool of EEG

Since EEG measures weak electrical changes, it is affected by external devices, such as the shaking electrode cord. Therefore, active electrodes are generally used for dry electrodes. Active electrodes that combine the electrode and the active element have the function of adjusting the electrical contact resistance (impedance) with the skin. The function eliminates the effect of noise caused by external devices, such as the shaking electrode cord.
5.4.2.3 Measurement method

There are two methods of measurement of brain waves: the unipolar- induction method and the bipolar- derivation method. The unipolar- induction method includes a method of measuring some changes in the potential of each part by comparing with the reference electrode, that is, electrodes on earlobes, and another method of measuring some changes based on the average value of potentials of all the electrodes. In the bipolar- derivation method, the potential is measured at the time of

connecting two adjacent electrodes. The bipolar- derivation method includes a method of measuring by connecting vertically from the nose to the back of the skull and another method of measuring by connecting horizontally between both- side ears from left or right.

5.5 Cerebral blood flow - brain blood detection

The condition of the driver driving in a DS affects the nervous system, sensory system, motor system, circulatory system, digestive system, respiratory system, endocrine system, and immune system of the driver. Therefore, it becomes possible to obtain the driver's condition
objectively and quantitatively if these physiological conditions are observed.

In these biometrics, it can be said that the observation of the brain activity, which is the nervous system of the driver, is important. From around 1980, it became possible to observe the activity of the brain in real time by the development of the neural function image technology, and techniques such as positron emission computed tomography (PET), single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT), functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) have been developed [6]. However, the equipment necessary for these methods was very expensive, the measurement and signal analysis were complicated, and the utilization in DS was difficult. In such a situation, the medical equipment manufacturer of Japan developed multichannel NIRS that could measure the relative blood flow change of the brain in proportion to the brain position.
The principle of NIRS has been known for a long time and is as follows. Near- infrared light (from
650~\mathrm{nm}
to
1000\mathrm{nm}

) passes through tissues and is absorbed by hemoglobin (Hb) in the blood. When light of a certain wavelength passes through a substance, the absorbance is proportional to the concentration of the substance present in the sample and the optical path length. Since the optical absorption spectra of oxygenated Hb (oxyHb) combined with oxygen and deoxygenated Hb (deoxyHb) dissociated from oxygen are different, the state of oxygenation can be known from the change of Hb concentration, when the absorbance of near- infrared light over two wavelengths is measured. When an irradiation probe and an absorption probe of near- infrared light are arranged on the scalp with an interval of about
3\mathrm{cm}

, light which comes out from the irradiation probe and advances on the arc are detected by the absorption probe and the Hb quantity on the optical path can be calculated. That is to say, NIRS makes it possible to observe the condition of oxygenation of Hb in the capillary of cerebral cortex which exists from
2\mathrm{cm}
to
3\mathrm{cm}
under the scalp as shown in Figure 5.11.
Figure 5.11 Principle of NIRS

When plural irradiation probes and absorption probes are arranged in a lattice shape on the scalp, the light that advances between each probe simultaneously offers the information of each position, and the information of the oxygenation in the cerebral cortex in the wide range will be obtained. The measurement is possible in the comparatively free attitude if the cap in which multiple probes are arranged beforehand is fixed and this becomes multichannel NIRS. The device capable of measuring up to 120 channels has also been developed.

NIRS does not directly observe the activity of the brain but observes the situation of cerebral blood flow. It is known that cerebral blood flow rapidly rises locally in response to oxygen consumption when the brain is active. This phenomenon is called "luxury perfusion" in which a large amount of oxygen is sent to the active site more than the amount necessary for the activity of nerve cells. A rapid increase in oxyHb and a decrease in deoxyHb can be observed in the capillaries immediately after the start of cerebral nerve cell activity.
As a research example using NIRS for the measurement of driver condition in DS, [7] there is an evaluation of the effect of ADAS. The advanced driver assistance is adaptive cruise control (ACC).

Since ACC is an ADAS that automatically follows the forward- traveling vehicle, the driver is released from the workload of driving that follows. In this study, whether this burden reduction actually exists or not was observed by NIRS.

In this study, the experimental subject in DS is the following of the forward- traveling vehicle. The experimental conditions are the following state with and without ACC. When ACC is used, the driver does not
perform acceleration/deceleration operation to follow the forward- traveling vehicle but only steering operation. The headway time of ACC was
1.2~\mathrm{s}

. The condition in which the driver operates without using ACC, the distance between vehicles was maintained at about the same level as in ACC use and both conditions, and 1 trial was 210 seconds. The two conditions were alternated twice. NIRS was the near- infrared light imaging equipment OMM 3 000 made by Shimadzu Corp., and all 42 channels were sampled in
0.205~\mathrm{s}

. As a result, in the condition without ACC, oxyHb increased in the latter half of the operation task. As a common brain activity, although both dorsal parts of the frontal lobe were activated during the driving task, in the condition with ACC, there was no increase in oxyHb during driving, and the activation of the frontal lobe was smaller than in the condition without ACC. From this result, it can be said that the driving load of the driver was reduced by ACC.

In addition, there is a result that measured the change of distraction degree and arousal degree in the DS driving. Our laboratory also uses NIRS to confirm that the driver's alertness decreases during automated driving.
5.6 Electrocardiograph - heartbeat detection

As a biometric measurement for objectively obtaining the driver's condition, the autonomic nervous system is difficult to understand if there is no measuring instrument next to the state of brain activity. When the autonomic nervous system is used as an index, surprises, near- miss incidents, tension, excitement, attention concentration, malaise, etc., can be understood.

HR and respiratory rate are used as indexes of the autonomic nervous system. Especially, the practicability of HR is high, because the HR can be measured by various HR meters. The name such as PQRST is given to various heartbeat waveforms in the electrocardiogram for medical use, and the R wave that shows the largest heartbeat is used for the heartbeat analysis [8].

The interval of the maximum value of R waves is called RRI (R- R interval). The pulse interval can be considered to be almost RRI, but strictly it is different from RRI. If RRI is known, HR per minute can be known, and the function of autonomic nerve can be estimated by the

change of HR. Generally, an increase in HR is an index of physical and mental burden, and a decrease in HR is an index of relaxation degree and lowering of arousal. And, HR lowers when the consciousness concentrates in the outside, and HR rises when the consciousness concentrates in the inside. The protective reflex defective reflex (DR) increases HR, whereas the stereotactic reflex orienting reflex (OR), which occurs in response to a new stimulus, decreases HR. In relation to the tribulation, HR increases in tense situations and decreases when fatigued.

In addition, the fluctuation of RRI is called HR fluctuation heat rate variability (HRV), and it can be analyzed by the frequency component of the RRI fluctuation. High- frequency component HF is related to the parasympathetic nervous system, and low- frequency component LF is related to the sympathetic nervous system.

The next indicator for the autonomic nervous system is blood pressure. Blood pressure itself is the objective variable controlled by the autonomic nervous system. Thus, if blood pressure is known, autonomic status is known. However, there is a difficulty in realizing accurate blood pressure measurement during driving.

The pulse wave can be easily measured even during driving. Pulse waves can be measured from the fingertips or earlobes and can be considered close to, although not strictly, HR. However, the accuracy is deteriorated, because it is obtained from the heart through the blood vessel, and it curls from the heartbeat. It especially affects the calculation of HRV. Pulse wave amplitude may also be decreased at the fingertips and increased in the earlobes. This is because blood vessels constrict in the fingertips and dilate in the head when a steady reflex occurs. This is a mechanism of the body to send more blood flow to the brain and to understand new information.
Previous studies have also shown a link between vigilance and HRV. With delay in vision, some components of HRV (from
0.02\mathrm{Hz}
to
0.08\mathrm{Hz}
) increase.
The accuracy is inferior to percent time that the eyes are more than

closed (PERCLOS), however, may be better than subjective indices or EEG. This is an event in the case of sleep deprivation, and the prediction accuracy of decrease in vigilance of usual sleep state is low.
It has also been reported that the relationship between vigilance and HR has a higher correlation with the standard deviation of RRI than with

the LF and HF of RRI. According to this, the standard deviation of RRI can predict the result of vigilance after 1 minute, and it is not influenced by individual difference. In the frequency analysis of RRI, a fixed time observation period is required. However, the analysis becomes possible even from the data of several pulses, when it is the standard deviation, and it can be said that the time resolution method is excellent.
5.7 Driving performance

It is also possible to estimate the driver state from the driving performance without using physiologic measurements. However, the evaluation of driving performance has not been established, although there are various indicators. Nevertheless, the driving performance index is defined s follows in SAE [9]. The basis of the index that shows the own vehicle condition in the longitudinal direction is the own vehicle speed. Acceleration is obtained by first differentiation of vehicle speed by time, and jerk is obtained by further first differentiation of acceleration.

In the response time of acceleration/deceleration and stop, it is important to clarify the relationship between the foot of the driver and the pedal. It is because the response time differs depending on whether the response is started from the state of placing the foot on the floor, placing the foot on the pedal, or stepping on the pedal a little. Therefore, when the response time measurement results are shown, the start and end points must be accurately described. Time headway (THW: distance between vehicles divided by own vehicle speed) and time to collision (TTC: distance between cars divided by relative speed) are typical inter- vehicle distance and inter- vehicle time which show spatial margin between own vehicle and preceding vehicle. It is said that THW represents the driver's sense of rear- end collision risk in the situation with small speed fluctuation. On TTC, it is said that the driver judges the brake start based on the reciprocal of TTC. The relation between THW and TTC is examined, and the time derivative value of TTC and secondary prediction value of TTC are also proposed. The driving performance in the anteroposterior direction is still to be examined.
It is necessary to clarify the definition of inter- vehicle distance, because the distance between vehicles is an important index. Because

there are various variations in the definition of the inter- vehicle distance. In traffic engineering, the distance from the front end of the preceding vehicle to the front end of the following vehicle is defined as the distance between vehicles. This is because the front end of the vehicle is made to be a standard in the fixed point observation, and it is also called "Headway Spacing".

From the sensing point of view, the inter- vehicle distance means the distance from the rear end of the preceding vehicle to the front end of the following vehicle. Therefore, it becomes shorter by the length of the vehicle than the distance between vehicles in traffic engineering. SAE defines the inter- vehicle distance as gap. In the DS, the vehicle dynamics is based on the center of gravity of the vehicle. Therefore, the distance between the center of gravity of the preceding vehicle and the center of gravity of the following vehicle often becomes the inter- vehicle distance. However, the distance between the center of the vehicle body and the distance between the rotation centers of the vehicle have not been unified.

When the preceding vehicle is measured by Light Detection and Ranging / Laser Imaging Detection and Ranging (LiDAR), what value should be shown as the inter- vehicle distance? The method decided for one vehicle model is not always applicable to all vehicle models having various shapes.

Another important driving performance for the longitudinal direction is the lateral driving performance. The driving performance in the right and left directions is also determined in SAE as follows. The time from the stimulus presentation point to the steering operation start time point is called steering reaction time; the time from the operation start time point to the operation end time is called steering movement time; and the time obtained by combining the steering reaction time and steering movement time is called steering response time. These indicators are used to evaluate lane departure warnings and lane keeping support systems.
Steering from a certain direction to the opposite direction in a short time at a certain switching angle or more is called modified steering or steering correction. Switching angles of
3^{\circ}
5^{\circ}
, and
6^{\circ}

have been proposed. If this angle is too small, the noise of steering vibration is included, and if it is too large, fine correction by the driver cannot be reflected. Therefore, it is necessary to specify the threshold value when
calculating the modified steering. When the degree of distraction is high, the frequency of modified steering decreases, and large modified steering is applied.

As a method to evaluate the smoothness of steering, there is a SE method introduced in the next section 5.8. The prediction error (PE) becomes small when the steering operation is concentrated, and the PE distribution spreads when the secondary task is carried out. The feature that is not in the longitudinal direction in the lateral direction is the relative position index to the road. That is, where the vehicle is driving in the lane becomes the driving performance index in the lateral direction.

However, three cases are used as the standard of the road: center position between lanes, average value of travel locus of the preceding vehicle that passed, and lane edge. And, three points: center point on the right and left of the front axle, edge of the tyre, and center of gravity of the vehicle are used as a standard of the vehicle.

The vehicle lateral position deviation, standard deviation of lane position (SDLP), is most often used as the lateral driving performance. It is calculated from the standard deviation of lane lateral position data of a certain driving section, and it shows the vehicle lateral fluctuation in the corresponding driving section. In normal driving, the SDLP value goes from
0.2\mathrm{m}
to
0.3\mathrm{m}

, and it changes by age, road environment, and vehicle speed. As another index, time to line crossing (TLC) is also often used. This can be said to be TTC in the right and left directions. That is, it is an index showing the time to reach the edge of the road in a few seconds if nothing is done. An approximate calculation method of dividing the lateral distance by velocity and acceleration has also been proposed. It is said that the approximation method can be used when TLC is within
0.5\mathrm{s}
and that it becomes an improper value when TLC exceeds
0.5\mathrm{s}

. It can be said that the smaller the TLC, the lower the control performance of the lateral position. However, it is necessary to remove a value that is too large, because too large a value is a problem.
5.8 Steering wheel angle
The driver state changes according to the driving time. The degree of change and the time required vary depending on the load on the driver, the workload, and stress.

Because loads, workloads, and stresses are confusing, use these meanings clearly. When "load" is used, it is assumed that the driver is loaded and fatigued. The load may be physical or mental. On the other hand, when a workload is used, it is used to cause not only fatigue but also a positive change of state (warming up and activating) of the driver. Therefore, it is called mental workload, not simply workload, and it is used when a mental task is accompanied. Stress is originally a nonspecific adaptation syndrome for external noxious stimulation, and it is used when the correspondence ability of the driver for the driving environment at that time is asked.

Among these workloads, mental workload is important for HMI. There are the subjective evaluation method, the subtask method, etc., as evaluation methods of mental workload, and it is also possible to evaluate the amount of mental workload from the result of physiological measurement. However, the estimation of mental workload is considered to be most appropriate only from normal driving without any subjective evaluation or unnatural subtasks. This is a workload measurement method based on driving performance.

Basically, steering operation quantity, accelerator and brake pedal operation quantity, and visual line the driver does are available. Among them, the SE method has been established as a concrete method to analyze steering operation quantity [10].

The SE is a non- invasive and non- contact method because it measures only the steering operation quantity by the driver, and it has an advantage that the driver can measure in a natural state without being conscious of the measurement. It is easy to catch the change of the workload, because it can continuously measure during driving. Although some other methods use the lateral position for the travel lane other than the SE method, they require an on- vehicle camera. The SE method does not require additional equipment; therefore it is superior and is said to have high sensitivity. Not only there is SE method but also there are other methods to analyze the frequency of steering input and switching frequency of steering. Among them, the use frequency of the SE method is overwhelmingly high.

SE is a method to evaluate the smoothness (roughness) of the steering operation, as it was named "entropy". That is to say, it is a technique for noticing if the steering operation becomes rough as mental workload increases. In previous studies, the SE increased as the

operation of in- vehicle information equipment became more complicated. And, there is a research that examined the drowsy evaluation, because the steering entropy quantity increases when the drowsiness increases.

The calculation method predicts the present steering angle value from the past three points on steering angle data of 150 ms interval by the quadratic interpolation. The difference between the predicted value and the actual steering angle value is used to calculate a steering angle PE(Prediction Error). Next, 90 percentile value of PE is obtained from one driving data, and the values is called
\alpha
value, and the appearance frequency is classified into 9 bins by the multiple of
\alpha

. The smoother the steering operation, the sharper the center becomes, and the coarser the steering operation becomes, the lower the center becomes and the higher both sides become. Finally, the logarithmic sum of these nine bin ratios is defined as the amount of entropy.

The SE is an excellent method for evaluating mental workload by the driving performance. The downside is that it cannot be used in real time. The real- time steering entropy (RSE) method solves the defect of the SE that it cannot be used in real time. The RSE was announced in 2015 (the SE was in 2005) [11]. The RSE does not need to specify the driving course, and there is no need to distinguish standard driving from evaluation driving. It is an excellent technique that can calculate online in real time.

The calculation procedure is the same as that of the SE, in which steering angle data is acquired every 150 ms and PE is calculated. The SE records all driving data and calculates the PE distribution offline. On the other hand, the RSE updates PE distribution, which becomes recursive calculation. Specifically, the change points of PE are replaced by the long PE distribution and the short PE distribution. Then, the entropy of the long- time distribution and the entropy of the short- time distribution are calculated by the same calculation as the SE, and the sum of these difference values and the logarithm of the ratio of each PE is defined as the entropy value of the RSE. It has been reported that the evaluation of mental workload when subtasks were performed in the RSE is appropriate. However, there is a cautionary note that RSE is affected by disturbances such as the driving attitude of the driver, steering grasping position, road surface condition, and so on.

5.10 ADAS evaluation by DS

Here, the ADAS that can be evaluated by the DS and the functions that can be evaluated are described. The ADAS have the lowest automation rate at the lowest level of automated driving level 1; however, they have far more specifications than level 2 or higher automated driving.
5.10.1 FVCWS evaluation by DS

First, let's see the front vehicle collision warning system (FVCWS). It is the oldest system in the ADAS. The basic function of this system is to measure the distance between the vehicle and the vehicle traveling ahead on the same lane and to issue a warning to the driver when the TTC falls below a certain threshold. The DS can be used for the following evaluation items:

1. Appropriateness of warning timing  
2. Validity of the means of warning  
3. Validity of the overdetection rate  
4. Validity of the undetected rate  
5. Evaluation of product quality on curved roads (during curves, guardrails are often detected and false warnings are issued).

Overdetection means that something other than a vehicle traveling ahead is detected, and it is a type I error. Undetected means that the vehicle traveling ahead is not detected, which is a type II error.

Since the FVCWS does not have vehicle control and only provides information to the driver, the evaluation items in the DS are mainly related to HMI. Validity evaluation of warning timing is the basis of a warning system that evaluates the delay when the system issues the warning and the response time of the driver.

The validity of the warning methods is to evaluate whether the warning is given by sound or display, or by haptic vibration of the steering wheel, and the contents of each method. For example, when the warning is given by sound, the tone color, volume, output method, and the like are evaluated, and a sound of
4\mathrm{kHz}
is determined to be an intermittent sound of
80\mathrm{~db}
at
2\mathrm{Hz}
There are various external sensors such as LiDAR, radio wave radar, camera, etc., for detecting the vehicle traveling ahead by the FVCWS. It is difficult to detect any vehicles

correctly. Since the characteristics of the sensor include overdetection (type I error) and non- detection (type II error), it is necessary to evaluate whether each is acceptable to the driver. Depending on the type of sensor, the engineer knows under what circumstances the overdetection or non- detection is likely to occur, and it is possible to reproduce the situation of the erroneous detection by the DS.
Depending on the driving scene, a false warning which cannot be classified as overdetected or undetected may occur. A typical case is a

case where guardrails enter the detection range of a sensor and are erroneously recognized as a preceding vehicle when traveling on a curved road with a small curvature. The degree to which these false warnings are acceptable to the driver can also be evaluated by the DS.
5.10.2 Automated breaking evaluation by DS

Next is automated braking. Automated braking is not simply a braking control of the FVCWS. This is because the specification reflects the failure of the FVCWS, and therefore the warning specifications are different. This is also because the braking control is unexpected from the FVCWS.

In many cases, the FVCWS issues two types of warnings, the primary warning and the secondary warning, depending on the TTC length. However, the primary warning was not commercially successful because many extra warnings were called "nuisance alarm." Therefore, many automated brakes do not have a primary warning. In addition, while some FVCWSs display vehicle- to- vehicle distance from the viewpoint of providing information, the information providing the element of the automated brake is only the secondary warning. Moreover, the timing of the automated brake application is later than the secondary warning, and the method of applying the brake is also an intense sudden brake, which a general driver would not apply for a lifetime.

Therefore, in automated braking, the evaluation of the secondary warning timing is mainly performed on the DS. The timing of automated braking is such that evaluation of the driver is unnecessary because of the limit of physically avoiding collision.
5.10.3 ACC evaluation by DS

Next is ACC. As a driving support system, it is the oldest commercialized system after the FVCWS, and the oldest system when considered as an improved version of cruise control. The ACC can also be equipped with an FVCWS by adding the required sensors and actuators for cruise control. However, like the automated braking, it does not have all the functions of the FVCWS, and it is often only the specifications required for the ACC.

As the evaluation item using the DS for the ACC, it is considered that the the feeling of deceleration of the own vehicle after catching up with the forward traveling vehicle and the control feeling of whether the acceleration of the own vehicle is good or bad when there is no forward traveling vehicle. However, since the control feeling is not suitable for the actual vehicle test, there is no need to use a DS. The use of DS is often used to evaluate the utility and safety assessment of ACC from the perspective of human factors. For example, the DS evaluates the effect of reducing the load on the driving task by the ACC, and whether or not the driver behavior changes by getting used to the ACC.
Historically, the ACC has evolved from a throttle control system to a brake control system, from a speed of
40~\mathrm{km / h}
or more to a full speed range including stop and go. It goes without saying that DS plays an active role in determining the specifications for these advanced human factors.
5.10.4 LDWS evaluation by DS

Next is the lane departure warning system (LDWS). It is a system to warn of the deviation from the lane during driving. The LDWS is intended to be used on expressways because it detects white lines on both ends of the front driving lane with an in- vehicle camera. In case of driving on generic roads of city area, there are many white lines other than those indicating the edge of the road on the road surface, so that the vehicle is operated at, for example,
60~\mathrm{km / h}
or more in many cases.
The following items can be evaluated using the DS of LDWS:

1. Appropriateness of warning timing  
2. Validity of the means of warning  
3. Validity of the overdetection rate  
4. Validity of the undetected rate  
5. Evaluation of product quality on curved roads (it often crosses the inner white line when it curves).

The warning timing validates the distance to the white line and how many seconds it takes to reach the white line. The warning means evaluates whether it is a sound, a display, or a haptic to vibrate the steering wheel. Overdetection and undetection are the same concepts as the FVCWS. Since many drivers cut in the white line inside the curve on
curved roads, the degree of cut- in should be evaluated as a countermeasure against overwarning.
5.10.5 LKA evaluation by DS

Next is lane keep assist (LKA). The LKA is not a system that only adds steering control to the LDWS as the automated braking is not a system that only adds brake control to the FVCWS. However, the hardware configuration of the LKA is a lane departure warning system plus steering control. Therefore, the in- vehicle camera that recognizes the driving lane is the same.

However, the LKA does not issue a lane departure warning when the LKA is in operation because the LKA does not deviate from the lane. Therefore, the main evaluation item using the DS of LKA is whether the control condition on the curved road is accepted by the driver. Normally, the driver tends to move towards the inside of the lane when driving on a curve. Therefore, even if the vehicle is traveling while maintaining the center of the lane in a straight line, the driver may feel uncomfortable when maintaining the center of the lane on a curved road. Therefore, it is necessary to confirm how far the vehicle approaches the inside of the curve by lane control during curve driving.

The LKA prevents the driver from operating unless the driver is holding the steering wheel. Therefore, an alarm sound and an alarm method when the driver's hand is released from the steering wheel, and the HMI of how many seconds after the driver's hand is released from the steering wheel to release the control are also the evaluation items in the DS.

FVCWS, automated braking, ACC, LDWS, and LKA are the main ADAS. In addition, there are diagonal rear vehicle warnings at the time of lane change, automated lane change, peripheral warning at the time of parking, automated parking, etc.

In any of the ADAS, the human factors of the HMI concerning the information provision method to the driver and the warning can be evaluated by the DS, and the experiment can be conducted more safely and efficiently than the actual vehicle. Since the control feeling can be regarded as a kind of HMI, it can be evaluated by a DS. However, for the control feeling, it is necessary to use a DS that can reproduce the feeling of acceleration and deceleration just like a real vehicle, and in the case of
using a DS that only has images without moving devices, it is necessary to carefully select evaluation items.
5.11 Trust evaluation
5.11.1 Concept of validity

Trust evaluation can be composed mainly of validity and reliability. In this section, validity is defined as the certainty that the evaluation can find out the true characteristics that suit the purpose of the evaluation. On the other hand, reliability is defined as the certainty of how accurately the evaluation result is obtained and is independent of whether it is the true characteristic to be evaluated. The following will focus on validity of evaluation using the DS. When trying to secure validity of evaluation using DS, it is necessary to inspect whether the evaluation purpose can be achieved by using DS. The motivation that an evaluator tries to use DS is because an experiment is difficult in the actual environment owing to some reasons. Namely, an evaluator asks a DS for the experimental reproduction equal with environment. However, even if its evaluation has validity in actual environment, the evaluation which is reproduced by DS is not necessarily to have validity. This is because the current level of DS technology is limited and can only reproduce the actual environment partially and basically. Due to the nature of the evaluation, the validity of evaluation using DS cannot be established without equivalence to the actual environment. Therefore, when it tries to prove the validity of evaluation using DS, it's equivalence must be checked by comparing the evaluation results in the actual environment with the evaluation results in DS. Otherwise, if it is possible, it is better just to conduct evaluation in the actual environment and there is no meaning to use DS. Moreover, it is difficult to conduct this comparison in the evaluation which assumes a dangerous situation such as the situation occurring in a traffic accident. There is some research on adjusting DS by the data acquired by the above comparison in a specific situation [13- 16]. However, even if this adjustment is conducted perfectly, strictly speaking, there is no guarantee of getting evaluation results equal to them in the actual environment except in situations where this comparison proves equivalence. It should be thought that the current DS technology has only limited reproducibility and it would be impossible to prove the validity of
evaluation using DS by this comparison and to prove the equivalence of DS to the actual environment by the bottom- up method based on experimental results.

One of the remaining methods of proving the validity would be the top- down method based on the physical certainty of information that DS provides, not a bottom- up method like the proof by the experimental results described above. If DS can provide the information equal to the information which is provided by the actual environment for the driver and its evaluation has validity in the actual environment, it is thought that evaluation using DS would also be able to have validity. In this case, the most important point is "the actual environment for the driver," not the actual environment. As mentioned above, the current DS technology cannot provide the information equal to information that is provided from the actual environment perfectly. However, if the limit of information that a DS can provide exceeds the amount of information that the human perceives from the actual information, in other words, the amount of information that the human can use to recognize the actual environment, the DS is equivalent to reproducing the actual environment for the driver. It is thought that a human cannot use all the abundant information that is provided from the actual environment. For instance, a human only receives necessary visual information from among those that are provided from the actual environment and this bottom- up information is complemented by a high- order brain function that performs as top- down processing (binocular stereoscopic processing, shadow stereoscopic processing, etc.). Then humans regenerate visual space in the brain by this process. It may not be necessary that DS can provide all of the visual information that is provided from the actual environment.

Namely, DS just needs to provide the limited information which a human uses. This fact gives rise to the possibility that evaluations with the appropriate validity in DS will be possible even in situations where DS technology is limited. Therefore, it is important to understand the relation between the perceptual information processing functions and the limitation of information that DS can provide. In this section, the features and mechanisms of the perceptual information processing that is considered important for ensuring the validity of the evaluation using DS, are shown.
5.11.2 Visual information processing

Light from the actual environment is concentrated by the eyeball optical system (a cornea, a crystalline lens, a vitreous etc.). The image of the actual environment is projected onto a retina and is changed to a nervous signal. A retina is composed of photoreceptors, bipolar cells, and middle neurons which are composed of horizontal cells, amacrine cells, and gangliocytes. These make the layer structure. Photoreceptors are classified into cone cells and rod cells. There are about 7 million cone cells and 120 million rod cells in the retina. On the other hand, there are only about 1 million optic nerves that transmit nervous signals to a brain. Namely, nervous signals which are output from the photoreceptors are not transmitted to the brain directly. They are reconstructed by corporate processing of cells in the retina and transmit to the brain. If the mechanism of these corporate processing of cells in retina can be found out, DS would be able to provide the information that is used by this corporate processing effectively. Then DS may be able to make the driver see the environment exactly as the actual environment even if DS technology is limited.

The nervous signals transmitted by optic nerves are communicated to the primary visual cortex (hereinafter called "V1") in the occipital region. The nervous signals from V1 are transmitted to the occipital parietal cortex via the dorsal pathway and to the lower temporal cortex via the ventral pathway [17]. It is thought that these nervous signals reached the prefrontal cortex finally and realize the higher visual space recognition. When it is possible to specify important visual information in these top- down sequences of processing and the method providing them by DS, DS would be able to provide the environment that has a high equivalence with the actual environment.

One of the most important functions of DS is to make the driver perceive the depth of environment. The method that DS provides first is to project an image with geometric accuracy to a screen. By this method, the driver can get a geometrically accurate image on their own retina. It is thought that the driver perceives the depth of environment by adding the following information based on this image:
- Binocular parallax [18]- Accommodation [19]- Convergence [20]- Shadow and shade [21, 22]
- Decrease of the contrast owing to absorption and scattering by the atmosphere [23]- Texture gradient [24]- Occlusion and overlap [25, 26].

The stereoscopic vision system using binocular parallax has already been put to practical use. This system can make a human perceive the depth of environment drastically. Moreover, when DS can provide the driver the information of shadow and shade, information of decrease of the contrast owing to absorption and scattering by the atmosphere, information of texture gradient or information of shield and overlap properly based on the time place and occasion, DS may be able to make the driver perceive the depth of environment even if it does not use the stereoscopic vision system.

The other important function of DS is to induce vection. Vection is the moving sensation that occurs by only providing visual information which is got when humans move without providing physical moving information. For instance, when you get on the train while seeing a train that stops at the next platform through the window and then this train begins to move, you may have felt yourself moving in spite of your train not moving [27]. This sensation is vection. Vection would be considered a sense of compensating for vestibular sensation. Namely, vection is one of the strongest supporting sense systems for DS that is difficult to provide the information of vestibular sensation. Presently, it is thought that the visual information with the wide- angle provides a high sense of presence. This is based on the study that circular vection tends to occur because of visual information with a wide- angle [28]. On the other hand, it has been confirmed that linear vection occurs by only providing the extending visual information to the central vision area [29]. Namely, When the DS is used in a scenario where the vehicle is driving on a highway, it may be not necessary that DS provide the visual information with wide- angle in order to get the high presence equal to the actual environment, unlike when the DS is used in a scenario where the vehicle turns an intersection on a city area. Moreover, It is important for the DS visual information to make the driver recognize the positional relationship between the vehicle position and stationary objects (walls, ground, mountains, etc.) correctly. Whether or not the driver feels this positional relationship correctly determines the occurrence of vection on

the driver. Therefore, it is important to suppress the jitter of Computer Graphics (hereinafter called "CG") because there is a possibility that the jitter of CG disturb to recognize that the stationary objects is to stay stably and firmly. It is considered that the driver's sense of speed depends on the perceived relative speed with the surrounding objects. Especially for the driver, it is important in driving to perceive the absolute speed of the vehicle. Then, the visual information that becomes the information source is the optical flow generated by the stationary object. In other words, it is important for the driver to feel that the optical flow is firmly caused by a stationary object. The shaking of the image caused by this jitter of CG may prevent the driver from feeling the object expressed as a stationary object in CG. In case of setting big stationary objects in a distance, it may be important to express a decrease of contrast due to the absorption of light by air for these stationary objects by CG. The optical flow, which is the visual source of information that gives the driver a sense of speed, changes with distance. It is also important for the driver to correctly recognize the sense of distance from the stationary object in order for the driver to perceive the absolute speed. The decrease in contrast due to the absorption of light increases as the distance increases. This visual information may lead to the driver feeling the correct distance between an own vehicle and stationary objects based on the driver's experience, and as a result, the driver would feel the correct absolute speed.
5.11.3 Vestibular information processing

The sense organ for vestibular information consists of the semicircular canal with which a rotational component of one's own movement is perceived and the otolith container with which a longitudinal component is perceived. The horizontal semicircular canal, the anterior semicircular canal, and posterior semicircular canal exist in a semicircular canal. These are positioned so as to cross each other vertically. Namely, these semicircular canals react to the acceleration generated by the rotation in the direction in which they are placed. An otolith container consists of the utriculus and the sacculus. It has been pointed out that humans perceive acceleration from these vestibular organs, while humans may also perceive angular velocity by integrating these acceleration information into the brain [30]. The utriculus reacts to the linear

acceleration for the vertical direction and the sacculus reacts to the linear acceleration for the horizontal direction [31]. One of the purposes of the sense organ of vestibule information is to catch the change point of one's own movement and sense the degree of one's own movement. Therefore, when the vehicle is traveling at a constant speed, it is basically impossible to perceive whether the own state is stopped or moving. In that sense, vection performs the important function of compensating the sensation of one's own movement. Examples of devices that stimulate the vestibular sensation in DS include six- axis motion devices, translation devices, and turntables. The purpose of these devices is to properly provide the driver with the acceleration that occurs in the driver while driving. However, it is impossible to achieve this in all situations. Therefore, it is important to smoothly induce vection while the acceleration information provided by these devices is provided. The top- down processing in the brain links vestibular sensation information with vection.
5.11.4 Auditory information processing

The purpose of providing sound information in DS is roughly divided into two. One is the production of the motion state of the vehicle. This corresponds to running noise, engine noise, wind noise, etc., and provides the driver with vehicle speed information. The other is the localization of objects in the surrounding area.

If the vehicle is running side by side on the right side, let the driver know its presence by making a sound from the right side. 5.11.5 Physical consistency between perceptual information

One point to note here is the physical consistency between perceptual information. If there are differences in the reproducibility between the perceptual information provided by DS, it is necessary to pay attention to the scenario provided by DS. For instance, when DS is used to realize a scenario in which a vehicle turns left or right at an orthogonal intersection, it is relatively easy to provide the necessary visual information. On the other hand, it is very difficult to provide vestibular sensation information suitable for this scenario on the DS. If the DS cannot completely provide vestibular sensation information that is consistent with the visual information, it is basically better to give up on realizing this scenario with this DS. If this scenario is reproduced by this DS, the lack of vestibular information for the visual information occurs. This lack does not simply mean that the driver is not provided with the vestibular information. This lack provides information that there is no vestibular sense information that should be provided originally and exposes the driver to the situation where physical contradictions occur between visual information and vestibular information. It is thought that our perceptual information processing is basically applied for the situation with physically consistent perceptual information. Therefore, in the above case, the relation between the perceptual information is physically broken, and it is considered that it is difficult for a person to perform perceptual information processing. It becomes difficult for the driver to build spatial perception, and there is a concern that DS sickness may occur. In that sense, it means that the DS cannot provide the driver with the perceptual information equal with the actual environment at the

stage when the DS caused the DS sickness to the driver. Therefore, it would be said that the DS has low reproducibility in the actual environment and the validity of the evaluation results performed on this DS is low.
5.12 Automated driving evaluation by DS
The practical application of automated driving in proportion to the technology level is advanced. The following six levels proposed in SAE J3016 are de facto for this level of technology.

Level 0 (manual operation) No self- driving element; driver controls all operations Level 1 (driver assistance) Partial automation of operational control of drivers Level 2 (partial automated driving) Automates operational control under driver supervision Level 3 (conditional automated driving) Conditional autopilot, driver backs up Level 4 (highly automated driving) Automated driving is possible; however, a driver is required and manual mode is available Level 5 (fully automated driving) Autonomous in all situations, no driver required.

The so- called automated driving is a Level 3 or higher that can run without driver monitoring and is called highly automated driving. The critical difference between Levels 2 and 3 is that when an accident occurs while driving in the autonomous driving mode, the responsibility for the accident rests with the driver because Level 2 was under the driver's supervision, and with Level 3 there is no driver's supervision, so the responsibility for the accident rests with the manufacturer providing the automated driving.

There are five issues to be addressed in realizing highly automated driving: handling of insufficient sensor performance, take- over, mixing of manual and automated driving, responsibility for traffic accident issues, and ethical issues. Among these issues, the DS can be used for take- over and ethical issues.
5.12.1 Take-over evaluation by DS

Let's start with a take- over. Take- over means that the automated driving state is taken and the driver changes to manual operation. Take- over is possible up to automated driving Level 4 because the steering and pedals are mounted. Let's take a look at the level of self- driving from a takeover perspective.

The automated driving level is classified by SAE in six stages from the conventional manual operation of level 0 to the fully automated driving of Level 5. When the level is changed, there are three kinds of items that have an effect: vehicle control, peripheral monitoring, and response in case of system troubles. In Level 1, vehicle control is performed by automated driving and driver in cooperation, in Level 2, vehicle control is performed by automated driving, in Level 3, peripheral monitoring is added, and in Level 4, response in case of system troubles is added. Although the functions of Levels 4 and 5 are the same, Level 5 does not require a driver, so that driving operational devices such as a steering wheel and pedals are not required.

Thus, take- over occurs at Levels 2 and 3. However, even at Level 4, since the driver can operate this vehicle, it is expected that take- over is possible. Let's see how a take- over is done at each level of automated driving; of course, level 0 is irrelevant, therefore from level 1.

Level 1 is the ADAS itself, such as ACC. During follow- up driving, the driver can take over freely at any time, and it is often left to the automated driving control when the situation becomes possible to support the operation from the manual operation.

At Level 2, all driving control can be left to the vehicle, increasing the opportunity for take- over. There is no particular problem in a situation where the driver actively takes over at his own will and enjoys driving beyond the driving control performed by automated driving. The problem is that the automated driving requests the driver to take over when the driver is not concentrating on monitoring the surroundings while the automated driving is controlling the operation. Automated driving requests for take- over when control is difficult. However, there is a concern that the driver might not be in a take- over situation.

What happens if the automated driving system requests a take- over when the driver is doing tasks other than monitoring the surroundings? In such a situation, a smooth take- over cannot be expected, and the
automated driving originally for improving safety may cause a dangerous situation.

In Level 2, although the operation control is performed on the automated driving side and the peripheral monitoring is performed on the driver side, the automated driving side also performs the peripheral monitoring to actually perform the operation control. Therefore, even if the driver neglects the peripheral monitoring, appropriate operation control is performed in most cases.

Therefore, there is a concern about the occurrence of a driver who misunderstands the specification of Level 2 as not requiring peripheral monitoring. In addition, in a situation where operation control is not required, there is a concern that the operator may not be able to concentrate on monitoring the surroundings even if the driver is obliged to monitor the surroundings. As a matter of course, if the driver himself/herself is driving, he/she cannot drive without monitoring the surroundings, so the driver concentrates on monitoring the surroundings. We all know that if you are doing some kind of task, such as using a cell phone to focus your attention on a conversation, you cannot focus on monitoring your surroundings and drive safely. Therefore, there may be a problem in imposing the obligation to monitor the surroundings with the specification that makes it impossible to concentrate on monitoring the surroundings.

The reason why there is a problem in monitoring the surroundings of the Level 2 automated driving is based on the results of an experiment using a DS conducted in this laboratory. The degree of concentration of peripheral monitoring by most of the experiment collaborators is reduced by experiencing automated driving with only peripheral monitoring without operation control.
Not only does it decrease concentration it also decreases alertness. In other words, if you keep driving without driving control, you will feel sleepy.

Rather, they seem to be less drowsy when performing tasks other than perimeter monitoring. For example, not only monitoring the surroundings but also watching a video on the navigation screen or a smartphone will not cause drowsiness. However, in this case, it is so- called inattentive driving. It cannot be said that sufficient monitoring of surrounding areas is being conducted.

A driver monitor that analyzes the driver's face with a camera to determine whether the driver is concentrating on peripheral monitoring is considered. In the present image processing, it is possible to detect the driver's line of sight, the number of blinks as an index of sleepiness of the driver, and the degree of opening and closing of the eyelids, so that it is possible to determine whether the driver is concentrating on monitoring the surroundings.
If the driver monitor detects that the driver concentration has decreased, a warning is issued to warn the driver. If you doze off, it can be used as a doze warning.

In the automated driving of Level 2, the driver tends to reduce the concentration of peripheral monitoring. Therefore, when the driver monitor is mounted to monitor the driver, the warning is always activated during the automated driving at Level 2. Is this a good driver? Warning sounds are not usually pleasant sounds. The noise is intended to warn the driver, so unpleasant sounds should be more responsive to the driver. Therefore, the driver monitor warning sound may impair the comfort of automated driving.

We wonder if we should go into the automated driving mode while being monitored by the driver monitor, or we should just stick to manual operation because we do not want to hear unpleasant warning sounds. At first you will probably try the self- driving mode; however, eventually you will only be driving manually.

At Level 2, the automated driving controls the operation, so that the vehicle can be operated by hands- off driving. However, if the driver is in a hands- off state, the concentration of monitoring around the vehicle decreases as described above.

For this reason, in most of the Level 2 equivalent automated driving currently marketed, automated driving does not work unless the driver grips the steering wheel. If the driver holds the steering wheel, the driver can naturally focus on driving and on monitoring the surroundings, even if automated driving is operating the steering and pedals.

Holding the steering wheel makes it the same as Level 1's Keep Lane Assist. Keep lane assist generally does not work unless the driver holds the steering wheel. Keep Lane Assist does not involve pedaling, but when combined with Level 1 ACC, it is the same as Level 2. In other words, if the driver should hold the steering wheel at Level 2, it is not different from Level 1.

When the driver holds the steering wheel, it is easy to take over, and there is no problem because it concentrates on monitoring the surroundings. However, it is no longer meaningful to distinguish Level 1 from Level 2, and the significance of existence of Level 2 is lowered.

As long as the driver holds the steering wheel, Levels 2 and 1 are not much different. So what about Level 3? At Level 3, in addition to the operation control being performed by the automated driving side, peripheral monitoring is also performed by automated driving. Therefore, the driver has no monitoring obligation.

Since there is no peripheral monitoring obligation, the driver can do anything while driving in the automated driving mode. The driver can enjoy a DVD movie on the navigation screen, or he/she can watch it on his/her smartphone. But can he/she off? A take- over request may also occur for Level 3 from automated driving. That is, when a situation is encountered or a failure occurs in which the automated driving system cannot respond. At this time, if the driver is dozing off, it is impossible that the driver can smoothly take over.

Therefore, mounting of a driver monitor is also considered. Unlike Level 2, the system does not warn the degree of concentration of monitoring around the area, so the warning for looking aside disappears, but the warning must be issued when the driver falls asleep.

In fact, a number of doze warnings have been researched, developed, and commercialized. However, private vehicles with doze warnings are not common. The general idea is not to drive when the driver feels sleepy. If the driver feels sleepy, the usual way of thinking is to take rest and take a nap instead of driving.

Also, is it effective to detect a doze and give a warning? Although a temporary effect can be expected, it is difficult to prevent falling asleep on a continuous basis. Therefore, after the driver monitor mounted on Level 3 automated driving detects the decrease in the driver's arousal level and warns the driver to raise the arousal level once, automated driving should be canceled. In other words, the driver can not doze off at Level 3. If the driver feels sleepy, he/she has to rest at a drive- in.

After all, automated driving Levels 2 and 3 are automated driving systems that can not doze off. Furthermore, it is not good to lose a warning while driving. This is because when the level of warning decreases, peripheral surveillance becomes less effective at Level 2, and
emergent take- over requests cannot be met at Level 3. In some cases, a planned take- over is carried out in response to an emergent take- over.

Planned take- over refers to a type of take- over that appears in systems that cannot operate automatically on general roads but can operate automatically only on expressways. That is, the exit point of the expressway and the entrance point to the drive- in are known, and the take- over request from automated driving to manual driving is made in front of them. In this case, since the take- over request is issued with a sufficient margin, it can be expected to return until manual driving can be performed after the take- over request even if the arousal level is lowered. In addition, since the take- over request can be sent to the driver gradually rather than suddenly, the driver's consciousness will gradually increase towards driving.

When executing the planned take- over, the point at which the takeover request is issued is important. The point should be a straight line. This is because the driver does not perform the driving operation until the take- over, so it is necessary to get used to the driving operation. To get used to driving, it is better to drive in a straight line first.

In a DS experiment conducted in this laboratory in the past, steering wheel operation for lane change was smoother as the vehicle ran on a straight line for a longer period of time in a lane change situation after take- over at the straight line. This indicates that it takes time to get used to driving. Therefore, the take- over request selects a point where the straight line continues for a long time. Automated driving vehicles have digital maps, so we do not have to worry about picking a spot.

However, in an emergent take- over, there is no point to choose. In other words, the point where the take- over request is issued is not necessarily the long straight line. What happens when the emergent takeover is requested at a curve? There are curves on expressways, and there are curves at points with slopes.

In experiments with DS to see what happens when the driver takes over on the curve, we see that there is a problem. Most drivers wobble after the take- over. The difference between automated driving and driver driving, which was not felt when driving straight, can be felt at curves. The driving style of the curve shows the experience and preference of the driver, and it is unique when entering the curve, during the curve, and at the exit of the curve. For example, at a point where the vehicle enters a curve from a straight line portion, the driver may feel a sense of

incongruity in the speed of automated driving and steering control. Therefore, if the driver takes over in the middle of the curve, the driver may feel unsteady because he/she tries to change to his/her own driving line. The emergent take- over seems problematic. It is not just when the take- over occurs at the curve.

The position of the obstacle causing the takeover request in this experiment was changed every time the experiment was performed so that the position was not expected by the driver. The test was conducted on a highway with two lanes, a driving lane and a passing lane, as shown in Figures 5.12 and 5.13.

An experimenter told the driver that it was automated driving until the take- over request was beeped, and told a driver to determine the reason for the request and act accordingly. The experimenter did not mention changing a lane with the steering wheel or slowing down with the brake pedal. The driver was also asked for one of the following six tasks until the take- over request was issued:

1. Place both hands on the steering wheel and watch ahead. The foot position is free.  
2. Release both hands from the steering wheel and the line of sight was free. The foot position is free.  
3. Place both hands on the steering wheel and watch the video on the navigation screen.  
4. Release both hands from the steering wheel and watch the video on the navigation screen.  
5. Put one hand on the steering wheel and perform an additional task.  
6. Release both hands from the steering wheel and perform the additional task.

The navigation screen was installed at the lower part of the center of the instrument panel, and the forward view could not be seen when the navigation screen was closely observed. The additional task is a task of inputting many four- digit numbers presented next to the navigation screen.

Before we get to the experimental results, let us assume the response of the driver from the take- over request to the take- over. However, it is more important to estimate the process by which the results are obtained and compare them with the actual results than to obtain the experimental results. When the take- over request is issued, if the driver is not looking ahead, it is likely that the driver will immediately turn his/her face forward and turn his/her attention forward. The driver will try to understand the situation to find out why the take- over request was issued. Then, once the driver understands the situation, he/she should choose the action appropriate for the situation and move on to the action such as steering or braking. When such an action is carried out, the take- over of the driving task is completed, and the vehicle enters the so- called manual driving loop in the driving feedback loop as shown in Figure 5.14. In the case of automated driving, the driver is not involved in the operation at all, so it can be said that the vehicle is outside the driving which is out of the feedback loop. That is, after the take- over request, the driver can be thought of as returning to the manual driving operation, understanding the situation, and starting the manual driving operation to complete the driving feedback loop by manual operation. If the above actions were completed within TTC seconds, the take- over would have been established.
