In the above experiment, it was found that a problem may occur when the take- over is performed while the vehicle is running. It can be seen that this problem has a problem on the driver side and a problem on the vehicle side. The problem on the driver side is whether or not the driver is in a state in which take- over is immediately possible when the take- over request is issued. The problem on the vehicle side is that take- over cannot be supported. Whether or not the driver can take- over is whether or not a forward monitoring can be performed immediately upon the take- over request, the situation can be recognized, and the smooth transition to operation can be made. That is, the driver has sufficient alertness. Therefore, the necessity of the driver monitor is discussed in order to determine the arousal level of the driver at the time of the take- over request or before the request. Should the driver monitor be installed, the driver be constantly monitored during automated driving, and if a decrease in alertness is detected, the warning or stimulus should be given to restore alertness? It would be nice if the driver monitor could accurately monitor the driver's wakefulness, but what if the warning is issued when the wakefulness is not lowered by mistake? It is not a serious mistake, but if the driver is enjoying a comfortable automated driving experience, he/she might find the warning offensive.

In our laboratory, we are also continuing research on the problem of driver wakefulness lowering, not from the standpoint of warning after wakefulness decreases, but from the standpoint of how to prevent wakefulness from decreasing. Automated driving frees the driver from the heavy task of driving, so when a new task is imposed so as not to lower the arousal level, the driver is selected with the least load.

There are a number of tasks that do not reduce alertness if the load on the driver is ignored. Active conversation and singing do not reduce alertness, but it does burden drivers. Section 6.2.1 describes specific experimental results. The tasks we tested in our lab that did not reduce alertness included gripping the steering wheel, providing information based on where the driver is driving, flashing LEDs based on breathing rate during high alertness, and flashing LEDs that trigger saccade stimulation. Of these, steering wheel gripping and saccade induction were particularly effective. If the driver holds the steering wheel, he/she will not be able to lower his/her alertness from his/her driving habits. Saccade induction seems to be effective due to the biological characteristics of humans, but there is a problem whether it can be performed voluntarily.

The fact that the steering wheel grip is effective for preventing the lowering of the arousal is a method in which the automated driving Level 1 is extended and cost is not required. Even when the level of automated driving has evolved from 1 to 2 or 3, the most effective means for takeover is to have the driver maintain the driving posture and hold the steering wheel.

On the other hand, the problem on the side of the vehicle which cannot support the take- over is to suddenly shift the control to manual driving operation after the take- over request. In other words, this means that even if the driving control is suddenly moved to the driver while the vehicle is running, a problem arises because the driver is not ready for the driving operation. In the planned take- over, it is assumed that the take- over request is issued only on the straight line. This is because the driver will not be able to cope with the problem unless the line is straight.

As described above, most of the drivers operated the steering wheel smoothly when changing the lane immediately after completing the takeover on the straight track and when changing the lane after driving on the same lane for a while after completing the take- over. This indicates that

the manual driving operation of the driver requires a familiarization drive. There is also another study in which the steering wheel operation is disturbed when the vehicle is taken over while driving on the curve. In view of this, it may be preferable to continue Level 1 vehicle control such as lane keeping instead of stopping vehicle control at the time of take- over. However, it is necessary to verify whether lane keeping is working and there is no problem when quick steering is necessary to avoid obstacles.

We have found a number of challenges in take- overs. Switching from automated to manual driving operation cannot be done easily by determining specifications. Conversely, what about switching from manual driving operation to automated driving? The author has experienced this in the driving support system, and so there is no problem. With ACC, the driver simply turns on the set switch and he/she can safely leave the pedal. The same goes for switching to automated driving, where the driver can turn it on at any time. If you are worried that automated driving might require a special HMI, try it out on a DS, as we did in the take- over experiments. In driving support systems and automated driving, the driver entrusts the driving operation to the automobile, which greatly increases the utilization of the DS. When the driver drives the vehicle manually, the behavior of the vehicle in response to steering wheel operation and the feeling that the behavior of the vehicle imparts to the driver through the steering wheel are strictly required. However, in the case of ADAS, the driver does not have a severe sense of feeling required to drive the vehicle through the steering wheel, and therefore, if the DS pays attention to the graphics representing the driving environment, the generation of G may not be as accurate as during manual driving. Therefore, even low- cost DS can be fully utilized.
5.12.2 Ethics evaluation by DS

There are five challenges to achieving Level 5 automated driving: handling sensor performance inadequacies, take- over, mixing manual and automated driving, liability in the event of an accident, and ethics. Among these, in addition to the take- over described so far, we consider the ethical issue and the problem of the mixture of manual and automated driving. Let us start with ethical issues.

The problem with the ethics of automated driving is the case where the trolley problem is applied to automated driving. That is, in a situation where the brake of the automated driving vehicle is broken and cannot stop suddenly, there is one pedestrian (a gentleman looks rich) in the driving lane and two pedestrians (young students) in the other lane as shown in Figure 5.19. Automated driving vehicles will either turn to the roadside to avoid contact with pedestrian groups and collide with the roadside zone, or they will keep driving and crash into the pedestrian. In this ultimate situation, automated driving can be programmed to choose. This is not a matter of developer preference. What should we base our decision on, not my taste?
Figure 5.19 Trolley problem in automated driving

In response to this problem, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) Media Lab launched a project called Moral Machine [33]. It collects people's judgments by answering questionnaires about the various automated driving trolley problems on the Moral Machine site. There are a lot of questions on the Moral Machine, and you can post new situations. The questions are based on the assumption that the automated driving vehicle with the broken brake will be damaged by going straight or changing lanes on a two- lane road, and the choice between going straight or changing lanes is made in the following situations for example.

- If you go straight, five pedestrians will die, and if you change lanes, you will hit an obstacle on the road and one driver will die.- The automated driving vehicle is being driven by a pregnant woman and a child who is just three years old, and the number of pedestrians who were thought to be five is actually four people and one dog, two
of whom are criminals, one elderly and one homeless. In addition, everyone may cross the street ignoring the red traffic light.

There are a number of other settings. In the above questions, you might choose lane change in the first setup, but what percentage of the next question would you choose lane change? When you answer the moral machine question, it shows you your choices and the results of your average choices. The author's answers were close to the average, but some of the questions were noticeably off. In other words, the Moral Machine has no right answer. So far, 40 million people around the world have tended to answer questions, but the trends vary by region and culture.

The parameters of choice are the difference between survivors and victims, sex, age, human or animal, body shape, social status, passenger or pedestrian, compliance with traffic rules, and whether to change course. Among these parameters, a common trend among respondents, regardless of nationality, age, or religion, is to prefer humans to animals, large numbers to small numbers, and young people to the elderly. It also tends to give priority to compliance with social status and traffic rules. However, there is no consistent trend for other parameters. However, there are regional trends. For example, in Finland, where the income gap is small, passengers or pedestrians, or social status is not a determining factor. In Central and South America, however, many felt that homeless people and criminals do not have to be helped. Japan's trend is slightly different from that of the rest of the world. That is, they do not value the number of lives saved. In other words, they tend to focus on who to help rather than the number. They also tend not to change their course.

In addition, the tendency to assist pedestrians rather than passengers is most prominent in the world. By comparison, Norway is second and Singapore third in this trend, while China tends to help its crews rather than pedestrians. France tends to focus on the number of survivors and to help younger people more than older people. In Taiwan, China, and South Korea, however, there is a strong tendency to help the elderly. These results show that there is no solution that the world of the trolley problem can accept. But because most of the Moral Machine's respondents are young men, the results of a survey across all generations may change.

Let's assume that automated driving vehicles have a fair judgment in the trolley problem of minimizing the number of victims. If the victims include drivers, would you like to ride the automated driving vehicle? The specifications of automobiles are basically uniform worldwide. Automated driving vehicles will not change this basic principle. However, the driver's ethics are not the same in countries and regions around the world, according to the results of the Moral Machine. Is it all right to change the specifications depending on the destination so that different ethics are applied to different parts of the world?

One of the factors for changing the specifications is the traffic infrastructure situation in the area where it is used. For example, suppose an automobile lane is one lane away from each other, and there is an area with a bicycle lane next to the automobile lane. In order to avoid the risk of contact with oncoming vehicles, the vehicle is programmed to travel a little further from the oncoming lane and a little closer to the bike lane. This reduces the risk of oncoming vehicle contact but increases the risk of bicycle contact. That means there will be a statistically significant increase in crashes between automated driving vehicles and bicycles in the region. In this way, changing the specification of automated driving will change the type of accident. For this reason, the author thinks it would be better to standardize the specifications of automated driving, which is related to accidents.

With regard to ethics, it is not possible to unify ethics itself, so why not unify the process of reaching a conclusion? In other words, research and development of programs that reflect the preferences of local users in each country by the same mechanism, while maintaining the principles.

Now let us consider how to program the automated driving ethic. Drivers should have a clear sense of ethics, and the automated driving ethic should be the same. The simple one is to set the rule of which to choose as the production rule and select logically by if- then- else. Changing the production rules of the database by destination would allow for a variety of specifications. However, this approach requires that all confronting situations be embedded in the database. The actual situation may be ambiguous or unexpected. As a result, automated driving decisions are quickly broken in situations that if- then- else cannot determine. In order to deal with situations that do not fit in the database or are unexpected, automated driving vehicles will need to learn about
the real world. That would allow automated driving vehicles to judge a wide range of situations.

Before proceeding with the development of the program, let us see what the society thinks. First of all, the three famous principles of robotics. Automated driving vehicles think and act on their own based on information obtained through sensing. In other words, since they can be called robots, they refer to the three principles of robotics. The Three Principles of Robotics were proposed in the work of science fiction writer Isaac Asimov. In the 1950 "I, Robot," it is described as follows in the 2058 "robotics handbook," 56th edition [34].
Article 1: Robots must not harm humans. In addition, they shall not cause harm to human beings by overlooking such danger.
Article 2: Robots must obey orders given to humans. Provided, however, that this shall not apply where the order issued contravenes Article 1.
Article 3: The robot must protect itself unless it is likely to violate Articles 1 and 2 above.

Suppose that the driver is being carried by the robot following these three principles. How will the robot behave when the trolley problem occurs? Let us see how the automated driving vehicle that follows the three principles of robotics behaves in the trolley problem. When the driver is not in the vehicle, the driver should change the lane in accordance with Article 1 and cause a self- injury accident in the situation where the driver is a pedestrian in the straight line and the driver is the obstacle in the lane change. If there were five people going straight and one person changing lanes, they would try to change lanes to minimize the number of victims. However, it turns out that the three robot principles alone are not enough because they are against Article 1. What would it do if it had a driver and one person going straight and the obstacle changing lanes? Going straight is against Article 1, and changing lanes is also against Article 1 because it harms the driver. Even if the driver instructs the driver to go straight ahead, it is against Article 1, but even if the driver changes lanes, it is against Article 1 and cannot make a decision. Again, the three principles of robotics are not enough. New rules are needed to ensure that decisions are made in accordance with ethical standards.
Therefore, the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) has established the Moral Conscious Design Initiative Guidelines

(Ethically Aligned Design) [35]. This is being revised, taking into account the opinions of practitioners and researchers. The IEEE Moral Conscious Design Initiative Guidelines target artificial intelligence (AI) and autonomous systems (AS). Autonomous driving will be powered by AI, but it will be autonomous. AI and AS are collectively called A/IS. As the major principles of A/IS, the following three points are listed:

1. Universal human values: A/IS can be a huge force for good in society if it is designed to respect human rights, harmonize with human values, increase happiness overall, and protect us. This value is necessary not only for engineers but also for policymakers and should benefit everyone, not for the benefit of a group or a single country.  
2. Political decision and data handling: When properly designed and implemented, A/IS has great potential to foster culturally appropriate political freedom and democracy. These systems improve political efficiency, but digital data should be protected in a verifiable manner.  
3. Technical dependency: A/IS should provide reliable services, and trust means that A/IS can enhance human-driven value and securely and actively achieve its designed objectives. The technology should monitor that its operation is consistent with human values and meets the prescribed ethical objectives of respecting rights. In addition, the verification and verification process should be developed to be auditable and authoritative.
The IEEE Moral Conscious Design Initiative Guidelines set out the following four issues to be considered in order to realize the three principles:

1. Human Rights Framing: How can A/IS ensure that human rights are not invaded?  
2. Accountability Principle Framing: How can A/IS ensure that A/IS is accountable?  
3. Transparency Principles: How can A/IS ensure the transparency of A/IS?  
4. Educational Framing: How can A/IS maximize the benefits of A/IS technology and minimize the risk of misuse?

This means that the automated driving vehicle ethics program (system) must be framed so as not to invade human rights, that the decision- making process can be output ex post facto, and that it must be developed to have the fewest problems in the region at the time of the ex post facto verification. In addition, the following three points should be given priority as the implementation principle within the development team of automated driving:

- Identify the norms and values of each system affected by the A/IS.- The norms and values of the system are implemented in A/IS.- Assess the coordination and collaterality of norms and values between people and A/IS within each system and development team.
In order to develop the program that reflects ethics in automated driving in accordance with the IEEE Moral Conscious Design Initiative Guidelines, the authors suggest, for example, the following:
1. In order not to invade human rights, when the automated driving vehicle is no driver, priority is given to life other than that of the automated driving vehicle.
(Pets if going straight, obstacles if changing a lane, choose to collide with the obstacles.)
2. If the automated driving vehicle occupants are present, priority should be given to occupant safety.
(Pedestrians if going straight, obstacles if changing the lane, the automated driving vehicle will not change the lane. In case of this, the regulations shall be established in advance.)
3. When damage is inflicted on persons other than crew members, judgment shall be made in accordance with the ethics of the country or region where the automated vehicles are used.

This is just an example, and the contents are not the author's taste or idea, and there are no references. The idea is to place these basic principles on the premise of program development. Then, the issue is to make the program conform to the ethics of the country/region in item 3.

We found that it is possible to consider the program that expresses ethics. However, initial program values and constants must be collected experimentally. The best way to experiment is to collect driving data in the DS with the help of a person with a typical sense of ethics. In this method, drivers are asked to make a decision on whether to go straight or change lanes by causing a truck problem on the DS.

It is a good idea to experiment with two different patterns, one for manual driving with broken brakes, and the other for the automated driving vehicle. Also, independent of the DS experiment, it is necessary to take a questionnaire just for judging the situation like the moral machine and check whether it is the same tendency as the result of the DS. This is because there is no time to think carefully in actual situations, and the presence or absence of a difference between immediate judgment and thoughtful judgment is also important data.

Also, in the case of a learning type program, learning should be started not only in extreme situations such as the trolley problem but also in normal use. Therefore, from the status of compliance with the normal traffic rules of one's own vehicle to the status of travel of another vehicle, the status of the environment in which the vehicle is normally traveling is also used for parameter learning of the program.

Level 5 automated driving vehicles do not have steering or pedals because they are not supposed to be driven by drivers. This means that it is not possible to learn the driver's ethics during normal driving. For this reason, it would be better to start from the point where the Level 1 driver actively controls the vehicle, learns the ethics during normal driving in the Level 1 usage situation, and gradually raises the level of automated driving, instead of suddenly changing to Level 5. Of course, there is also the idea that a Level 5 automated driving vehicle will inherit the values it learned when it was developed. However, ethics can vary slightly depending on the user and the area in which they use it, so it is better to have a mechanism that allows them to always learn. Therefore, the DS is utilized.

Thus, the automated driving vehicle that is not controlled by the driver should have a mechanism to monitor the ethical satisfaction of its occupants during normal use. This means that the system is needed to detect changes in physiological indicators of occupants without contact.
5.12.3 Communication method evaluation by DS

Next, let's look at the mix of manual and automated driving issues. What's wrong with the mix of manual and automated driving? How do you communicate with other drivers during normal driving? You can think of the blinker when you turn right and left at the intersection or change lanes, the passing when you want to pass, the thank you hazard, the horn, etc. These are also implemented in automated driving vehicles, and there are no particular problems. However, communication without using the vehicle's blinker, hazard, passing, or horn becomes a problem. That is, how the automated driving vehicle can show what the driver has shown to other traffic with gestures and facial expressions. Level 5 automated driving vehicles do not have drivers. Perhaps all the windows in the automated driving vehicle are smoked so you cannot see inside. Under these circumstances, if the automated driving vehicle starts to slow in front of a pedestrian who wants to cross the road, the pedestrian might not know whether the vehicle wants to tell the pedestrian to cross or just slow down for some reason.

In the past, large trucks were equipped with speed indicators to inform pedestrians about the condition of the trucks in Japan, if not as a tool for communication between vehicles and pedestrians as shown in Figure 5.20. This was a triplet of lamps mounted on the top of the truck windshield, and the number of lamps on the green varied with speed. The speed indicator lights are all turned off when the truck is stopped, and one light is automatically turned on at speeds of

or less, two lights are automatically turned on at speeds of
40~\mathrm{km / h}
to
60~\mathrm{km / h}
or less, and three lights are automatically turned on at speeds of
60~\mathrm{km / h}

or more. Pedestrians can know the speed of the truck by looking at the number of the speed indicator lights of the truck coming from a distance. It was useful as a primitive form of a vehicle- pedestrian communication tool. However, it was abolished in 1999 because it would become an import barrier. The speed indicator was unique to Japan. It was a victim of the automobile export war. Even imported trucks could be approved if they were modified and equipped with speed indicator lamps, but they were regarded as import barriers because of the cost of modification. Such communication tools with pedestrians and other drivers are necessary for driverless automated driving vehicles. At the very least, you will need something to show that it is the automated driving vehicle so it can be recognized correctly by other traffic. As a means of communication with pedestrians and other vehicles other than blinker and passing, it is possible to attach an electric bulletin board facing outside the vehicle. On- board electronic bulletin boards are often used by public vehicles for traffic regulations and construction guidance. Electric bulletin boards are sold not only in public vehicles but also in stores, where messages such as "Thank you" and "After you" are displayed or printed in flowing characters. However, under the current Road Traffic Law, it is necessary to be careful when lighting other than the lights, and strictly speaking, lighting while driving may violate the law in some countries. In the inexpensive one, LEDs can be arranged in a matrix, dot characters can be selected to store several patterns, and messages can be displayed depending on the situation. Adding speed indicator light to this and providing the message for every situation could be the tool for communicating with the outside of the automated driving vehicle. However, it takes longer to read the message than it does to turn on the blinker or pass the ball, and it can not be identified from a distance. Therefore, it is necessary to have a means of communication that can be understood instantly.

Communication between the vehicle and the pedestrian is done by eye contact and gesture. This type of non- verbal communication is faster and more reliable than messages. What kind of system do you have in mind for the automated driving vehicle to do the same? For an external display, it may be necessary to use a large display for conveying pictograms and personified pictures in an easy- to- understand manner, rather than the display for text. Alternatively, a number of lighting devices may be set on the vehicle roof so that they can be viewed at

and from a distance, such as speed indicator lights used in heavy- duty trucks in Japan, and the lighting pattern may be changed depending on the state of automated driving. This requires standardization and regulation around the world, but there are no language barriers and children can understand them. Mercedes- Benz is actually researching and developing a way to communicate between automated driving vehicles and pedestrians [36]. Here's how Mercedes- Benz recommends communicating between automated driving vehicles and pedestrians. This is a lighting device that is under development in a concept vehicle called a cooperative car, indicating that it is operating automatically for approaching pedestrians. A light arranged on the roof of the vehicle indicates that the vehicle is the automated driving vehicle, and the movement of the vehicle is displayed by the lighting method of the lamp. Lights located on the windshield, front grille, headlamp, mirror, lower part of the side window, etc., positioned so as to be visible from any angle of

, indicate the driving mode of autonomous driving and the lamp located on the roof indicates the movement of the vehicle (slow flashing indicates deceleration, fast flashing indicates approaching pedestrians, etc.). Mercedes says these represent the vehicle's own will and can communicate with pedestrians. The lamp on the roof emits turquoise blue as a color which gives a sense of security to pedestrians by examining each color. Flashes of red or yellow, like warning lights, may cause uneasiness among pedestrians and hinder the spread of automated driving, so colors that provide a sense of security are a well- considered choice.

Marelli corporation is researching and developing a system that controls the light distribution of headlamps and projects marks onto the road [37]. This is called a digital write processing unit. The headlamp is capable of not only finely controlling the light distribution according to the traveling condition but also projecting the mark for warning the

driver on the road surface. In order to precisely control the light distribution, the projection of three LEDs is composed of 1.3 million micromirrors, and the angle of the micromirrors is finely controlled to create the light distribution pattern. Since the light distribution is fine, the glare of oncoming cars and pedestrians is minimized compared with conventional headlamps. Of course, an external recognition sensor detects other vehicles and pedestrians and adjusts the light distribution to the most optimum possible from the navigation information and the position of the vehicle. Then, a guideline is indicated at a place where the road width becomes narrow, and a mark indicating the direction of a pedestrian is also displayed. The marks projected onto the road may be recognizable by pedestrians, although this may only be at night. So could the digital light processing unit be the new communication tool for vehicles and pedestrians?

Marelli's digital light processing unit is not the first to mark roads. It is still fresh in our memory that it was announced in 2015 in the Mercedes- Benz concept car F015 [38]. The F015 was Level 5 fully automated driving vehicle with the tagline Luxury in Motion. It is a phrase that expresses the state of realizing an interior in which the front seat can rotate backward and face the rear seat because there is no need to drive. In order to communicate with pedestrians, F015 installed LED matrix display units on the front and back of the vehicle to display messages. When there is a pedestrian, a zebra zone showing the pedestrian crossing is drawn on the road by a visible light laser, and the pedestrian can be urged to walk. When the pedestrian swings his/her hand, he/she understands the gesture, draws a text, and communicates with the pedestrian. Mercedes- Benz hired a social psychologist to research and develop a system to communicate with the pedestrian.
It is needless to say that the DS can be utilized for the evaluation of these communication tools described here.
5.13 Conclusion

In Section 5.2, gaze detection was used to evaluate HMI, and there were contact type and non- contact type systems. Each system had advantages and disadvantages, and it was necessary to select an appropriate system according to the purpose of the experiment and measure the viewpoint of
the driver. In the future, it was desired to develop a system that can detect the driver's viewpoint even in various experimental participants (poor eyesight) and environment (sunlight).

As mentioned in Section 5.3, reaction times must be strictly defined and are influenced by experimental procedures, so experimental scenarios, including experimental methods, must be examined. The experimental data must be processed on a statistical basis. As the number of experiments increases in the future, it is expected that experimental scenarios suitable for the evaluation will be developed.

In Section 5.4, the brain wave was used as a method to know the brain activity of the driver, and we introduced the measurement method in the paragraph. EEG could quantitatively know the arousal level of a driver and was used, for example, in research on a Level 3 automated driving system in which a take- over request exists. It was important to know the awakening state of the driver, and if the driving tasks are mixed between the driver and the system in the future, the system needs to know the driver's state, and one method is to use brain waves. In the research, it is possible to measure by using the introduced EEG, but when using it as a driver during actual driving, a more compact and simplified measurement system is required.

NIRS, as described in Section 5.5, was initially expensive and its large size made it difficult to use in DS. However, it is expected to become popular in the future, as cost reduction and miniaturization have advanced and hurdles for DS use have lowered.

The HR described in Section 5.6 has traditionally been measured by a tactile monitor attached to the chest. Recently, the method of estimating the HR from the pulse wave has become popular, and the method of taking the pulse from the wrist or the earlobe has been used. In the future, practical application of a non- contact type HR meter using millimeter wave radar is expected.

Section 5.7 explained a state estimation method of drivers by driving performance. The driver condition was estimated by measuring the vehicle motion because the driving performance appeared at the distance between vehicles and the driving position in the lane. Further, in estimating the driver state from the operation system, it is easier to use the steering operation which causes the lateral movement of the vehicle than the operation of the pedal which causes the longitudinal movement of the vehicle. Therefore, in Section 5.8, the SE method was introduced

as a typical method for analyzing steering operation. In actual vehicles, steering angle information can be easily extracted from Controller Area Network (CAN) signals, and it is considered that this method will become a general analysis method in the future.

Although the conditions under which the simulator sickness described in Section 5.9 can be avoided are known, from an ethical point of view, it is difficult to test whether the sickness occurs. Therefore, it is necessary to explain the risk of simulator sickness to the subjects of DS and to consider immediately interrupting the experiment if there is a fear of sickness.

In Section 5.10 we showed that in the trust evaluation of the DS, it is important to verify the subject's driving behavior in DS and the subject's driving behavior in actual environment, but more importantly, the information and actual environment provided by DS to the subject are provided to the subject. The DS has technical limitations at this time, on the other hand, drivers do not use all the information provided by the actual environment. Namely, the DS does not have to provide the driver with all the information provided from the actual environment, and the information that the DS can provide only needs to include the information used by the driver. Even if there is a limit to the information that the DS can provide, this can be done by optimizing the provided information or limiting the usage scenarios based on the mechanism of perception of the information used by the driver. If the information used by the driver can be covered by the information that can be provided from this limited DS, it means that it may be possible to design a DS that can obtain exceptionally reliable experimental results. In order to achieve this, the designer of DS would be required to have knowledge of the perceptual information used by the driver when driving, the mechanism of this perception, knowledge of the technical limits of the DS, and the creativity that can effectively connect these knowledge.

Section 5.11 introduced the items that can be evaluated by DS in each representative ADAS. Even in the future when the development of autonomous driving is desired, the necessity of ADAS evaluation in the developed car does not change because it takes time to spread fully automated driving.

Section 5.12 introduced how to use DS in take- over evaluation which is a problem for the present in automated driving. The issues leading to the practical application of automated driving were explained, and the
roles of DS were shown. The DS will play an increasingly important role in the development of automated driving in the future.

6.1 Introduction

In this chapter, we introduce three ADAS and three automated driving studies using DS conducted at Shibaura Institute of Technology. The first study for ADAS is presented in Section 6.2 "A study on the effect of HUD information on driving operation," the technology of Cooperative Intelligent Transport Systems (C- ITS) is used to communicate the information (position and velocity) of the vehicle with each other in the blind spot. We introduce an example of evaluating the effectiveness of a system that informs the driver of vehicles existence by Head Up Display (HUD) using a driving simulator (DS).

In Section 6.3, we introduce the research example using a DS. In this study, we construct a driver model that reflects individual driver characteristics for advanced emergency braking systems (AEBS) that may collide with a forward vehicle and used the driver model for the activation timing of AEBS. This introduces the effect evaluation of AEBS that reflected the individual driver characteristics.

Section 6.4 presents an example of a study using DS on the effect of a special alarm sound, focusing on the learning effect under unconsciousness. Usually, the warning sound is a high- frequency sound and is harsh to the ear, so sometimes the warning sound is turned off and is not effective. Therefore, in this study, we try to prove that there is an alarm effect by an unconscious learning effect even if the alarm sound is low frequency and not unpleasant.

Next, as one of the three studies of automated driving, Section 6.5 introduces an example of verification of subtasks with arousal effect during automated driving. At automated driving levels 2 and 3, there is a take- over from automated driving to manual driving, so the driver must not sleep during automated driving. Here, we examine a low- load subtask that maintains high arousal level without undue effort.

Section 6.6 provides an example of using heartbeat to estimate the driver's level of alertness during automated driving. Because the relationship between heart rate and alertness tends to vary among drivers, this study uses machine learning to understand the relationship between alertness and heart rate.

In Section 6.7, we introduce the research example using a DS. This study is to investigate and verify using DS the effect of low awakening states in drivers on driving operation and whether they are capable of accurate driving in an automated driving system corresponding to automated driving level 3, which involves switching from automated driving to manual driving.

In Section 6.8, this study focused on both the semi- automated driving system prior to fully automated driving and full self- driving automation, investigating the driving characteristics of drivers in each case.
6.2 A study on the effect of HUD information on driving operation
6.2.1 Introduction of evaluation for HUD information

Currently, advanced support systems, such as AEBS and Adaptive Cruise Control (ACC), have become popular due to measures for the widespread use in each country. The advanced support systems often use meters, mirrors, and the information display to inform drivers the operating status and to alert them the emergency. Most of the systems that are actually on the market inform drivers the possibilities of collisions by the combination of warning displays and warning sounds when the systems are activated. However, as the number of types of systems grows, the amount of information increase, which cause difficulty for the drivers to immediately recognize what danger the warning is for. In the future, the amount of the information provided will be expected to be increasing much more by utilizing the technology of C- ITS that is a communication technology with other traffic participants, such as vehicle- to- vehicle and vehicle- to- pedestrian communication [1], which is considered by companies and governments. When the drivers receive many information in dangerous situations, they may panic or drive in the wrong operation. When the display position is not appropriate, the information cannot be properly transmitted to the drivers, and the systems may not be effective enough to avoid collisions. In order to reduce these risks, it is necessary to study how to provide the information so that drivers can easily recognize and intuitively decide how they should perform the driving operation.

Therefore, the purpose of this study was to examine the effect evaluation of a system that provides drivers with information of traffic participants, such as vehicles, pedestrians, and bicycles, using a HUD and the technology of C- ITS. The HUD is generally said that a small amount of the driver's eye movement is required for providing information and has been rapidly spreading in recent years.
6.2.2 Method
6.2.2.1 Driving simulator
In this study, the experiments were conducted using a DS from the viewpoint of safety and required, as shown in Figure 6.1. The DS consisted of a

cylindrical screen and an actual vehicle body, which could reproduce the same movement as an actual vehicle by a motion device. Generally, a DS make it possible to safely conduct experiments even in such a condition where there may be at risk of injury to a driver in an actual vehicle.

6.2.2.2 Conditions for the experiment

As the method to provide the driver with the information, this study combined three types of notification in the system: (1) the display on the HUD of the presence of traffic participants, (2) the background color changes on the HUD, and (3) the single tone warning sound. In this study, we newly constructed three patterns in the system: Base, Distance, and Sound. In Base, the types and directions of approaching objects were shown on the HUD. In Distance, the background colors were gradually changed to green, yellow, and red, according to the distance between the ego vehicle and the approaching object, the types, and directions. In Sound, the warning sounds were presented with the playing cycle changed according to the distance. We compared the three patterns of Base, Distance, and Sound with an existing system, Off that displayed only the speed of the ego vehicle on the HUD. 6.2.2.3 Evaluation method

Based on the data obtained in the experiment, the drivers' brake operations were analyzed targeting on the time to collision (TTC), average deceleration, and maximum deceleration. The results were compared between the systems, expecting to reveal the driving behavior to avoid the collision with traffic participants. A Wilcoxon rank sum test was performed on each data to examine whether there was a significant difference between the systems.

In addition, the eye movements of the drivers were measured using a gaze- detection device. Using the obtained data, the ratio of gaze time during driving was calculated by nine divided areas in the front area of the vehicle (as shown in Figure 6.3): front window, left- front window, room mirror, HUD, meter, left- door mirror, left- side window, right- door mirror, and right- side window. After each experiment, we conducted a questionnaire using a five- step selection
formula for asking the inconvenience of the system to the driver and examined the effect by the method to provide the information.

6.2.4 Conclusion of evaluation for HUD information

In this research, we evaluated the effect of the systems that utilize the C- ITS technology to provide the information of traffic participants in the blind spot using the HUD to drivers. As a result, it was confirmed that the system using sounds had the most effect on the brake operation, and the system using display also had a certain effect. On the other hand, the system that presented sounds resulted in an increase in the evaluation of annoyance and could be unsuitable as a means to always use for providing the information. This study simply changed the type of information presentation in each system to compare the effect. However, in the future, it will be necessary to examine the method of providing the information of traffic participants in blind spots in a more complex way. For example, only display is used at low- or medium-

risk levels while the display and sounds are combined at high- risk levels like existing systems. In addition, it is essential to create appropriate Human Machine Interface (HMI) by studying methods, which can allow drivers to more quickly recognize the information of traffic participants in blind spots, such as the display size and coordination method, and can reduce the time required for judgment of drivers.
6.3 Study on AEBS applying driver models
6.3.1 Introduction of evaluation for AEBS

This section is to introduce the experiments that were conducted to investigate further sophistication, as an example of AEBS that operate in an emergency. As for sophistication, the effect of the system reflecting driver characteristics was evaluated by the experiments using a DS, by constructing individual driver models and applying them to the operation timing for collision warning systems.
6.3.2 AEBS taking into account the individual characteristics of drivers

International standards for AEBS uniformly set based on the data of various driving operations in normal driving. The activation timing of alarms is set in order not to interfere with the drivers' normal operations. When the alarm interferes with the driver's driving operation, there is a possibility that the functions of the AEBS are not fully utilized by providing unsolicited feeling to the driver. However, there are various timings of drivers' operation in normal driving. By presenting an alert early for some drivers, it may be possible to take actions with sufficient margin to avoid collisions without interfering with the drivers' operations. Therefore, this study examined the effect and effectiveness, using the driver model reflecting the individual driving characteristics for the activation timing of the AEBS alarm. (Figure 6.4) As driver models, transfer function models, crossover models, forward gaze models, fuzzy models, and neural network (NN) models have been proposed. There are also tailor- made driving support systems [2] that reflect the individual characteristics of drivers, using the driver model. In this research, we used a NN, which measures the nonlinear driving operation of a driver and could model nonlinear control to model it. The driver model is constructed by training NN to learn driving operations of a driver. The driver model monitors the driver's operation by estimating the driving operation of the driver. When the driver's operation is different from the normal driving, such as a delay in brake operation, the driver model makes the decision to present an alert. In this study, we examined the effect by applying the driver model to the alarm activation timing.
Figure 6.4 AEBS with driver model

Experiments were conducted to examine (1) the measurement of the braking operation of drivers to construct the driver model and (2) the evaluation when the driver model was applied to the alarm activation timing. The DS was composed of a visual display and a force display, and could reproduce up to a deceleration of
4.5 \mathrm{m / s}^2
during braking, where the driver could feel the deceleration. The participants

6.3.7 Conclusion of evaluation for AEBS

In this research, we investigated a performance improvement method using a driver model for collision damage mitigation braking systems that operate in an emergency. As a result, the following conclusions were obtained:

1. When the deceleration of the preceding vehicle was large, the risk of driving became large, and the drivers tended not to impair acceptability of the alarm activation timing even if the alarm was presented earlier than the timing of the braking operation in their usual driving. 
2. It was found that the safety evaluation was higher by presenting the alarm at the timing applied to each driver rather than the one at the uniformly set operation timing.

In this study, the safety evaluation was performed to clarify the effect of applying individual driver characteristics to the alarm activation timing, using the driver model. This research targeted on the driver's braking operation along with the deceleration of the preceding vehicle. In the future, it will be necessary to

study the effects in various driving scene. Additionally, the NN was used to build the driver model. In the further study, it will be also necessary to consider the use of Time Delay NN, which can dynamically handle time- series data, in order to improve the simulation accuracy of the driver model.
6.4 Effect of unconscious learning for driver attention
6.4.1 Introduction of unconscious learning

In recent years, various safety technologies have been developed to reduce automobile accidents. However, although the number of fatal accidents due to drivers' violation of their duty to drive safely has been on a decreasing trend, as shown in Figure 6.11, the percentage is still high [3]. It is considered that this is because the consciousness of the driver for the safe driving duty has not changed.
Figure 6.11 Fatal traffic accident rate in Japan

As a technology to prevent the accident beforehand, the forward collision warning system has been developed. The forward collision warning system needs to sound the warning early in order to avoid the collision. If this is the case, an excessive warning will be given, and the driver will feel bothersome and avoid the current warning sound.

Then, in the previous research, it was hypothesized that it was effective as a warning, even if it was not a high sound to attract attention, noticing that human acts by learning under unconsciousness. In general, the intermittent sound of high- frequency band such as
1 - 4\mathrm{kHz}

is used as the warning sound in order to sense the sense of urgency. This is because humans tend to feel a sense of urgency about "a high- frequency sound that is regularly periodic and intermittent" [4, 5]. However, in the scene of high urgency, we thought that calm sound rather than urgent sound could act calmly, so we adopted low sound as the alarm and conducted experiments. Noise in the car is noise from the road and muffled noise. The sound from the road surface has a frequency of
5 - 30\mathrm{Hz}
, and the muffled sound has a frequency of about
5 - 200\mathrm{Hz}
[6]. Therefore, the intermittent sound of
250\mathrm{Hz}

, which is slightly higher than the noise in the car, was considered as the adopted warning sound. As a result, the response time of the driver for the dangerous event became earlier, and the driver did not feel the trouble compared with the present alarm sound [7].

In this study, the warning sound mentioned previously is adopted as an induction sound to induce safety confirmation. And, it was considered that the consciousness for the safety confirmation action was
improved, when the driver learns the pattern of the induction sound under the unconsciousness. Experiments are conducted and verified using a DS.
6.4.2 Experimental method
6.4.2.1 Outline of the experiment

The DS used in this experiment is a six- axis motion type. The participants were 16 men in their 20s who had ordinary driver licenses. 6.5 Comparison of the effects among the keeping awakening tasks for the driver during automated driving using EEG analysis
6.5.1 Introduction of keeping awakening tasks

At present, automated driving technology is attracting attention mainly in the automobile and IT industries. In the automated driving vehicle, the automated driving system independently recognizes, judges, and operates on the basis of information from various sensors and cameras mounted on the vehicle, and carry the vehicle to the destination. Since the workload of the driver during the automated driving becomes small by the system taking charge of all the work in the operation, the lowering of the arousal degree is worried [10].

The Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) classifies vehicle driving support levels, including self- driving technology, into six levels from level 0 to level 5 according to the function of the system and defines them as shown in Table 6.11 [11]. Generally, the system called automated driving is over level 2, but in the stage of levels 2 and 3, the peripheral environment monitoring by the driver and the correspondence in the emergency are required. Therefore, it is necessary to avoid the situation that the arousal of the driver lowers.

spans.content: As drowsy countermeasure techniques of the driver in the driving, there are some techniques to detect the low arousal condition of the driver by sensors and cameras, etc. and to give the stimulation. However, since these methods cannot improve the environment in which the arousal state lowers, they may cause the drowsiness again after the stimulation presentation. On the other hand, the methods which always give the stimulation regardless of the arousal state of the driver can very easily realize the arousal state maintenance of the driver, if these can be dealt with problems such as troublesome and habituation to the stimulation. Therefore, in this study, we focused on the method to maintain the arousal condition while giving constant stimulation.

In this study, at first, the investigation was carried out on three kinds of tasks: one kind of load task to the driver mounted in the automated driving vehicle at present, and two kinds of tasks expected to be mounted for the purpose of the arousal maintenance in future. Next, we devised two new tasks to maintain the driver's wakefulness with different approaches. Then, the experiment was carried out for 16 general drivers by the driving simulator (SloTDS- O in 2.1), which reproduced these five kinds of tasks, and the wakefulness maintenance effect was compared.
6.5.2 Experimental tasks
6.5.2.1 Conventional method (1): Holding steering wheel

6.5.2.1 Conventional method (1): Holding steering wheelIn some automated driving in level 2 vehicles on the market at present, a task of holding steering wheel during automated driving is imposed on the driver. The main purpose of this task is to prevent the driver in the automated driving from engaging in the task other than the driving operation and to quickly return to the driving operation in the emergency. Since no special equipment or special operation is required, the driver can be easily engaged. However, it is concerned that it leads to the physical fatigue, because both arms are restrained, even if the driver does not actually drive. In this study, the driver is required to actively steer the steering wheel like the manual operation according to the driving of the vehicle under the condition that the driver understands the automated driving.
6.5.2.2 Conventional method (2): Pushing button

6.5.2.2 Conventional method (2): Pushing buttonAs a load task to the driver, the button operation is carried out at fixed time intervals. The main purpose of this system is to check the driver's drowsiness. By switching to manual driving according to the situation, it becomes possible to avoid the automated driving in the low arousal condition. Though there is no driver load as much as the holding steering wheel, this may give the trouble for the monotonous task. In this study, the speech stimulation was presented every 1 min, and the reproduction was carried out as a problem to push the button installed in the steering wheel.
6.5.2.3 Conventional method (3): Saccadic eye movement

6.5.2.3 Conventional method (3): Saccadic eye movementThe saccade motion is one of the motions which occur in the human eyeball, and it occurs when the gaze moves from one gaze point to another gaze point. It may occur involuntarily when viewing natural images or reading texts, or it may occur voluntarily. It is known that this movement tends to decrease in the low arousal state. Hoshino et al. [12] carried out the experiment under the hypothesis that the lowering of the arousal can be suppressed by inducing this motion by the visual stimulation, and it was confirmed that the lowering of the arousal of the driver was significantly suppressed by the load task in which the right and

left flashing stimulation of the light displayed in HUD is followed by the eye. In this technique, the driver does not have to move the body consciously, so the reduction of the physical burden becomes possible. As a problem, it is mentioned that the oversight of the stimulation occurs, when the presentation position is not observed during the stimulation presentation.
6.5.2.4 Proposed method (1): Information provision

The first task proposed as a new method is to present various information around one's own vehicle to a driver as a voice stimulus, and the driver only hears it. The feature of this method is that it can support the peripheral environment monitoring of the driver, while utilizing the information around the own vehicle which changes every moment as a fresh stimulus. As an image of this method, an example of scenery from inside the car and information provided by the system is shown in Figure 6.20.
Figure 6.20 Concept of information provision system

This time, the information judged to be usable as the stimulation is traffic situation, weather forecast, sightseeing information, future travel route notification, and geography and history of the circumference. Among them, traffic situation and weather forecast are the information which most people would care if they were moving by their vehicle. Though the remaining three information were not necessarily required, it was considered that it was possible to make the driver interested in the peripheral environment by working as a sightseeing guide. By periodically presenting these information from the system, it aims at the maintenance of the waking condition of the driver.
6.5.2.5 Proposed method (2): Single light blinking

Next, the proposed method attempts to maintain the arousal condition by blinking the light source installed in the place which comes into the driver's visual field at the fixed period. In devising this technique, the physiological phenomenon of the human was referred. It is generally known that the human respiratory cycle changes by various factors, and it is reported that the respiratory frequency decreases when sleepiness occurs [13] and that the respiration synchronizes with rhythmic movement of limbs and visual stimulation. From these facts, it was considered that the lowering of the respiratory frequency was avoided by presenting the blinking stimulation in the usual respiratory cycle for the visual sense of the driver, by synchronizing the actual respiratory cycle with the blinking stimulation, and as a result, it was connected with the maintenance of the arousal condition.
In this study, a white LED bulb (color temperature
10000\mathrm{K}
, luminous intensity
2180\mathrm{mcd}
) of
5\mathrm{mm}

diameter was installed in front of the driver, and the stimulus presentation was carried out by flashing it. The frequency of blinking stimulation was 17 times per minute (3.5 s per attempt), referring to the general respiratory cycle of the adult. The intensity of the light source was set as shown in Figure 6.21, because the ratio of inspiratory, expiratory, and rest periods was roughly 1:1.5:1 in one breath of a human. That is, the LED gradually brightens at the inhalation of
1\mathrm{s}
, gradually darkens at the expiration of
1.5\mathrm{s}
after reaching the maximum luminance, and the loop which maintains the darkest state for
1\mathrm{s}
as a rest period is repeated until the end of the experiment.

6.5.5 Discussion

In this experiment, it was confirmed that 10 out of 12 persons fell asleep in the environment in which nothing was done. This was more than initially expected. Most of the experiments were carried out by sitting for
20\mathrm{min}

without doing anything. It was easy to get bored and sleepy because there were many afternoon hours. And, the tension lowered by feeling that there was no necessity of the own driving, and the resistance for the sleepiness seemed to be also difficult to occur.

As a result of the experiment, the task which seemed to have the most arousal maintenance effect as a whole was Holding steering wheel. As the reason, it seems to be related that the body was moved during the automated driving and that the posture was taken in the same way as the manual driving. It is said that the effect of the active action on the arousal is large, and it is effective for the finger difference call of the railway operator in the familiar thing. And, the conversation is also noticed as an active action, and the arousal effect by the conversation during driving and monotonous work are studied. The present experimental results show that the active task has a higher arousal maintenance effect than the passive task. Since the inside of a vehicle is narrow and the same posture is often observed for a long time, it is considered that the active load of holding the steering wheel and actually rotating the steering wheel effectively led to the arousal maintenance. And, there was "I woke up just by holding the steering wheel" as a comment of the subject person after the experiment. From this, it was indicated that the degree of concentration to the driving naturally heightens by becoming the same posture as usual driving, even if it is recognized to be the automated driving in the brain.

Though the Pushing button task was also the active motion, and the subjective evaluation was high, the arousal by the EEG tended to be similar to other task. It is considered that the sufficient arousal effect could not be obtained because the work task was monotonous and the frequency was also low. This could be confirmed from facial expression and comment, and the voice stimulation was presented during the time from feeling the sleepiness to actually falling asleep, and the sleepiness was temporarily solved.

In the peripheral situation providing task which is one of the proposed methods, more than half of the subjects fell asleep. Many subjects fell asleep in the latter half of the experiment, and a large lowering of the arousal degree was shown in the graph of the arousal degree in the latter half. From this, it is considered that the habituation to the voice stimulation occurred. In the present experiment, it was considered that the fresh stimulation could be presented by presenting multiple information prepared in advance for each driving point. However, the driver side only listened to the presented voice, and it became only sound stimulation, if the consciousness was not turned. By this, it seems that the habituation to the voice, not the information, occurred.

On Saccade induction stimulation and Single light blinking task, the subjective evaluation was low, and there were many opinions of "I didn't feel anything" even in the comment. However, it seems that the fixed effect appears in the Saccade induction stimulation, when the number of falling asleep and the arousal degree graph are observed. It can be said that the driver gives the arousal effect without feeling the large load to the driver, because the physical burden is little, though the driver actively causes the saccade

motion, and because it works for eyes and brain using the simple light stimulation. Since the change of eye movement and respiration was not confirmed in this experiment, it seems to be necessary to carry out the additional experiments on whether the wakefulness maintenance as expected is actually carried out. And, there was the comment of "I feel sleepy when I look down" on the LED stimulation. From this fact, it is also necessary to examine the layout in presenting the optical stimulation.
On the experiment carried out this time, when the proportion of falling asleep was observed according to the attribute of the subject person, the youth was
, and the old age was

, and the significant tendency was confirmed. This means that the effect of the stimulation greatly changes by the age group of the driver. As the factor in which the falling sleep tendency which is different by the age group appeared, we consider sleep disorder and functional depression of the sense organ with the aging. In general, it is known that human sleep changes with age. In particular, it has been reported that the elderly have decreased total sleep time, increased shallow sleep, and decreased sleep efficiency due to arousal from sleep [14]. In this experiment, the existence of these symptoms is uncertain, because the life rhythm of the subject is not accurately grasped. However, when these symptoms occur chronically to the driver, even if the person intends to take the sleep time of the previous day sufficiently, the sleep is not actually sufficient, and the sleepiness may easily appear in the daytime. In addition, the tendency of early to bed and early to rise by the progress of the sleep phase is easy to appear in the old people, and this seems to become a factor of the sleepiness generation in the daytime. Aging is also known to affect sensory organs such as vision and hearing, and symptoms such as visual field narrowing, hearing loss, and reduction of the audible range appear. As a result, there was a possibility that the elderly driver could not see the arousal maintenance stimulation, could not hear the driving sound from the simulator, and could not feel the arousal maintenance stimulation in comparison with the young and middle- aged driver. From the above fact, it seems to be important to consider not all drivers uniformly, but age group and characteristic of the user deeply when dealing with the awakening of the driver. All the contents described here are hypotheses. The number of data used for the analysis is also 3- 5 persons for each age group, and it is insufficient for completely grasping the characteristics of the age group. In order to clarify the relationship between the age group and falling asleep, it is necessary to increase the number of experimental subjects in each age group and to conduct large- scale experiments focusing on the daily life rhythm of drivers.
6.5.6 Summary of keeping awakening tasks

The investigation was carried out on the tasks of the type which always gives the fixed stimulation for the purpose of the arousal maintenance of the driver in the automated driving, and three types were introduced as conventional methods. And, as new methods, two kinds of tasks of presenting information on vehicle periphery and using optical stimulation were proposed. On six kinds of environments including these five kinds of tasks and the condition of doing nothing, the experiments using the automated driving function of the DS were carried out for general drivers of 16 persons, and the arousal maintenance effect was compared. As the result, though 10 persons in 12 persons fell asleep under the condition of doing nothing, it became possible to reduce the number of persons by carrying out each task. This effect was found in active tasks. And, it became clear that the holding steering wheel has the fixed arousal action, that the consideration of the habituation to not only the content but also the voice itself is necessary for the voice stimulation, that the light stimulation can carry out the arousal support in the range which the driver does not notice, etc. In addition, the possibility in which the age group of the driver was greatly related to the awakening of the driver was indicated. On this fact, we indicated the possibility of the effect by sleep disorder and functional depression of the sense organ by the aging.

As future issue, reexamination of contents and presentation position of the stimulation based on the present result, detection of the change of eye movement and respiration in the use of the equipment, data acquisition in actual road environment and result comparison, etc. are needed. On the stimulation, not only the simple work task like this time, but also the arousal maintenance task which adopted the active work such as phonation and conversation should be checked. In addition, since the sleepiness of the driver is expected to be greatly affected by the sleep of the previous day, the meal immediately before and the time zone, etc., the control of the experimental condition and the change of the driver characteristic by the change of the condition, etc. would also be examined. 6.6 Estimation of driver drowsiness change in automated driving using heart beat analysis
6.6.1 Introduction of heart beat analysis

Recently, the research and development for realizing the automated driving are rapidly developing. And, the automated driving in the simple level has been practically used. The automated driving technology is classified into the level which consists of five stages from the degree of the driver involvement and the responsibility point of view by SAE of America [11].

In the present automated driving technology, the driver must monitor the surrounding environment, and the operation must be continued when the system in emergency cannot cope with it (level 3 or lower automated driving). Therefore, in automated driving at a simple level, a system which can realize the takeover of safe operation is indispensable. In order to realize this safe driving succession, in a previous study, we obtained the heart rate information (RRI) of the driver, calculated LF/HF and CVRR(Coefficient of Variation of R- R interval) by heart rate variability analysis, and classified arousal by machine learning.

However, in addition to the above three indicators, there are many indicators that can estimate the degree of arousal, and it is not known which one is the most effective. In this study, besides heart rate index (RRI, LF/HF, CVRR) which was handled in the research until now, the index which can show the physical condition of human is newly added, and stability and reactivity are analyzed and compared, and the effective index in the estimation of the arousal is verified.
6.6.2 Heart rate analysis
6.6.2.1 Autonomic nervous system

Humans regulate circulation of blood and body temperature by two autonomic nervous systems. This autonomic nervous system cannot be adjusted by its own will, because it works unconsciously when it receives change and stimulation of the surrounding environment [15].

The autonomic nervous system is composed of the antagonism of two autonomic nervous systems, "sympathetic nervous system" and "parasympathetic system" as shown below. By adjusting the balance of these two autonomic nervous systems, the body adapts to the change and stimulation of the peripheral environment.
sympathetic nervous system
It is predominant when the body is active, such as during exercise, and promotes physical functions such as palpitations, increased blood pressure, and increased body temperature.
parasympathetic system

When the body is resting, such as during sleep, it becomes dominant, and it has a function to suppress the physical functions such as palpitation, blood pressure lowering, and body temperature lowering.
6.6.2.2 RRI (R-R interval)

The heart rate data of the driver acquired in this study is only RRI, which is the heartbeat interval of the heart rate. In the electrocardiogram of the human, there is the name of P, Q, R, S, and T in the mountain and valley of the waveform as follows. The interval of R with the largest amplitude is called RRI (R- R interval) (Figure 6.28). The fluctuation of RRI is affected by the regulation by the autonomic nervous system, and it fluctuates by the change of position and mental activity.
6.6.2.3 Heart rate variability analysis
By analyzing the heart rate variability of the RRI explained in Section 6.2.2.2.2, various heart rate indices can be obtained as follows [16].
LF (Low Frequency)/HF (High Frequency)

It is obtained by frequency analysis of the time series data of RRI. LF (Low Frequency) shows mainly the activity of the sympathetic nervous system and a part of the activity of the parasympathetic nervous system in the frequency band of
0.05 - 0.15\mathrm{Hz}
. HF (High Frequency) shows parasympathetic nervous system activity in the frequency band of
0.15 - 0.40\mathrm{Hz}
. These ratios, LF/HF, indicate the balance of the autonomic nervous system and are often used as an index of human stress (Figure 6.29).
Figure 6.29 Heart rate variability analysis
Generally, the window interval in the frequency analysis is carried out by RRI for
5\mathrm{min}

, but in this study, the window interval was verified, and the classification result by the machine learning carried out in the next section 6.5 was compared by setting the window interval at 30, 60, 90, 180 s, and
90~\mathrm{s}
which was the result with the highest accuracy was applied.
SDNN (CVRR)
The standard deviation of the RRI (coefficient of variation). Variations in heart rate variability are shown. RMSSD
Square root of the mean square of the difference between consecutive adjacent RRIs indicates the intensity of vagal tone.
SDNN/RMSSD
It shows the activity of the autonomic nervous system as well as LF/HF. Used as an alternative indicator for LF/HF.
Origin distance of Lorentz plot (LP)
The origin distance LP is plotted with the nth RRI on the horizontal axis and the
\mathrm{n + 1th}
RRI on the vertical axis. The autonomic nervous system is fluctuated by the distance between the center of the distribution and the origin.
In this study, we compare and analyze these indices to verify effective measures for arousal estimation.

6.7 Driving characteristics of low awakening drivers during transition from automatic driving to manual driving
6.7.1 Introduction

Currently, various researches and developments are being conducted toward the realization of automated driving systems. Organizations in each country, such as National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and SAE International, have defined the roadmaps of fully automated driving systems, in which drivers are not involved in driving at all. The roadmaps include a system that stops the automatic driving function when the automatic driving system reaches the functional limit and shifts to the manual driving. In this system, there is a possibility that drivers cannot perform appropriate driving, when the drivers have been in low awakening states, such as drowsiness, at the timing of switching the system from automatic driving to manual driving.

This research investigated the effect of drivers' awake states on driving behavior, targeting the system that shifted to manual driving when the automatic driving system reached the functional limit. In the experiment, drivers in low awakening states and those in the awake state were examined under the same conditions to compare the driving behaviors at different awakening levels. A DS was used to ensure the safety of drivers in the experiment.

In this experiment, we examined the drivers' behavior for avoiding collision at that moment and compared the avoidance behaviors of the drivers in between low arousal states and arousal states. 6.7.4 Conclusion

6.7.4 ConclusionFrom the results obtained in the experiment, it was concluded that the lower the arousal level was, the more difficult the proper driving operation became, when the system switched from automatic driving to manual driving. Autonomous driving systems are the systems to support the driver's safety and comfort. However, when the system's functional limit requires the switching to manual driving, the delay time for driver's operations shown in this study should be fully considered. For example, the provision of information and reminder in advance might be effective for the delay time. In addition, drivers who are in arousal states can perform the driving operation quickly and properly. Therefore, it might be effective to use two types of systems together: one system to detect the driver's wakefulness during autonomous driving and the other system to prevent drivers in low- arousal states from performing driving operations.

6.8.1 Introduction of evaluation for transition from automatic driving to manual driving

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport, and Tourism in Japan (MLIT) was carried out a "Conditions for safe transition to drivers in driving support type automatic driving systems. [17] Many automobile manufacturers and research institutes in recent years have been developing automated driving systems. The widespread use of automated driving system automobiles can bring about various advantages to users. One of these major factors is that driver burdens regarding driving can be reduced. This can exhibit effects in providing driving support to the elderly as a result. Long- distance driving also becomes easier. Work such as daily commuting going back and forth on the same road also can be systematized. Therefore, wide- ranging use from long- distance leisure activities to daily commutes can be expected from the widespread use of self- driving automobiles [18].

NHTSA and SAE have defined a roadmap leading to autonomous driving with regards to full selfdriving automation and have divided the levels according to system capabilities [19- 21]. On the roadmap, full self- driving automation is classified as level 4 in NHTSA and level 5 in SAE. The NHTSA and SAE roadmaps are each shown in Table 6.17.

As part of a trend toward the practical application of automated driving in Japan, the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport, and Tourism also presented content in 2013 with the aim of achieving an autopilot system (automated- driving) on expressways in the early 2020s. The driving range of the autopilot system presented by the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport, and Tourism is shown in Figure 6.46.
