Figure 6.46 Driving range of automated driving [22]

Until the realization of full self- driving automation, a system has been defined in which a driver constantly monitors the operation of an automated driving system and performs automatic driving under the responsibility of the driver [23]. In this scenario, automatic driving functions are suspended and switches to manual driving when the automated driving system malfunctions or reaches its functional limit. This automated driving system is classified as Level 3 automated driving in the NHTSA and SAE roadmaps in Table 6.17 [24]. It is thought that drivers in this automated driving system could perform the driving operation at the time of switching if the driver can carefully monitor the control of the system. However, there is the possibility that the driver cannot appropriately operate the vehicle when switching from automated to manual driving if the driver is in a low awakening state (e.g., drowsy) [25].

Based on the above background, the objectives of this study are to investigate and verify using DS the effect of low awakening states in drivers on driving operation and whether they are capable of accurate driving in an automated driving system corresponding to automated driving Level 3 in Table 6.17, which involves switching from automated driving to manual driving. In this regard, experiments were conducted in the same conditions on drivers in a low awakening state and normal state as a verification method of whether driving behavior is accurate, and we investigate and verify this by comparing each driving behavior.

Simultaneously, also considering full self- driving automation (which does not require driver monitoring), drivers do not have to engage in driving during automated driving in the expressway, but smoothly switching from automated to manual driving is necessary when exiting an expressway. However, if the driver falls asleep during automated driving on the expressway, then there is the possibility that a smooth transition to manual driving may not occur near the expressway exit. Therefore, another research objective is to clarify driver operation characteristics when the driver falls asleep during automated driving, the automated driving is canceled at the expressway exit, and the driver transitions from a low awakening state to an alert state.

6.8.2.2 EEG measurements

The cerebral cortex is composed of about 14 billion nerve cells which show weak potential changes along a certain rhythm that is related to the activity state and stimulation of the brain. A potential fluctuation of several tens of
\mu \mathrm{V}
, including a frequency component of
0.5 - 100\mathrm{~Hz}

, can be obtained when actually attaching an electrode to the scalp and amplifying the biological signal with a biological amplifier. A record of such electrical phenomena in the brain is referred to as an EEG. Each part human cerebrum is related to perceptual information processing and body movement control, and it is said that inferences on the relationship between human behavior and brain function could be made by measuring the potential fluctuations derived from each of the parts of the cerebrum. The International Federation of Clinical Neurophysiology determined 21 points in the head for deriving EEGs, and this derivation method is called the 10/20 electrode system (10/20 system) [26]. Actual measurements involve picking and choosing from these 21 points specified by the 10/20 system as a basis. Figure 6.47 shows a conceptual diagram of the 10/20 system and the derivation sites in the 10/20 system. This 10/20 system can be classified into the two methods of the reference derivation method and bipolar derivation method. The reference derivation method measures potential differences by attaching one electrode to an unrelated electrode such as an earlobe and another electrode to the scalp, and this has been used in clinical examinations. The bipolar derivation method records potential differences between two points on the scalp. The reference derivation method, which is often used in the field of ergonomics, was used in this study, and the three locations where
\alpha
and
\delta
waves clearly appear (Fz, Cz, Pz) were measured [27]. Frequency analysis on the measured EEGs also results in its classification into the three frequency bands of

), and
\alpha

). The
\alpha

\alpha

\beta

6.8.3 Experimental methods
6.8.3.1 Low awakening driver

Research on low awakening drivers has investigated the effects of driver awakening on driving behavior when switching from automated driving to manual driving. The automated driving system placed from levels 1 through 3 in NHTSA and SAE in the automated driving system roadmap shows that this is automated driving, but this is mainly operated by the driver. Therefore, drivers must constantly monitor the automated driving system. However, drivers may have their attention diverted when traveling long distances or driving on familiar roads such as commutes, and the possibility of falling asleep or looking away increases. This indicates that there is a risk where drivers may temporarily not be able to conduct the monitoring in an automated driving system. Drivers may be able to immediately return to monitoring the system operation in the case of inattentive or temporarily careless driving, but there is the possibility that drivers cannot suitably operate the vehicle when switching from automated to manual driving in emergency conditions if the driver has fallen asleep or is in a low awakening state.

It is assumed in experiments that drivers are in a low awakening state when using the automated driving system. When the driver enters a low awakening state, the automated driving system simulates a situation where the functional limit is reached, and the driver performs an emergency avoidance driving operation when switching from automated driving to manual driving. The operational characteristics of the driver relating to emergency avoidance were analyzed during these experimental conditions. Experiments under the same conditions were conducted for a driver in an alert state in order to compare with the operational characteristics of a driver in a low awakening state. The methods described in Section 6.8.3.1.3 were used in the evaluation of the driver awakening state. EEG measurements shown in Section 6.8.2.2 were also used. The measured EEGs in this experiment were in the 8â€“13 Hz band, which corresponds to
\alpha
waves.

The holding and nonholding of the steering wheel by the driver is also an important factor in the automated driving system. For example, systems which sound an alarm when the driver is no longer holding the steering wheel have been considered in the NHTSA and SAE level 3 system, where the driver is the main operator. However, the purpose of using the automated driving system is to reduce the burdens of driving, and for that purpose. Therefore, the construction of an automated driving system without holding a steering wheel has been considered, and operating the automated driving system without holding the steering wheel by presenting the functional limit of the system as an alarm to the driver has also been considered. In this study, experiments were conducted in the low awakening state of the driver with the assumption of a state in which the steering wheel is not held, which has a high risk due to switching from automated driving to manual driving. Therefore, experiments were conducted by informing the participants to not hold the steering wheel during automated driving.
6.8.3.1.1 Experimental scenario

The experimental scenario involved the driver using the automated driving system and driving in the left lane of an expressway. The reason for selecting an expressway was because the realization of an automated driving system was thought to occur sooner in an expressway rather than a general road, where there are many complex changes in the road environment.
First, the driver's own vehicle used an automated driving system and drove in the left lane of an expressway at a constant speed of
27.8~\mathrm{m / s}
(100\mathrm{km / h})
. After driving a certain distance, another vehicle merging from the merging lane appeared. This vehicle had an intervehicle distance of
56~\mathrm{m}
in front of the autonomous vehicle merged at a speed of
16.7~\mathrm{m / s}
(60~\mathrm{km / h})
. An intervehicle distance of
56~\mathrm{m}
was set here because this was in accordance with the appropriate intervehicle distance of
2~\mathrm{s}
in an expressway. Also given that the autonomous vehicle was driving at a speed of
27.8~\mathrm{m / s}
and the interrupting vehicle was driving at a speed of
16.7~\mathrm{m / s}
, there was the possibility that the autonomous vehicle and interrupting vehicle could collide after the interrupting vehicle merged in front of the autonomous vehicle.

The automated driving system in this experiment set situations where there was the possibility of colliding with this interrupting vehicle as a functional limit, so all operating rights were transferred to the driver and manual driving was implemented when the interrupting vehicle finished merging in front of the autonomous vehicle. Therefore, the driver must use their own decisions to conduct collision avoidance driving operation after the interrupting vehicle merged in front of the autonomous vehicle, and automated driving switched to manual driving. This research compares and verifies the driving operation of the driver in a low awakening state or alert state during this driving operation in order to avoid a collision.

The collision avoidance driving operation of the participant is thought to be due to brake or steering wheel operation. This study also set a large vehicle running on the left- hand lane of the autonomous vehicle in order to simulate actual traffic volumes. The driver was not informed prior to the experiment that an interrupting vehicle would appear from the merging lane while driving the automated driving system, and the number of tests was conducted once per driver. This was because once the driver experienced the fact that there was an interrupting vehicle, the driver would anticipate future occurrences and mentally prepare for this, changing their driving operation. Similarly, this was because it was assumed that the system switching to manual driving under situations which the driver did not predict would occur in environments where the automated driving system was actually used. There were 60 drivers participating in this experiment (40 in low awakening state and 20 in alert state), and experimental data conducted in the first session were used for analysis. Experiment participants were 60 men in their 20s who had ordinary driver's licenses. Experiment participants consented to cooperate in the experiment after having been explained the objectives of the study.

Level 1 is a normal alertness level, and the driver has no sleepiness at all, with stable blinking. At level 2, the driver is awake but somewhat sleepy, and behaviors such as yawning and opening their mouth can be seen. At level 3, the driver's expressions seem sleepy, showing increased yawning and re- seating themselves, exhibiting more smaller movements. At level 4, the driver's expression seems fairly sleepy, and they consciously blink. Behavior such as shaking the head to stay awake may also be seen. At level 5, the expressions become extremely sleepy, and the patient is no longer awake. Here, the eyelids have completely fallen and the eyes are close, and the neck may even be leaning back [30]. A video camera which shows the driver was installed inside the DS described later in this study. Assigning levels on the NEDO evaluation was conducted by monitoring the driver's facial expressions during the experiment using this device.

Alertness levels 1, 3, and 4 were used in this study. Of these, level 1 was set as the alert state, and levels 3 and 4 were set as the low awakening state. The reason why levels 2 and 5 were removed was because level 5 was set as a sleeping state where the eyes were close and operational behavior could not be conducted, and that level 2 is not a low awakening state but instead classified as an alert state.
6.8.3.2 Sleeping driver

6.8.3.2 Sleeping driverResearch on sleeping drivers aims to clarify the driving characteristics when a driver falls asleep during automated driving, the automated driving is cancelled at the expressway exit, and when the driver transitions from a sleeping state to an awakened state. The automated driving system positioned at NHTSA and SAE levels 4 and 5 on the automated driving system roadmap has the system as the main operator. Therefore, the driver is not obligated to constantly monitor the automated driving system. However, there is the possibility that drivers may not be able to smoothly switch to manual driving near exits if the driver falls asleep during automated driving of expressways.

6.8.5 Conclusions
6.8.5.1 Low awakening driver

Research on low awakening drivers investigated the effects of the sleeping state of the driver on driving operations when switching from automated driving to manual driving in experiments using a DS. The experimental scenario was a scene where a low- speed preceding vehicle interrupts from a merging lane in front of the autonomous vehicle, at which time the automated driving system switches from automated driving to manual driving, and the driver must operate the vehicle so as to avoid colliding with the preceding vehicle. The following conclusions were obtained from these results.
6.8.5.1.1 Proportion of driving operations for collision avoidance performed by the driver

The driver was confirmed to have conducted either braking operations or both braking and steering operations in order to avoid collision when the automated driving system switched from automated driving to manual driving. Almost all drivers in the low awakening and alert states were able to avoid collisions with braking operations, but
, and
of drivers at alertness levels 4, 3, and 1, respectively performed collision avoidance with both braking and steering operations.
6.8.5.1.2 Reaction time until the driver steps on brake

The reaction time was defined and evaluated as the time until a driver stepped on the brake after an interrupting vehicle interrupted from a merging lane to the lane of the autonomous vehicle in order to evaluate whether the driver was able to appropriately conduct braking operations for collision avoidance when switching from automated driving to manual driving. Results showed that the reaction time of drivers was distributed from 2.5 to 6 s at alertness level 4, 3.5- 5 s at level 3, and 0.3- 3 s at level 1. The average reaction time of 20 participants was 4.3 s at alertness level 4, 3.6 s at level 3, and 2.0 s at level 1. It can be seen from these results that the reaction time of drivers when the automated driving system switched from automated driving to manual driving was 2.3 s slower at alertness level 4 when compared
to that at the alert state, and the reaction time of drivers was 1.6 s slower at alertness level 3 when compared to that at the alert state.
6.8.5.1.3 Maximum brake pedal force

The maximum brake pedal force during braking operations was evaluated in order to determine whether drivers were able to appropriately operate the brake pedal during braking operations for collision avoidance. Results showed that the maximum brake pedal force for drivers was distributed from 5 to 300 N at alertness level 4, 10 to

lower at alertness level 3 when compared to that at the alert state.
6.8.5.1.4 Time to maximum brake pedal force

The time to maximum brake pedal force during braking operations was evaluated in order to verify whether drivers were able to appropriately and quickly perform braking operations for collision avoidance. Results showed that the time to maximum brake pedal force in drivers was distributed from 0.5 to 8 s at alertness level 4, 0.5 to 3 s at level 3, and 2.5 to 6 s at level 1. 6.8.6 Conclusion of evaluation for transition from automatic driving to manual driving
This study focused on both the semi- automated driving system prior to fully automated driving and full self- driving automation, investigating the driving characteristics of drivers in each case.

It was concluded that accurate driving operations in automated driving systems that have a mechanism for switching from automated to manual driving became more difficult as the low alertness level of the driver became higher when switching from automated driving to manual driving. Automated driving systems are a system for supporting the safety and comfort of drivers, but it is thought that delay times for driver operations shown in this study (e.g., providing information or sounding warnings in advance) should be considered when needing to switch to manual driving due to functional limits of the system. Furthermore, drivers in an alert state can more rapidly and accurately operate vehicles, so it is thought that also providing a system that detects the alertness level of drivers during automated driving and prevents driving in a low awakening state could be effective.

Comparisons of the experimental results of the driving characteristics of sleeping and alert drivers falling asleep during automated driving and transitioning into an awakening state at expressway exits show that, for the braking characteristics during emergency avoidance behavior, drivers in the sleeping state had a long reaction time until initiating braking operations and smaller maximum brake pedal force. It can be seen from these results that over

of sleeping drivers collided with pedestrians due to delayed visual recognition of pedestrians and inability to forcefully press on the brake. Therefore, driving immediately after awakening may be linked with serious accidents, and there is a need to sufficiently awaken the driver before switching to manual driving if the driver has fallen asleep during automated driving. Time indices for sufficiently awakening drivers will need to be investigated as a future topic of study.
6.9 Conclusion

In Section 6.2, we evaluated the effect of the systems that utilize the C- ITS technology to provide the information of traffic participants in the blind spot using the HUD to drivers. As a result, it was confirmed that the system using sounds had the most effect on the brake operation, and the system using display also had a certain effect. In the future, it will be necessary to examine the method of providing the information of traffic participants in blind spots in a more complex way. And it will be required to create appropriate HMI by studying methods, which can allow drivers to recognize the information of traffic participants more quickly in blind spots.

In Section 6.3, our results was when the deceleration of the preceding vehicle was large, the risk of driving became large, and the drivers tended not to impair acceptability of the alarm activation timing even if the alarm was presented earlier than the timing of the braking operation in their usual driving. And it was found that the safety evaluation was higher by presenting the alarm at the timing applied to each driver rather than the one at the uniformly set operation timing. In the further study, various model construction methods such as TDNN, NARX, and LSTM have been proposed for driver models using machine learning, so it is necessary to consider the appropriate modeling method for constructing individual driver models.

In Section 6.4, we used subconscious learning to demonstrate that low- frequency, unobjectionable alarm sounds are also effective for hazardous events. By using the learning effect under the unconscious condition, it is thought that not only sound but also vibration and flashing of light which do not cause discomfort to the driver can be used as an alarm, and it is possible to design an alarm which is more acceptable to the driver. It can be said that DS is indispensable for such research on safety.

In Section 6.5, we examined subtasks that maintain alertness while driving and proposed effective subtasks. Although there are many subtasks that are effective in maintaining alertness, this study is characterized by the fact that the driver has a low load without compromising the comfort during automated driving. We will continue to use the DS to find such low- impact, effective subtasks.

In Section 6.6, we proposed using heart rate and machine learning to determine alertness. In the future, we will use DS to evaluate the method of estimating the heart rate from the pulse of the wrist and the noncontact method using such as the millimeter wave radar.

In Section 6.7, it was concluded that accurate driving operations in automated driving systems that have a mechanism for switching from automated to manual driving became more difficult as the low alertness level of the driver became higher when switching from automated driving to manual driving. And comparisons of the experimental results of the driving characteristics of sleeping and alert drivers falling asleep during automated driving and transitioning into an awakening state at expressway exits show that, for the braking characteristics during emergency avoidance behavior, drivers in the sleeping state had a long reaction time until initiating braking operations and smaller maximum brake pedal force.

Driving Simulators for the Evaluation of Human-Machine Interfaces in Assisted and Automated Vehicles

Driving Simulators for the Evaluation of Human- Machine Interfaces in Assisted and Automated Vehicles is a concise reference work on driving simulators, which conveys the technology behind simulator systems used to test driver assistance systems and automated vehicles, including electric vehicles. Coverage includes architecture, computer graphics, evaluation parameters and applied examples.

A driving simulator is a device that has the function of presenting similar visual, auditory and force perceptions to those experienced during driving, creating the illusion that the driver is driving an actual car. The advantage of tests using a driving simulator is that it can reproduce dangerous traffic situations and tests safely. Driving simulators are also valuable in research and development into intelligent driving systems, allowing for testing and evaluation in a simulation environment rather than on the road.

With its concise selection of relevant material and applied focus, this book will be of use to research and development professionals in industry and academic researchers whose work involves automotive systems and technologies in general, and particularly those working on driving simulators and automated driving.
